TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Treasurer's attention been drawn to the findings of the Home Finance Survey, conducted by the Melbourne Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research, which was published by the Victorian Housing Ministry in December 1981? Is he aware that 45 per cent of first home buyers surveyed had household incomes in excess of 150 per cent of average weekly earnings? Is it a fact that, since no means tests have been applied to the tax rebate for first home buyers during the past five years, some $100m of the $230m allocated for the first full year of the scheme will go to households which are in the top 25 per cent income group in Australia?

—My attention has not been drawn to that survey specifically. I thank the honourable gentleman for drawing my attention to it. I will have a look at it. The thrust of the honourable member's question is that in some way the tax rebate that the Government has chosen to give, in assisting first home buyers, is inappropriate. I am reminded of some of the things that were said by the honourable member and his colleagues some years ago when tax rebates in other areas were introduced. In particular, he was pleased to say some years ago, when he was a Minister in the former Government, that there can be no deception when each claimant, whether rich or poor, gets exactly the same rebate for education expenses. I suggest that the honourable member could apply that argument with equal force to housing.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL ACTION: EFFECTS ON EXPORT EARNINGS

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Treasurer indicate the effect that industrial unrest has had on Australia's export earnings and, also, its effect on Australia's standing as a reliable trading partner?

—My colleague the Deputy Prime Minister has already, on a number of occasions, drawn the attention of this House to the effect on export earnings- and therefore the international trading standing of Australia-of industrial stoppages. There can be no doubt that one of the contributing factors to the poorer than expected trade performance of Australia this year, and therefore our weaker balance of payments, has been the high level of industrial disputation. The fact cannot be denied that, in the three months to November 1981, working days lost in all industries were 60 per cent higher than in the previous three month period and two and a half times those lost in the three months to November 1980. That statistic alone illustrates the enormous contribution that industrial disputation has made to Australia's sluggish trade performance in this financial year.
—What about half a million people unemployed every day?

—One has only to reflect upon the strikes in the coal industry and the vast armada of ships tied up outside the port of Newcastle, of which the honourable member for Hunter should be more aware than just about any other honourable member of this House, to realise the enormous contribution that the disastrous industrial strife in parts of Australia has made to our very indifferent trading performance.

—I refer the Treasurer to statements made yesterday regarding the level of company tax in Australia and ask: Is it a fact that since 1976-77, company tax as a proportion of total taxation has fallen from 15 per cent to 13. 5 per cent while taxes on wage and salary earners have risen from 41.7 per cent to 45.7 per cent? Is it also a fact that taxes paid by wage and salary earners have risen approximately 40 per cent faster than have wages and salaries, while company taxes have risen by less than the rate of rise in company income? In the light of this situation, does the Treasurer regard a cut in company taxes as having a higher priority than tax cuts for wage and salary earners?

—I do not propose to be drawn into any speculation as to what ought to be done in particular Budget areas. I will make but two other comments. Firstly, I understand that the remarks of my right honourable colleague were directed to a number of matters in the corporate area and were in the context, in part, of the Industries Assistance Commission examination which is being undertaken in this area. Secondly, many factors account for the fall in corporate tax receipts as a proportion of total tax receipts. My understanding is that the figures cited by the honourable member are substantially correct. I would not seek to dispute them, but they can be attributed to a number of factors and not, as the honourable member's question implies, simply to the appropriateness of the current levels of corporate taxation.

—Is the Treasurer aware that interest rates have reached record levels under his Government's policies? Does he know that in the last two years bank mortgage interest rates have jumped by an unprecedented 4 percentage points? Will the Treasurer now assure this House that there will be no further increases in housing loan rates this year?

—As the honourable member is well aware, I have never been in the habit of giving assurances about future levels of interest rates, and I do not propose to depart from that practice now. The only alternative to the monetary policy which the Government is following at present would be a policy that in the short term might purchase some relief from the current level of interest rates but in the medium to longer term would give us much higher inflation and unavoidably much higher interest rates. The Government, in the housing package I announced last Thursday, addressed itself to those areas in which people are experiencing a burden as a result of increases in interest rates and also increases in the price of land which, in part if not in whole, are due to the effect of inflation in the community. The only real alternatives to the policies being followed by the present Government are policies which, even if they bought some short term relief, would produce in the medium and longer terms much higher inflation and much higher interest rates.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. In view of the adverse world reaction to English cricketers accepting invitations to play cricket in South Africa, what is the Australian Government's policy on this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has consistently opposed apartheid and has given continued support to the Gleneagles Agreement on sporting contacts with South Africa. It is for this reason that the Government has viewed with concern the current participation by 15 first class English cricketers in international matches in South Africa. We are particularly concerned that the success of the Commonwealth Games could be threatened by the actions of first class cricketers from England or, for that matter, from Australia. I understand that the English Test and County Cricket Board has announced that the English cricketers currently in South Africa and any who might join them will be disqualified from selection for the English test side for a period of three years. The TCCB has also stated that any English cricketer who plays in South Africa in international teams will also be ineligible to play for England.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe that the Australian Cricket Board, in the event of an invitation as described by the honourable member being made, would need to take very careful account of all these factors because the attitude of the ACB in respect of Australian cricketers will be crucial in maintaining the unity of test match playing countries. There is a very real danger that the events described by the honourable member could wreck test cricket and the very popular international one-day series as we know them. That, in the view of many people including many cricketers, would be a tragedy. If the sorts of offers mentioned by the honourable member are made, I urge all those involved to give most careful consideration to their decision. What they do could affect not only their own careers but also the future of many young Australian athletes and the future of young cricketers all over the cricket-playing world.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FEDERATED SHIP PAINTERS AND DOCKERS UNION OF AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Prime Minister. I ask firstly: Why is the Prime Minister, having had the report since 18 December 1981 of the royal commissioner inquiring into the activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union of Australia, still refusing to give effect to the urgent recommendations contained in the third interim report that the Income Tax Assessment Act and the royal commissioner's terms of reference should be amended to enable the royal commissioner to investigate and expose the ramifications of the tax avoidance industry which he identifies as the fastest growing industry in Australia? Secondly, how does the Prime Minister reconcile this continued refusal to act on the recommendations of the royal commissioner with his unfounded criticism in this House on 18 February this year of the Victorian Leader of the Opposition? Thirdly, why does the Prime Minister give priority to amending the social security legislation because less than a million dollars may have been diverted to wives and children of men on strike, while refusing the royal commissioner's request for legislative amendments aimed at smashing the tax avoidance industry which is costing billions of dollars a year? Finally, as this question directly involves the integrity of the Prime Minister, will he answer it himself?

—The Attorney-General and the Treasurer are deciding what matters should be put to us in relation to the extension of the terms of reference and access to taxation records. The honourable member is slightly off beat when he says that this access is critical to the fight against tax avoidance, because the nature of the scheme which was outlined in the report was outlawed by this Government 18 months ago. It was a scheme that involved massive evasion and, as I say, it was outlawed by this Government 18 months ago. This Government has acted against tax avoidance more vigorously than any other government and it will continue to do so. Once the recommendation of the Attorney and the Treasurer is ready to be taken by the Government, it will be taken.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH SCIENTIFIC AND INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH ORGANISATION: WATER RESEARCH

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Science and Technology: In view of the serious problems facing Australia's fresh water resources, will he outline to this House research being undertaken by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation on this matter? Are new structural arrangements to be made that would allow more effective research in this important area?

—Mr Speaker, I draw your attention to a question of mine on the Notice Paper, No. 4200-and 4122 if you want both-which hinges on this question of the report of the Australian Water Resources Advisory Council.
—The question asked is a much wider one than that which is on the Notice Paper. I call the Minister.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the question. I am aware of the interest of the honourable member who put the question on the Notice Paper. I think it is worth while emphasising some things that are being done at the moment. Water research has been given top priority by CSIRO. Yesterday I announced that CSIRO is conducting a review of the environmental problems of the Murray-Darling Basin, which will interest many honourable members. This review is aimed at identifying those areas and issues most in need of scientific investigation and determining how CSIRO's research programs can best provide useful answers.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition, CSIRO has just completed a review of its water resources activities. I intend to circulate copies of the review to interested Federal members before Parliament rises this week. Also, the Government hopes to make an announcement shortly on new structural arrangements within CSIRO to enable effective research in this important area.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister a question. It relates to the rather curious assertion made by him in his electorate talk on Sunday week last. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: We have had economic growth at twice the average of other major industrialised countries in recent years.

Is the Prime Minister aware that, in fact, the most recent figures show that the growth of income per head in other industrial countries has been more than twice that of Australia and that the latest Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development bulletin of economic indicators, which I have, shows that the growth of real product per head grew by 2.7 per cent in western industrialised countries between 1975 and 1980 but only 1.3 per cent in Australia? Given this pitiful result of five years of monetarist experimentation and recent information of renewed growth of Australian unemployment, will the Prime Minister, in the interests of all Australians, change his policies and adopt a more constructive economic strategy?

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman's figures cover a five-year time span . In the last two or three years of that period he will know quite well that Australia has performed very much better than other major OECD countries. The Leader of the Opposition only highlights the fact that Australia took some time to recover from the period from 1972 to 1975 before it could once again get on the growth path under the policies of this Government.
—I ask the Prime Minister whether he has any estimates of the cost to the nation of lost wages and lost production if power zoning applies in New South Wales, involving a one day a week shutdown.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the basis of a one day a week shutdown I have had some calculations done. We must all be concerned that there is a belief now that a shutdown for one day a week will not be adequate unless power supply in New South Wales can improve markedly. This matter has gone far beyond party political contention because it is a major blow to the Australian nation. What is happening in New South Wales is, in a very real measure, a national calamity. It will harm hundreds of thousands of Australian families who will lose wages and purchasing power over the coming months.

ANSWER.PARA: On the calculations that have been done by my Department, if 500,000 employees each earning average weekly earnings lost one day's work a week, the loss of wages would be $32m a week or $416m a quarter. The loss of after-tax household disposable income would be $22m a week or $286m a quarter. The loss of final output would be $60m a week or $780m a quarter. At this point it is worth noting that if the power zoning were to extend to two days a week the loss would therefore be $1.5 billion a quarter. That is the prospect, at worst, ahead of New South Wales in the coming period. Obviously, the loss of taxation receipts and the flow-through effects throughout the whole economy on sales, profits, prices and employment in many other industries would be massive indeed. This has not just come about through the consequences of maladministration in New South Wales; it is now a matter of major national concern and a major tragedy for this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. In the light of the judgments of Gibbs C. J. and Mason J. in the case of the Commissioner of Taxation v. Whitford's Beach Pty Ltd, is it a fact that the requirement of identity of property that has dogged the application of section 26A of the Income Tax Assessment Act to many transactions does not apply to the second limb of this section dealing with the profit from profit making undertakings and schemes? Therefore, will he instruct the Commissioner of Taxation to take proceedings under section 26A against the Bell group of companies for recovery of the tax payable on the share and property transactions involved in the Elder Smith Goldsborough Mort takeover? Finally, will he further instruct the Commissioner to investigate the many similar profit making schemes and undertakings involving the purchase of property and its resale in the manner used by the Bell group which have produced such huge tax free profits in recent years?

—My attention has been drawn to that particular case. I would like to say two things about it. Firstly, generally speaking, the judgment of the High Court of Australia does indicate something of a different-may I say welcome- attitude in regard to tax avoidance matters. I think that honourable members on both sides of the House who are interested in practical measures to strengthen the arm of the community against tax avoidance practices will welcome that particular development. So far as this particular case is concerned, let me say to the honourable gentleman that I have no capacity to instruct the Commissioner of Taxation nor, indeed, does any Minister have any capacity to instruct the Commissioner to take particular action against individual taxpayers. Frankly, I hope the day never comes in this country when the actions of the Commissioner of Taxation in regard to individual taxpayers will be at the whim of ministerial discretion. Because of the provisions of section 16, the Commissioner cannot tell me whether section 26A in its newly interpreted form applies to the particular case. I can assure the honourable member that the Commissioner of Taxation would, in my very firm belief, be applying that particular section in those areas where he believes it should apply.

—Is the Minister for Housing and Construction aware that although there has been considerable publicity since last Thursday afternoon, there is still some doubt in people's minds as to the eligibility for benefits under the Government's new housing policies? Will the Minister consider some form of public awareness campaign to ensure that people who are eligible for benefits are made aware of that eligibility?

—Notwithstanding wide Press dispersement of the good news of the Government announced by the Treasurer last Thursday, the information provided was of a rather general nature. Many people, of course, are interested in their own positions. I state, for the information of the Parliament, that officers of the Department of Housing and Construction over the weekend and officers from my office today have been inundated with queries from people who want to know about their own positions. We have had to roster people to help to overcome the problem associated with the inundation of calls. It appears to me, therefore, that because of the excellence of the Government's housing package it is most desirable that as many people as possible learn as quickly as possible their entitlements and rights under the scheme. Accordingly, I have arranged for a sum of $300,000 to be spent on advertisements--
—Order! Honourable members on my left will remain silent.

—Quite obviously, honourable members opposite are not interested in letting the Australian people know their rights. These advertisements will take the form of television advertisements and Press announcements. The television advertisements will appear in Sydney and in Melbourne tomorrow night and in provincial areas and other capital cities of Australia within the next few days . The Press advertisements are planned to commence on Thursday.
—This is a bloody disgrace.
—Order! The honourable member for Robertson spoke in terms which I will not repeat. I wish him to know that if he does that again I will immediately name him.

—As Minister for Housing and Construction I quite often get many letters-I do not get any from you, Mr Speaker, because you are aware of the Homes Savings Grant Scheme-from members of the Opposition who are unaware of the scheme. I get letters from people who have been given wrong information inasmuch as some things are not applicable in the present scheme. It appears to me that when there are people such as the Premier of New South Wales running around creating havoc and creating concern in people's minds by saying that interest rates will rise to 18 per cent, I have a responsibility to assuage people's fears. I conclude on this note--
—Quite obviously the Opposition does not care. It is not interested in home ownership.
—The Minister will proceed with his answer.

—Just to show that there is no bias, that this is a government for the whole of Australia, the sum of $300,000 will be split up on the following basis: 36.1 per cent will go to New South Wales-quite rightly as this is the largest area of population-and 34.6 per cent will go to Victoria. That is quite right also-it is the second highest population area. Then 9.7 per cent will go to Queensland; 7.6 per cent to South Australia; 6.4 per cent to Western Australia; 1.2 per cent each to Tasmania and the Australian Capital Territory, and 0.4 per cent to the Northern Territory.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: GOVERNMENT DEPARTMENTS AND STATUTORY AUTHORITIES: OVERTIME

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Recently, the Department of Finance issued a directive to Government departments and statutory authorities to cut out overtime. Will the Prime Minister tell this House whether any department or statutory authority is exempt from this provision? Will the Prime Minister acknowledge that this is a financial decision with no consideration of efficient management or morale of the Public Service? Will he explain how service departments can operate without overtime? Does he anticipate that any work that cannot be carried out in the regular hours will be carried out by public servants above the class 8 level who are not entitled to paid overtime?

—I would be very surprised if any blanket instruction has gone from the Department of Finance in relation to all overtime-saying that overtime cannot be worked and cannot be paid. In our Cabinet and Government discussions on these matters we have obviously had a very particular concern for the departments and offices that are supplying services to people-the Department of Social Security and the Commonwealth Employment Service to name but two. Whilst there has certainly been an injunction to cut out unnecessary overtime, I do not believe that any instruction has been given to cut out all overtime, to bar it absolutely. Since the honourable member has asked a question in relation to that matter I will see whether there is anything that I need to add to this answer.

—I refer the Minister for Industry and Commerce to recent comments that he made advocating a reduction in company taxation. Firstly, were these remarks spoken on behalf of the Government? Secondly, if they were, do his remarks reflect a preference by the Government for reductions in company taxation as against reductions in personal income taxation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lynch The Rt Hon Sir P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable gentleman for the question. When he reads the full text of the address which I gave to the Bureau of Industry Economics he will see in particular the point that was made therein and the general theme of that address. What I said there and what I am very happy indeed to repeat in this House in simple economic propositions is this: Non- inflationary growth is the key to improved living standards in this country, to job creation and to the Government's capacity effectively to care for those who are in real need. Of course, economic growth is dependent upon continuing and high levels of investment in business and in Australian industry. Investment itself is determined by industry's competitive edge and overall corporate profitability, which comprehends issues such as the investment allowance, depreciation allowances and those other matters which are before the Government at the present time. These are issues of which honourable members on both sides of the House should be very much aware because they are on public record. They are issues which the Government will face in making decisions on the Industries Assistance Commission's report on budgetary assistance.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me be perfectly clear. No business constituency is unaware of what I am about to say. Given the need for this Government to maintain the tightest rein on Commonwealth expenditure patterns-that has always been made clear to the business constituency-this is certainly no time for any suggestion of business largesse. Equally, in announcing the date of the IAC report on budgetary assistance to industry, the Government made the point that it was not out to reduce industry support. The critical question here, a question not easy for the Government to answer in due course, is in fact one not of quantum but of priorities: How to develop the most cost effective programs for industry and how to respond to the particular needs of Australian industry at the present time. Also, in that speech I made the point which other senior Ministers have made recently, namely, that the impact of the international trading environment on industry is creating an extraordinarily difficult situation. The cost pressures which are mounting at the present time impose very serious problems on the capacity of industry to continue its present momentum of employment growth.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry and Commerce. I also refer to the speech he made to the Bureau of Industry Economics , in which he indicated that a reduction in corporate tax would bolster Australia's sagging economy. Is it not a fact that the present problem is a lack of demand for products rather than a lack of investment? Would not a cut in corporate tax simply increase the after tax profits of the companies which, because of the depressed state of the economy, have no inclination at all to invest?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lynch The Rt Hon Sir P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is based on a total misinterpretation, in fact a complete misreading, of what was said in the speech to the Bureau of Industry Economics. I think the honourable gentleman, whom I would regard as fair and objective in making assessments beyond the scoring of party political points, would be very much aware that I said, in the context of the IAC report, that these were matters which the Government would need to address. I think it is important to make this clear: The official figures for manufacturing investment remain very strong. In 1980-81 they were some 46 per cent greater than in 1979- 80, with a further growth of 26 per cent indicated during the current financial year. Most official indicators available to me from Commonwealth sources indicate that the situation remains strong, although one early indicator, manufacturers' sales, suggests that a slight downturn did take effect in the December quarter. But this Government does not rely simply on official figures. I have indicated that, on the basis of early information available to the Government from industry sources, there is a softening, certainly in the industrial scene. The international economy is depressed and manufacturers' exports fell 5 per cent in the seven months to January 1982. At the same time manufactured imports increased by over 22 per cent in the same period. There is no doubt whatever that the currently strong position represented by official figures in the investment area is the result of decisions taken some years ago. I state without qualification that I expect that there will be some descaling of those decisions and some deferments in the decision-making pipeline.

ANSWER.PARA: If honourable gentlemen opposite have any care or concern for economic activity , investment and jobs in the Australian community they will focus their attention on the competitive edge of manufacturing industry. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, who is seeking to interject, knows full well that our competitive edge and this country's capacity to survive in a very difficult trading world at present are critically determined by the pressures for wage push, by a reduction in working hours and by the use of industrial muscle. These are the matters that ought properly to be the focus of concern of the honourable gentleman.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. It relates to his participation in the recent labour Ministers conference of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development held in Paris. Firstly, I ask whether he had an enjoyable and fruitful conference. Secondly, how does Australia's employment performance compare with that of other OECD countries? Finally, did the Minister learn of any new policies or measures at the conference that could apply to Australia in order to create more jobs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that the OECD employment Ministers met recently to discuss the situation with respect to employment and unemployment. The communique which was issued by Ministers at the conclusion of that meeting drew attention, amongst other things, to the fact that the only-I repeat the word ' only'-way in which the problems of unemployment can be tackled is by an attack on inflation. It was widely recognised by participants in the conference that this was the only way in which one could reasonably expect to solve the world's unemployment problems. Consequently those governments which--
—The only way?

—Yes, the only way. I will let the honourable member look at the communique if he wishes. It is unfortunate that the Australian Labor Party now seems to have alienated itself from almost the entire Western world so far as its policies on defeating unemployment are concerned. That is not the policy of the Labor Party, as I understand it. Rather, the Labor Party seeks to solve problems by funny schemes which will not employ anyone permanently. Let me return to deal with the conference.
—I raise a point of order. The Minister is completely misrepresenting the contents of that communique.
—There is no point of order.

—I simply say to the House that the Ministers said in their communique-by a remarkable coincidence I have it with me-that these efforts to combat unemployment 'could only be pursued with success in the framework of a concomitant and effective combat against inflation, as well as in the context of active international co-operation and open trading relationships bearing in mind the conclusions of the OECD Council at ministerial level'. Therefore, it is apparent that the conference has endorsed the policies of this Government which, of course, take exactly that approach, namely, that it is important to resolve the underlying causes of unemployment before one can expect to see an achievement in this regard.

ANSWER.PARA: In further answer to the honourable member might I say that Australia's performance in employment and unemployment compares very favourably with other OECD countries. It should, however, be brought home very firmly to this country that there are loose in Australia some forces which should give cause for concern so far as unemployment is concerned. There is no doubt that the increasing cost of labour in Australia poses a very serious problem for the future of employment growth in this country. It is simply becoming far too expensive for employers to employ more people. The claims for shorter working hours without matching increases in productivity have, likewise, priced many employees out of the labour market, as this country has been priced out of markets overseas by the same forces. Furthermore, the continuous industrial disputation has, likewise, been an inhibiting factor on employment growth in this country. One might well ask: How can one ask an employer in New South Wales today to take on additional employees when there is not even power for him to conduct his enterprise or factory? It should be appreciated that those factors are very basic, that they pose a continuous threat to employment growth in this country and that unless they are faced squarely and tackled by the community as a whole we will not see the increase in employment that I hope we would all want to see.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Housing and Construction. It follows his breathtaking announcement that the Government proposes to spend $ 300,000 on saving the Victorian Government. I think I am correct in saying that the Minister said that 36 per cent of the funds would be spent in Sydney and 34 per cent of the funds would be spent in Melbourne. As the population spread, as I understand it, is 35 per cent for New South Wales and 26 per cent for Victoria, will he explain how he came to the differential calculation whereby almost 30 per cent more will be spent in Victoria than in New South Wales? Will he explain why, if that is the position, less money will be spent in the other States of Queensland, South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania and in the Northern Territory? Does this mean that it is less important for these States and the Northern Territory to know about the great benefits brought about by the scheme announced last week?
—When are you going to pay the outstanding bills of your Department?
—I think that is unkind.
—You are not paying your bills, but you have got plenty of money--
—Order! The honourable member for Corio will cease interjecting.
—The distribution of this $300,000 was based on an historical analysis of where we were getting the queries from.
—Order! The Minister will resume his seat. When the House comes to order, I will call the Minister.

—In respect of the distribution of funds for television station material, in my own area one can get 60 seconds on television a lot cheaper than one can get the same time on a station in Sydney or Melbourne. We have taken into account the distribution of the migrant population--
—Will you make this formula available?
—Will you keep quiet, you empty head.
—Order! The Minister will cease taking notice of interjections. That only produces more interjections.
—Mr Speaker, I just remind the House that he has more holes in his head than a Swiss cheese.
—The Minister will resume his answer or be seated.

—We took into account the high cost of television advertising in the metropolitan areas of Sydney and Melbourne and the greater proportion of newspapers there compared with places such as Western Australia, Tasmania, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory. We are distributing this money to let the Australian people know their entitlements because we are concerned about the continuation of the very high level of Australian home ownership. People do not know of all the goodies to which they are entitled from this Government. We want to let them know. The distribution is fair and honest. Unlike the Opposition, we do not resort to cheap political tricks. We are interested in people.

—With your indulgence, Mr Speaker, perhaps I may correct either an error that I made or an impression that I gave. Instead of saying that 500,000 employees in New South Wales-which is the number that I have been advised-would be stood down with one zone standing by, I may have said '500'.
—You did.

—The number should be 500,000. I am glad to be reminded of that. The figure of $780m output lost in a quarter is, of course, correct, if there is one zone stood down each week; and it would be double that if two zones were stood down. There would be $286m household income lost in a quarter as a result of one zone in New South Wales being stood down on one day a week. These losses are massive. They affect the nation and individual families very greatly.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH SCIENTIFIC AND INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH ORGANISATION

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report and Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to section 57 of the Science and Industry Research Act 1949, I present the annual report of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation for 1980-81. I seek leave to make a statement concerning the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the four years since the Government announced its decisions on the independent inquiry into the CSIRO many changes have taken place within the Organisation. It is an appropriate time to inform the house of some of CSIRO's activities and policies and to outline CSIRO priorities for the rest of the 1980s. Firstly, I will explain the relationship between CSIRO, a statutory authority, and the government and parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The general business of the CSIRO is conducted by the Executive which consists of both full time and part time members. Under the Science and Industry Research Act, the Executive may make recommendations to the responsible Minister on policy, work and funding. The Minister may give a direction to the Executive on any matter of policy in the carrying out of scientific research.
The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in his statement concerning the independent inquiry clearly stated:
CSIRO's autonomy in the setting of research project objectives will be maintained.

The Prime Minister also stated that CSIRO's activities must accord with the policies of the government. It should be emphasised that although CSIRO has considerable policy and operational independence it is ultimately responsible to parliament and the elected government through the Minister for Science and Technology. This is important because of the widely felt need to relate science and technology policies more closely with social, economic and industrial policies.

One of the most important mechanisms for doing this is the Parliament where the attitudes, fears and aspirations of the Australian community are reflected. Parliament must be consulted about the type of science and technology policies being developed. I urge honourable members to become more involved in science and technology issues, and to raise the level of community debate on government, industry and academic policies in this area.

The CSIRO has a direct link with the community and the users of its research, through the CSIRO Advisory Council and CSIRO State committees, each consisting of informed representatives with varied areas of expertise. The Opposition spokesman on science and technology, the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones), is a member of the CSIRO Advisory Council. I might say he is an active and very good member of the Council. This Government has encouraged CSIRO to develop its contacts with industry to ensure that its programs are relevant to industrial problems, and that the results are known by industry.

CSIRO does not operate in a vacuum divorced from the realities of society or the economy. Nor can CSIRO be regarded as a sacred cow simply bcause it is a scientific organisation. It is important that there is close contact between researchers and industry.
Research Priorities

The Government has reaffirmed that the main role of CSIRO is scientific and technological research in support of Australian industry, agriculture, community interests and other perceived national objectives and obligations. The type of research to be undertaken will be longer term research for the community benefit which industry and other research organisations are unable to carry out. CSIRO will also undertake fundamental and short term problem oriented research if it is related to the role of the organisation.

I have already announced some of the research priorities identified by the Executive for CSIRO in the 1980s. In addition to the traditional areas of high priority such as agriculture and minerals, there are now six areas nominated for expansion. They are: Water and soils, manufacturing industry, biotechnology, energy, oceanography, and plant pathology.

These areas are of particular relevance to Australia and its economic future. They have not been developed in isolation. Rather they have been identified through CSIRO's ongoing review programs, consultation with the community and industry and naturally interaction with the Government. I believe CSIRO's research effort is now finely tuned to the future needs of Australia. Although it is not difficult to re-assign research priorities quickly, the research effort of CSIRO cannot be redirected anywhere near as quickly. For example, there is no magic wand with which radio astronomers can be turned into biochemists.
CSIRO Finances

CSIRO is an organisation of more than 7,500 people, including 2,000 scientists in about 40 divisions located in more than 100 laboratories across the country. The Government is regularly asking CSIRO to take on new responsibilities on its behalf or approving new initiatives of special interest to the Government. Recent examples are the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory; an oceanographic research vessel and research for the Australian fishing zone; Project Aquarius which is concerned with aerial fire fighting; greatly increased computing responsibilities; and, more recently, responsibility for energy research previously conducted by the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, although the latter has not yet been absorbed into CSIRO's budget. So despite the general reductions by which the Government has contained public expenditure, which have affected CSIRO like any other department, CSIRO's budget has actually increased by 10 per cent from $260m to $286m, not including $29m for the new superannuation commitments and the $5m for the extra pay day last year.

I appreciate the calls that have been made for more money for research in CSIRO . But they have to be seen in the light of other important Government projects and commitments and the Government's policy of public sector restraint. In times of budgetary restraint it is simply not possible to fund all research projects considered to be both nationally important and scientifically rewarding.

At such times the criterion of relative scientific merit must be balanced carefully with community need and national interest. Without an ever expanding budget it is therefore obvious that lower priority programs can no longer be funded at a meaningful level. The CSIRO executive has emphasised that for most scientific projects there is a threshold level of funding below which the work should be discontinued. Therefore, rather than apply across the board cuts, the executive, after rigorous analysis of existing programs has decided to terminate or amalgamate some of the lower priority activities. To quote the Chairman of CSIRO, Dr Paul Wild, the organisation is grasping the nettle of change.

The efficient use of resources is a prime essential in today's difficult economic climate. With the given total of funds to work with, CSIRO must simply concentrate on the most important things. These are not always the same as in the past. Changes over the past year include a new institute of energy and earth resources, new divisions of energy chemistry, energy technology, cellulose research and tropical animal science, and an industrial microbiological unit. To make these additions possible divisions have been closed down. This included the divisions of mechanical engineering and chemical technology. I would add that the total direct Commonwealth funding of research and development in all areas increased from $620m in 1978-79 to $940m this financial year. CSIRO accounts for about 30 per cent of this. This 10 per cent increase in real terms over four years demonstrates the government's commitment to science and technology in a time of severe financial restraint.
Water Research

An example of the need to co-ordinate science and technology policy with the national interest is in water management. Because of the great water problems facing Australia, water and soil research is now a high priority area for CSIRO. A number of new proposals are being drawn up to focus and improve research into water resources. The CSIRO has just completed a review of the Organisation's water resources activities. The aim was to identify priority areas for future research, resources required to undertake research, and organisational and co- ordination arrangements. The review has concluded that research should be expanded in three main areas-salinity and other quality aspects, groundwater, and catchment hydrology. The Government hopes to make announcements shortly on new divisional and co-ordination arrangements to enable effective management of this important area.
Highlights

The year being reported on has had its crop of notable achievements by CSIRO. I might mention just a few that show special promise. CSIRO scientists discovered a naturally occurring protein which shows promise of yielding a practical biological method of defleecing sheep. They have developed a vaccine for increasing the lambing rate of ewes. A major advance has been made in the long battle against tick fever of cattle. The water weed salvinia which menaces Australian waterways has been completely eradicated by biological means at a test site at Mt Isa. Highly successful computer-controlled management techniques for growing cotton have been put into operation in the Namoi Valley. This venture, called siratac, in which the New South Wales Department of Agriculture is collaborating, has been welcomed and widely adopted by the industry.

For the first time a range of esters has been developed that act as highly effective insecticides but are non-toxic to other wildlife. The year has seen the world-wide launching of the sirospun innovation for the spinning industry, and the construction of the first full-scale sirofloc water purification plant, which now supplies 5 per cent of Perth's water supply from bore water. These are just a few of the many CSIRO achievements which have surfaced during the year.
Conclusion

I take the opportunity to thank the Chairman and the executive, the advisory bodies and the staff of CSIRO for their efforts over the past year. I applaud their pursuit of excellence. In CSIRO, Australia has a first rate research organisation of world renown, a leader in many areas of industrial and scientific research. I believe that now, more than ever before, CSIRO is strictly enforcing a policy of selectively and carefully chosen priorities. The national interest must always come first, but we should not become obsessed with looking at the short term to the exclusion of planned strategic science. Good science is a very subtle thing.
I end by quoting from Thomas Spratt, the first historian of the Royal Society. This was written in the year 1667:

It is stranger that we are not able to inculcate into the minds of many men the necessity of that distinction of my Lord Bacon's, that there ought to be experiments of light, as well as of fruit. It is their usual word, what solid good will come from thence? But they are to know that in so large and so various an art as this of experiments, there are many degrees of usefulness: Some may serve for real and plain benefit, without much delight: Some for teaching, without apparent profit: Some for light now and for use hereafter: Some only for ornament and curiosity. If they will persist in contemning all experiments, except those which bring with them immediate gain and a present harvest, they may as well cavil at the providence of God, that he has not made all the seasons of the year to be times of mowing, reaping and vintage.
I commend the CSIRO annual report to the House. I present the following paper:

Introduction

At the back of this volume the reader will find a chart that shows how CSIR and CSIRO evolved through the years. For the most part the evolution has been gradual and, until the 1970s, took place within an expanding organization. The year of this annual report, 1980/81, saw the start of a new phase in our evolution: a deliberate policy to stop certain activities and switch the resources to new activities.
The Executive's current policy may be summarized as follows:
1. Whatever we do me must do well. If resources are reduced then we must reduce the number of our activities, not the quality.
2. We must be selective in our fields of research and concentrate on nationally important and scientifically rewarding areas.

3. We must maintain our tradition of scientific excellence and remember that the maintenance of excellence depends on the performance of and the encouragement given to the individual. The needs for controlled objectives on the one hand and the scientist's freedom to follow his nose on the other must be carefully balanced.

How do we choose the problems we work on? Our first boundaries are set by our Act which makes scientific research on behalf of industry and the community our main role. At all levels of the Organization we maintain close links with representatives of industry and Government agencies, State and Federal, and our objectives are largely determined by interaction between our scientists and these representatives. In addition, we have the CSIRO Advisory Council and State Committees comprising eminent persons from all walks of life. We interact constructively with the Australian Science and Technology Council which advises the Prime Minister. We have our own Planning and Evaluation Advisory Unit which analyses the total scene and seeks out long-term trends. Finally, it is our own Executive, comprising four scientists and leading figures drawn from primary, secondary and tertiary industry that makes the final decisions on broad objectives.

Our current areas of research include many that have formed our traditional base and continue to be as important now as in past decades; the whole fields of agriculture and earth resources are examples. These continue at roughly constant levels. In addition, we have a short-list of research areas that we have singled out for potential expansion as resources become available. These (in no special order) are:
energy-with emphasis on the development of alternative liquid fuels and the conservation of existing stocks;
water and soils-the Australian continent's greatest need and most critical factor limiting its growth is water;
oceanography-vital to Australia, yet neglected in the past;
manufacturing technology-for an important branch of industry that urgently needs to become more innovative and self reliant;
biotechnology-an expanding field with boundless possibilities; and
plant pathology-with the aim of reducing diseases that are a scourge to agriculture.

In 1979/80 we set in motion major new initiatives on behalf of oceanography and manufacturing technology, as described in the annual report for that year. This year we have tackled energy and biotechnology. Next year we intend to focus particularly on the problems of water and soils.

The reorganization and intensification of energy research has resulted in the formation of an Institute of Energy and Earth Resources. An important part of the reorganization was made possible by the decision of the Government to redeploy approximately one-third of the staff of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission Research Establishment to CSIRO to work on non-nuclear energy research. Most of the scientific staff to be transferred will form a new Division of Energy Chemistry based at Lucas Heights (Sydney). At the same time, the Division of Mechanical Engineering is to be closed down and the majority of its staff redeployed into a new Division of Energy Technology based at Highett ( Melbourne).

Other structureal changes include the decision to close the Division of Chemical Technology and redeploy its staff to a new Division of Cellulose Research and a new Industrial Microbiology Unit. The latter will form part of our intensification of effort in biotechnology. The latest initiative in the agriculture sector is to form a new Queensland-based Division of Tropical Animal Science from resources taken mainly from existing Divisions. This new Division will provide a focus for livestock research in the tropics and sub-tropics and provide a more direct liaison with the existing Division of Tropical Crops and Pastures while maintaining close scientific links with animal Divisions in the south.

I hope, through these examples, to convey the vigour with which the Executive of our Organization, restructured following the Independent Inquiry in 1978, is responding to ever-changing national needs.

The efficiency with which we can adapt and respond to the needs of the time depend critically on consistent and dependable funding for the Organization. A 2 % cut in staff resources largely depletes each Division of its redeployable vacancies for a year and so prevents the recruitment of new specialist staff to tackle new problems as well as depriving the Organization of an injection of young scientists. As a result of a decision arising from the Review of Commonwealth Functions (RCF) in 1980/81, CSIRO will be subjected to a cut of 2. 16% in 1981/82.

Across-the-board cuts mean that each time the Government makes a staff ceiling cut in the Public Service, CSIRO receives a cut of a similar magnitude to that imposed on Government departments. We believe a distinction should be made between an organization such as ours, on which the future growth and prospects of the nation vitally depend, and the administrative arms of government. It is the Executive's belief that the national interest requires a larger government commitment to science and technology rather than a reduction.

Another RCF decision, taken without consultation, was to close our Scientific Liaison Offices in London and Washington, ending a long history of dedicated service to Australia. These Offices provided a valuable means of keeping Australia abreast of developments in science and technology policies in these countries and facilitated the operation of science agreements. They also undertook a variety of important tasks such as recruiting senior scientific staff.

Our principal function is to undertake strategic research on behalf of industry and the community. Research programs span many years, even decades, as one thing leads to another. To describe a single research result in isolation from the work and ideas that have led up to it can often be rather meaningless. Beginning with this annual report, we are therefore introducing accounts (Chapters 12-16) of some main themes of our research work, their past evolution, the present work and future prospects. Some years of annual reports will be needed before all such themes can be comprehensively covered.
Meanwhile, the year 1980/81 has had its crop of notable achievements that have come to fruition during the year. On the side of the biological sciences, these include:

the discovery of a naturally occurring protein (Epidermal Growth Factor) that, by modulating the thickness of the wool fibre, shows promise of yielding a practicable biological method of defleecing sheep;
a vaccine for increasing ovulation rate of ewes by some 40 per cent;

a killed vaccine to immunize cattle against Tick Fever; work is under way to isolate the specific protective protein that, with the aid of genetic engineering techniques, will enable the vaccine to become a commercial reality;

the development and marketing of highly specific substances (monoclonal antibodies) for the diagnosis of human and animal diseases (in collaboration with the Garvan Medical Research Centre and Bioclone (Australia) Pty Ltd);

the eradication of the water weed Salvinia (which causes serious blockages in Australian waterways) at a test site at Mt Isa by the introduction of a specific variety of weevil from South America; and

the implementation of a computer-controlled management technique (SIRATAC) for the application of insecticide and irrigation water on the cotton crops in the Namoi valley; the system, operated by a non-profit company, is being widely adopted by cotton farmers and may be extended to other crops in due course (in collaboration with the NSW Department of Agriculture).
On the side of the physical sciences, highlights of our research include:
the development of esters which act as highly effective insecticides but are non-toxic to other wildlife;

the world-wide commercial launching of SIROSPUN, a new system of spinning worsted weaving yarns involving a single-stage production in place of the conventional two stages (in collaboration with Repco Ltd and the International Wool Secretariat).

construction by Austep of the first full-scale SIROFLOC water purification plant, now supplying about 5 per cent of Perth's water supply from bore water and recently recognized by the 1981 'Plant of the Year' award of the Society of Chemical Industry of Victoria;
installation of the first commercial gas drainage system in Australia which prevented the probable closure of a highly efficient and valuable coal mine on the NSW south coast;
the development and commercial realization of a microfiche reader that brings reading within the scope of handicapped or disabled people; and
the development of a device that detects wear and faults in steel reinforced conveyor belts used by the mining industry.

These are but a few of a much longer list that could be given, but they serve to illustrate the diversity of our research activities. Most of our research is of the kind that leads to foreseeable application. A small part of it contributes to basic knowledge with no application in sight. One of the most significant fundamental discoveries of our time was the discovery at the University of Cambridge in 1968 of pulsars, which proved that stars can finish their lives by collapsing to small spheres (neutron stars) of fantastically high density-thus revealing a new state of matter. Up till recently, all known pulsars were located in our own galaxy (the Milky Way) but astronomers eagerly speculated that they might be discovered in other galaxies, which would open new paths of investigation. This discovery was made during 1980/81 with the CSIRO radio telescope at Parkes, thanks to one of our scientists in collaboration with two colleagues of the University of Tasmania. Using innovative data processing techniques, they succeeded in detecting a number of pulsars in our nearest galaxy, the Magellan Clouds. This is a notable achievement of importance to basic science.

CSIRO continues to enjoy the highest respect and confidence of the Government and the Australian people. Yet it is clear that the decade we have now entered is proving to be more difficult for CSIRO than former, more expansive, times. Nevertheless, the Organization will continue to adapt to changing circumstances; and through its policies of selectivity and concentration it will continue to strive to improve its response to as many of the strategic research needs of industry and the community as resources allow.
J. P. Wild Chairman

He does not use these words, but it really is the fear that CSIRO is entering a new era, the era of stagnation. Dr Wild said:

SPEECH.PARA: The year of this annual report, 1980/81, saw the start of a new phase in our evolution: a deliberate policy to stop certain activities and switch the resources to new activities.
He then went on to make this point:

We believe a distinction should be made between an organisation such as ours, on which the future growth and prospects of the nation vitally depend, and the administrative arms of government. It is the Executive's belief that the national interest requires a larger government commitment to science and technology rather than a reduction.

I ask honourable members to remember that if, as we find at the moment, our per capita government investment in science and technology is half that of France and if, as President Mitterrand has said, France will double its investment in his seven-year term, it means there would need to be a fourfold increase in our spending to keep our position relative to France. That is the situation that we face. Dr Wild points out, for example, that in this era when we need the greatest degree of international co-operation and exchange of ideas the decision was made by the Review of Commonwealth Functions to cut out Australia's scientific representation overseas. I ask honourable members to note that Dr Wild said the decision was 'taken without consultation'. It was forced on the Organisation. Dr Wild said:
. . . it is clear that the decade we have now entered is proving to be more difficult for CSIRO than, former, more expensive times.

There is no single factor on which the future of this nation depends more than the investment that we have in research and development. I think it is deplorable that the Government has cut it back so far.
