INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The disturbing and worsening shambles of Government monetary policy.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's monetary policy is disturbing and worsening in the shambles it inflicts on the community. The Australian Government is stricken with a bout of monetarist madness, soaring interest rates, the symptoms of a runaway monetary policy-policies that give every indication they will run the economy into the ground if they are not quickly brought back under control. Yet, the Government's monetary policies today, as they have been for all the days last year and for too many days of the last 6 1/2 years, are a shambles. The Government does not know what it is doing or where it is going. It is thrashing about like a blindfolded fool. Neither the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) nor the Treasurer (Mr Howard) seems to understand that he cannot hold together a set of widely contradictory policies with safety pins and stickytape. Both of them are trying to defy the fundamental logic of enforcing fiercely contractionary monetary control policies but are still wanting low interest rates in politically sensitive areas, such as housing . It does not work, it cannot work, it will not work, no matter how often the Prime Minister says that it must be made to work. It seems as though the Government is determined to start a new school of economics, the levitation school, that defies all the economic equivalents of the laws of physics. If the Government's economic commitment is to tight money, tight money means scarce money and there is a high price for scarce commodities. The high price for scarce money is high interest rates. It is as simple as that.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government cannot have it both ways. It is a breathtaking display of blind faith and economic illiteracy for the Government to rig the money market in the way that it has and for it then to expect that interest rates for essential social factors, such as housing, will somehow stay low and that economic growth will be promoted. The Government, by its own deliberate policies, has distorted the interest rate yield curve in favour of short term money market operations to the disadvantage of medium and longer term growth investment. No sensible person would park his money anywhere for more than a few days with the present condition of government monetary policies. The Government's economic policies simply do not last any longer than that.

Having made those criticisms, at this point one ought to start with an outline of what ought to be done and give justification for a radical departure from what the Government is doing. The first thing I assert is that there must be a devaluation of the Australian dollar-a clear, decisive, firm devaluation-as an effective demonstration to the money market and to the international economy. As conditions stand at the moment there has been a persistent slide in the value of the Australian dollar. A psychology has been developed in association with that slide. The expectation will drive the slide beyond what is a proper level for the Australian dollar in the international money market. A clear, decisive, once -only devaluation as a demonstration of the firmness of control of government economic policy will arrest that. It is highly likely, in fact, that it will allow some recovery of the Australian dollar.

Why is the dollar sliding and why are interest rates so high? Why are these two things interconnected? The facts are that with a persistent slide of the Australian dollar on international money markets the implication is quite clear: People will not bring their money to this country and those who have their money here will not keep it parked here unless there is a system of compensation, a system which will offset the losses that they suffer on exchange rate operations . The way in which the Government is doing that is to wriggle interest rates in this country. We now have the highest real interest rates of any industrialised country.

It was always argued by the Treasurer and by his faithful followers, no matter how few, in the government ranks that the reason for the high interest rates was the high interest rate structure in America. The American interest rate structure is sliding but the Australian interest rate structure stays, in real terms, the highest in the world. Why? The reason is that the government is rigging the money market. It is using interest rates as a compensation mechanism to provide compensation for those who have brought their money here from overseas, or those who are considering bringing it here. They will not bring it here and they will not keep it here while the Australian dollar continues to slide. The cost of that, of course, is met by the rest of Australia-by Australian householders trying to pay off their houses, by Australian business confronted with ever spiralling costs of working capital, by Australian farmers. It also means that monetary policy in this country is dramatically severe and is contracting economic growth. To support that claim one has only to refer to the report of the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Bank of New South Wales on the outlook of business for the year ahead. It is the gloomiest report in the best part of a decade. Business knows, as any moderately informed person understands, that with a continuation of present policies next year will be tougher than this year. This year is altogether too severe. The severity, as I pointed out before, is a direct product of domestic economic policies. It has little to do with international conditions. It is being inflicted on this community by a complete misunderstanding of the interrelationship of various aspects of monetary policy and fiscal policy, particularly our external account. Australians are paying, with excessive costs for their houses, with excessive costs for business working capital, with excessive costs for farm operating capital and with lost economic growth because of severe monetary policies, so that the Government can compensate overseas investors, people from overseas who have their money in Australia and who otherwise would not keep it here or bring it here.

That is not the way to run a sensible economic policy for a country at times of economic difficulty. A decisive once-only devaluation of 3 per cent perhaps, certainly not higher than 4 per cent or 5 per cent, would have an indisputable, demonstrable effect. It should be associated with an easing of the money supply. In that way spiralling interest rates can be arrested. In that way, with a series of other fiscal and monetary initiatives and a prices and incomes policy without which there can be no successful, no credible, no practical economic package, we can put Australia into a much healthier economic condition than it is now.

It is argued in some quarters that it is preferable to borrow overseas to patch up the gaps, the very big gaps, which are in our balance of payments-the balance of trade and the balance on current account which continue to blow out in deficit. That is a fine proposition. It is one that I have argued in earlier years. I stress that it was in the past because it is only a fine proposition when there can be confidence that the performance of the domestic economy within the performance overall of the international economy is such as to guarantee a sense of confidence that the balance of trade and balance on current account deficit can be wound back. I do not believe, given international conditions as they are now and as they portend for the near future, that we can be that confident.

It would therefore be, in my view, an act of great folly to encourage further larger overseas borrowings. There are in the pipeline borrowings overseas of an additional $500m overseas by the Government at this level. I am not talking about the State level. That will lift total overseas borrowings under this Government to some $5,500m or nearly 4 per cent of gross domestic product. In 1975 overseas borrowings were less than $1,000m and only a little over one per cent of gross domestic product. One cannot keep putting the country into hock when one has serious economic difficulties. One needs sound economic policies.

What is happening in the market? There is a complete flight of confidence in the Government's ability to handle monetary policy. I quote the Australian Money Market Weekly of 15 March, no more than a little over a week ago. It states:
AMMW's advice to money market participants and institutions is to avoid the bond market completely as Australia is now being run by a lame-duck government.
It goes on to state:
Faced with the abysmal market conditions, there is no prospect of recovery in the bond market, and also no guide from the monetary authorities as to where the market is heading.

One can pick up a half dozen or more of the more authoritative, persuasively substantial and informed money market newsletters which are saying exactly the same thing. If these sorts of sources are telling investors: 'Don't put your money into bonds. Hang on to it. Overnight and in the very short term at the most', it means that money is not going to go into the development of this country. It means that money is going to go into the overnight operations. It means that interest rates will be pushed up higher and higher on the short end until the Government moves on the medium to longer end. That is what is wrong today. That is the consequence of applying the policies that the Government is applying but doing it with a frail heart.

The Government should either apply the policies fully or change the whole thrust of its economic policy, which is what I have been proposing. Again, if one makes interest rates on the very short end of the market higher than they are on the medium to longer end of the market, as they are-that is, if treasury notes are running at between 18 per cent and 19 per cent and bonds are running at about 15 per cent to 16 per cent; bonds represent the money that is collected for the development of capital works in this country and treasury notes are just a holding operation-people, at least the moderately informed ones, are going to put all of their dough into the short end of the market, and that will keep pressure on interest rates to go up and up. Why are they doing it? They are doing it because they do not believe that the present structure of interest rates, given the nature of the Government's economic policy, can be sustained. They are demonstrating by voting with their cash that the Government's interest rate policy on medium to long term operations in this country, private as well as public, is not believable. That is a savage repudiation.

It means that important things such as roads, communications, harbours, railways, educational institutions and hospitals-a whole range of capital works- are not proceeding as they should be because the Government's interest rate structure has been rigged-I use the term advisedly; it was completely stupid to do it; one would have to be thoroughly illiterate in economics to do it-in such a way as to discourage people from putting their money sensibly into the development of this country. The Government has achieved the unparalleled result of destroying all confidence in the future of this country under its management.

Does the Government know what it is doing? On Friday morning the nation woke to read in the newspapers of the Government's brave new breakthrough in housing policy, which is directly related to this matter. There was an increase of $300m in housing interest repayments for home buyers-a great deal! There would be no relief for three out of four home buyers. But the battling banks would pick up an increased $100m in profits. That is how things stood on Friday morning-a one per cent increase. The weekend allowed the Government to sober up. On Monday morning the community read in the newspapers that Mr Keith Campbell, an inspirational force to the Treasurer, was declaring that interest rates on housing would go up another 1 1/2 per cent. So the Treasurer has in the pipeline , post-Victoria, another $450m in repayments for Australian home buyers.

The fact is that semi-government raisings are a flop. There was the $50m raising for Telecom which got only $17m less than a fortnight ago. Bonds are sagging with the official market rate at 15 1/2 per cent but the secondary market is collecting 17 per cent to 18 per cent. That means that, because of the spiralling interest rates, people are now selling bonds which they bought earlier at a lower interest rate for, in layman's terms, a lesser capital value. In that way they give a greater rate of return to those who buy them. That, in turn, is the mechanism by which the market signals to government that its raid on bonds is unbelievable. How can one believe a government when the official money market has a rigged rate on bonds of 15 1/2 per cent and the secondary market is pushing the rate up to between 17 per cent and 18 per cent? Who would put money into the private sector, into shares, when the rate of return for the past 16 months has been only about 5 per cent?

Let me conclude by commenting on the corporate sector. A very grim situation has arisen in this sector. Under the articles of association public corporations , large and small, are restricted to the amount that they can borrow as a ratio of their asset backing. They borrowed 12 months ago and more when interest rates were high and share values were high. Share values have collapsed by more than 35 per cent. They do not now have the asset backing to sustain the level of indebtedness-borrowings-that they had at very high interest rates. There are large corporations in Australia today flogging off assets in a desperate bid to get liquid, to get viable again. All of this is a product of the Government's incompetence, its foolishness, in handling the monetary policy. I call upon the Government to rethink where it is because if it does not rethink it, if it does not haul back from the savagery of the credit squeeze that we are now confronted with, we will see corporate failures on a very disturbing scale.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I am rather disappointed in the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden), because I came here today and I picked up the Daily Program blue sheet, and there it was:

SPEECH.PARA: DISCUSSION OF MATTER OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE-Mr Hayden (Leader of the Opposition)-
No less, today-
The disturbing and worsening shambles of Government monetary policy.

I thought that by coming here I would hear the Opposition's alternative monetary policy. As I listened to the Leader of the Opposition, I found that after two minutes he said: 'I am proposing a radical departure'. But during his quarter hour speech, he said not one thing, and he gave the House not one idea, about those areas in which, in the conduct of monetary policy, the Labor Opposition, if it were in government, would do anything different. The only thing that the Leader of the Opposition said that was different from the policy that is being followed now by the Government was that he trotted out his hardy manual of a once only devaluation.

The Leader of the Opposition is still living back in those old days of fixed exchange rates when it was imagined that one could have such a thing as a once and for all variation in the exchange rate. He has not learnt the lessons of those days. He ignores the fact that there is nothing more destabilising and disruptive to business and consumer confidence than very major movements in the exchange rate either way. But apart from that remark-and we are all familiar with the views of the Leader of the Opposition on that subject-there was not one word, not one scintilla of any suggestion from him, as to what the alternative monetary policy ought to be. One the one hand, he said that our policy was not tight enough; on the other hand, he said that it was too tight. In the dying moments of his speech, he talked about a credit squeeze; in the early part of his speech, he said that interest rates were too low. The Leader of the Opposition cannot have it all ways.

The Leader of the Opposition is proposing, in his own words, a radical departure. What is that radical departure? Where does the Leader of the Opposition differ from the Government? What changes would he have us institute in the conduct of our monetary policy in an environment in which the conduct of economic policy is far more difficult than it has been for a number of years? No one pretends that the interest rates being paid by the Australian community at present are anything other than extremely uncomfortable. The Government is very conscious of the effect of interest rates on many areas of the Australian community. But the question that we must ask ourselves-and the question that the Leader of the Opposition left totally unanswered in a speech which was full of rhetorical slogans but little else-is: What is the alternative monetary policy of the Australian Labor Party at present?

Is the Labor Party's monetary policy one of artificially holding down interest rates? The Leader of the Opposition did not tell us that. Does he believe that, by artificially holding down interest rates, we can sustain our international economic position? Does he not realise that, if one artificially holds interest rates, one will provoke a balance of payments crisis the like of which this country has never seen? Does he advocate that? He has done so on other occasions . Some of his colleagues have advocated that. But he was strangely silent on that alternative monetary policy today. We shall give him the benefit of the doubt. Maybe he is not in favour of doing that.

Is the Leader of the Opposition, therefore, secondly, in favour of the good old Labor Party remedy in the face of difficult decisions in the area of monetary policy of simply printing money? Does he believe that one can increase the deficit, not allow one's monetary policy to be adjusted accordingly, and simply print more money? Once again, there was deafening silence on that matter. That is not surprising, because the Leader of the Opposition knows from his earlier experience, and he knows from his understanding-I hope-of the present situation, that such an approach, such a scenario, would be to produce in present circumstances a much higher rate of inflation. Does he believe that we should not, therefore, as a third alternative, use monetary policy at all, so far as inducing a more rational environment for the conduct of wage negotiations? Does he really believe that the answer to the present situation is to allow the wages explosion to go--
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Batman and the honourable member for Hotham will remain silent.
—Let us have a bit of truth.
—The honourable member for Batman will remain silent.
—Tell him to tell the truth.
—The honourable member for Batman will not dispute with the Chair, otherwise the Chair will be required to deal with him.

—As a third alternative, perhaps, is the Leader of the Opposition's monetary policy one of simply saying that in the face of a wages explosion, which is undermining the international competitiveness of the Australian economy and visiting a great deal of disadvantage and suffering on the entire Australian community, his answer would be simply to say: 'Forget about monetary policy. Let the wages explosion rip. Let our international competitiveness be destroyed, and cure it all by a once only devaluation'? That action would transfer the costs to every Australian consumer and individual. Maybe that is his alternative monetary policy. But, once again, apart from that ritual repetition of his plea for a once only devaluation, the Leader of the Opposition was strangely and utterly silent about his alternative economic and alternative monetary policy.

SPEECH.PARA: At the commencement of his speech, the Leader of the Opposition promised us a radical departure, and we waited in vain for a description of what that radical departure would be. All that we heard was a collection of rhetoric, a collection of insults at the Government's policy, and a collection of meaningless meanderings from him as to those areas in which he thought the Government's monetary policy was deficient.

Nobody disputes for a moment that the world economic environment in which we are living is other than extremely difficult. Nobody, and least of all myself, will assert that domestic economic policies are irrelevant to our present condition.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have blamed the unions. Now you want to blame the world.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Batman and the honourable member for Hotham.

—Of course the domestic economic policies followed by this or any other government at present are relevant to the extent to which international economic adversity flows through into Australia. Of course, we are not impotent to have an influence on the effects of international economic conditions on the Australian economy. This government and I have never asserted otherwise. What we can do by our own domestic economic policies is either to aggravate or to reduce the harmful effects of the world economic situation. What I put to the House is that to adopt a substantially different monetary policy at present would be to aggrevate the adverse international economic conditions that the world is experiencing. Does anyone really imagine that the effects upon Australia of high interest rates in the United States, which are in turn caused by an unsatisfactorily high deficit in the United States, will be improved by the Australian Government running a higher deficit? Does anyone imagine that we shall be able to reduce the effects of American interest rates on Australia by turning a blind eye and, like King Canute, pretending that we can artificially hold down interest rates, as apparently on other occasions the Leader of the Opposition has imagined that we could?

SPEECH.PARA: During his speech, the Leader of the Opposition tried to pretend to the House that American interest rates were coming down and that therefore all the problems in Australia would be solved. Everybody with any degree-if I may borrow the Leader of the Opposition's phrase-of economic literacy will know that the American interest rates have an influence on the level of interest rates in Australia over a period, and that Australian interest rates do not simply go up and down like a yoyo every time American interest rates go up and down. The average Australian prime rate over the last two years has been 14.82 per cent. The current prime rate in Australia is 16.25 per cent, and the current prime rate in the United States averages 16 per cent to 16.25 per cent.

In the face of those figures, can you really believe the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Deputy Speaker, when he says that American interest rates are coming down and therefore Australian interest rates ought to be coming down? He does not even understand the current figures, yet he comes in here and says that this is part of his radical departure in the brave new monetary policy world.

At present the Government is facing one of the more difficult tasks of economic management that it has had over the last six years. Since the time when the Budget was brought down there have been a number of adverse economic developments, and it does not profit anyone to ignore them and to ignore their consequences. We have seen, particularly but not exclusively in the wages area, a serious undermining of the international competitiveness of our economy. We have seen a significant worsening of our balance of payments. We have seen in particular a deterioration of the trade account which is due in no small measure to the fact that world economic activity is very subdued. In turn, that has had a very adverse effect on commodity prices. Once again, anybody with an elementary understanding of the situation would know that our balance of payments are bound to be affected if international commodity prices are down. Therefore, demand for the goods that we export abroad will be down. They are facts of economic life and economic policy has to be adjusted accordingly.

The last prescription that I would hope that this House or the Australian nation would want us to adopt would be a prescription of loosening policy, of adopting an attitude that looser fiscal or monetary policy will solve the problem. No policy imposed at present will remove some of the uncomfortable features of our present economic life. There is simply no alternative at present to a degree of discomfort and a degree of economic adversity. What we have to ask ourselves is whether an alternative economic strategy-in particular the alternative monetary strategy of the Leader of the Opposition, which he would not tell us today but which I have tried from earlier speeches and statements of his to piece together-will create an improvement; whether it would be better, according to his economic prescription; whether his monetary policy of a slacker approach to monetary control, of a larger government deficit, of a looser fiscal stance of inevitably much higher government expenditure and, inevitably, therefore, either a looser monetary policy or much higher taxation, would better suit the economic environment in which Australia now finds itself in the first half of 1982.

I put it to the House that that is the crucial question that has to be asked. It is not to be denied for a moment that the present level of interest rates is anything other than very uncomfortable. We would wish them to be lower. We would wish that there were realistic alternatives to the present monetary and economic environment; but there is no alternative to the monetary policy that the present Government is following that does not involve, other than in the very short term , much higher inflation and, in turn, much higher interest rates. Of course, if we wanted to we could rapidly expand the money supply. The honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) is a little more candid on this subject than the Leader of the Opposition. He at least in these debates is prepared to stand up and say that what the Government ought to be doing is expanding the money supply. That is what he says and at least he is frank about it. The Leader of the Opposition squibbed it today. He talked about his radically different monetary strategy but when it came to laying it out and putting it on the table, he ran scared on the subject. At least the honourable member for Gellibrand is honest in saying that if he had the responsibility, he would simply print more money.

Of course if we printed more money at present we would be able to buy a reduction in interest rates for a while. We would be able to kid everybody that we could print more money and underwrite more inflation, and that nothing would happen. Perhaps for a few months everybody would say 'Ah ha, we have found the solution. With interest rates at 16 per cent in the United States and high interest rates all around the world, Australia alone has been able to insulate herself from that and has found the solution; simply by turning the handle of the printing press we are able to print our way out of difficulty and by underwriting inflation we are able to solve the problem'. It would be absolutely marvellous for a while but sooner or later the truth would out; sooner or later the realisation would come home that buying in the very short term a reduction of interest rates at the cost of much higher inflation and in turn even higher interest rates, would be a very poor bargain indeed, not only for a government that was foolish enough to do it but also for the Australian community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I first state my unqualified endorsement of the matter raised by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden)-namely, the disturbing and worsening shambles of Government monetary policy-as a matter of grave and increasing public importance. If the people listening to this debate were seeking confirmation of any belief that the Government's economic policies might be correctly formulated and effectively applied at present, those people now must feel shattered. There is no way in which the Opposition can or will stand idly by while this Government's incoherent obsession with discredited monetarist doctrine inevitably drags the Australian economy and the Australian people deeper into the mire and closer to the brink of economic disaster. For six years this Government has been saying to the Australian people: 'Batten down the hatches, cop it sweet and things will be better and brighter tomorrow'. They have not been better and brighter, and they are not and will not be better and brighter tomorrow if this Government persists with its dogged determination to pursue the discredited economic policies it has pursued for the last six years. It is simply not good enough for the Government to claim that our economic troubles are externally induced, as the Treasurer (Mr Howard) has attempted to do today. This represents a repudiation of the vital role of national economic management and it reflects the economic incompetence and ineptitude of a discredited government, of a discredited Treasurer and of a discredited Prime Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: If ever monetarism were to have a major test, the opportunity for such a test was provided in the spring of 1979 when the rag-tag government behind Mrs Margaret Thatcher was elected in Britain. It was committed to the pursuit of firm monetarist policies. After three years, the economy of Britain was in tatters. I give some evidence of that. Gross domestic product fell by nearly 4 per cent and industrial production dropped below 1973 levels. Unemployment surged past three million, more than twice the 1.25 million unemployed when the Thatcher Government took office. Profits dropped in 1981 to an estimated 2 per cent return on equity. Record bankruptcies and liquidations were the order of the day. Business investment in 1981 fell 3 per cent in real terms. One of the chief economic architects of the Thatcher policy, Professor Alan Budd of the London Business School, has now publicly repudiated the monetarism that he helped to design. He has stated that such drastic tightening should not have been undertaken.

In the face of this massive confirmation of the failure of monetarism as it was being applied in Britain, what did Britain do in the last Budget? This Government is at least six months behind in connection with changes that are taking place in national economic policy and management throughout the whole of the Western world. I make no attempt to justify or excuse the mismatch of monetarism and supply side trickle-down economics, tempered with a little bit of political and economic opportunism, being pursued by the Reagan Administration in the United States. Posterity will indicate the effectiveness of that. What does the most recent Budget in Britain do, amongst other things? First of all, it provides for the injection of an additional $1.36 billion into the economy. It provides tax relief. It provides for a higher value added tax threshold and, quite pertinently, the most recent Budget in Britain provides for an easing of money supply growth targets to 8 per cent to 12 per cent this year compared with 5 per cent to 9 per cent last year. So, the one nation which followed an almost exclusive monetarist policy-in addition to Australia-has now repudiated it and changed direction.

There is only one bright spot in the economic record of this present Government . That occurred in 1980-81, when economic growth in the non-farm sector increased by about 4 per cent in real terms. We well remember how the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Treasurer sought to take credit for that. A number of things happened during that year which this Government could not and should not have sought or taken any credit for at all. Some of that growth resulted from the fact that the Government had ceased momentarily to pursue its stated policy to rein back on government expenditure. But in the run up to the 1980 election it released the purse strings, it increased its spending and as a result of that there was an improvement in economic performance.

The second reason those improvements occurred was because the Government simply was not achieving its economic objective, it was not achieving the sort of strategy it wanted to provide. Fundamental to that strategy, of course, was its claim, which it persists in repeating, that its economic measures are not going to be successful until the real value of wages are reduced. So it pursued that objective. But during 1980 in particular, for the first time in the period of this Government, there was an real increase in the level of wages. That brought about an increase in consumer spending, business confidence and production and helped to hold down increasing unemployment. So that was the second reason for those improvements in the one year in which there was any bright spot in the policy pursued by the Government.

What was the third reason? The third reason was that things happened over which this Government had no control, things happened which improved the Australian economy which this Government deliberately set out to sabotage. During that period there was an inflow in foreign investment to Australia in order to take advantage of resource development. This Government was responsible for sabotaging the State governments in their attempt to undertake necessary public investment in public infrastructure in order to support those developments. So the improvements which occurred in the one bright spot in this Government's record in no way could be or should be asserted as having resulted from the policies being pursued by this Government. The only one thing which is keeping the Australian economy afloat at the moment is investment decisions that were made in 1978, 1979 and 1980. If they were firm investment decisions, if commitments were made, those investments are being carried on. If they were not firm, if there were no commitments made they are either being delayed, modified or abandoned. What has happened with the Rundle oil shale project? What has happened with Stage 2 of the North West Shelf project development? What has happened with the aluminium smelters? What has happened with the coal mining projects which are being abandoned right across the nation? These more recent investment projects are being abandoned wholesale.

What is the position to which this gaggle of incompetents on the Government benches has brought this nation? Let us go through them. They are as follows: The lowest level of consumer and business confidence since the Depression of the 1930s, the highest rate of bankruptcies since the Depression, the highest level of unemployment since the Depression, and an unemployment level which is still growing; an increase from 1 million to 3 million people in the Australian community living below the poverty line-that is, one person in every five or 20 per cent of Australians; one of the lowest levels of economic growth on record and a rate of economic growth which is falling; the Australian dollar which yesterday plunged to its lowest level for five years against the United States dollar; and, as the Leader of the Opposition quite clearly indicated, the highest interest rates ever recorded in the history of the Commonwealth. What is the prospect for the half a million people unemployed? Just to hold that level and absorb the increase in the labour force into employment we would need a growth rate in Australia of between 3 per cent and 3 1/2 per cent. The Treasurer targeted for that figure in the Budget Papers this year. We are not going to reach it. We will be lucky to get to 3 per cent. What is going to be the growth rate next year? It is going to be 1.2 per cent. As a result we will not even absorb those new people into the work force. Unemployment will grow. It is now 7 per cent and by the end of next financial year it will be 10 per cent.

This Government sought first of all a consumer-led recovery. That did not happen. Then it sought an export-led recovery. That did not happen. Then it sought an investment-led recovery. That did not happen. It has now reached the final absurdity-a recession-led recovery. The Australian community is becoming increasingly aware of the deficiencies of this Government and the policies that it is pursuing. It will increasingly turn its support to the Australian Labor Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falconer Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is debating a matter raised by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) concerning monetary policy. The Australian economy is facing an era of great pressure on interest rates. Australia, like other developed countries, cannot isolate itself from the effects of monetary and interest rate developments elsewhere in the world. Moreover, there has been a heavy demand for funds in Australia from companies, from individuals and from governments resulting from growth in the economy. The pressure on interest rates would be even greater if the Government had not acted to limit the public sector demand for funds, both through borrowings for infrastructure development and through containing government outlays. If a resurgence in inflation is to be avoided, control must be maintained over the rate of monetary expansion.

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition, in proposing this matter for debate today, talked about areas of public expenditure that were going ahead and which he felt ought to go ahead with greater expenditure. In this respect the Leader of the Opposition, as in so many other respects, is inconsistent if one looks at the context in which he makes statements about economic matters. When he was Treasurer and was bringing down the Budget for 1975-76 he had quite a lot to say about the deleterious effects of excessive public expenditure on rates of inflation and on the welfare of the community. Let me quote from the Treasurer's Budget Speech of that year. The Leader of the Opposition, who was then the Federal Treasurer, said:

It is not possible to provide more and more government services or transfer payments from the Budget without ultimately having to pay for them through cutting back after-tax earnings via increased taxes. It is not possible to get quarts out of pint pots.
That was what the Leader of the Opposition had to say when he was the Commonwealth Treasurer in 1975. He went on to say:
If inflation is to be curbed there are no soft options-only a choice between more or less difficult ones.

Of course, as Leader of the Opposition he likes to choose the soft options but he has not recanted as far as I know from those statements that he made in 1975. He has not said: 'Sorry, I was wrong'. But as Leader of the Opposition he says that the Government ought to indulge in more and more government expenditure in all sorts of areas that are, on the face of them, popular and would be well received by the public. But the difference is that he was then in government and now he is in opposition and feels he can afford the luxury of those sorts of statements.

The Leader of the Opposition said, as I recall his words: 'Who would put money into shares when the rate of return is as low as it has been recently?' This is another respect in which the Leader of the Opposition and Opposition spokesmen contradict themselves when it suits them. Australian Labor Party spokesmen, including the Leader of the Opposition, like to have it both ways. They like to condemn so-called excessive company profits when it suits them, branding them as rapacious and rip-offs. But when the Leader of the Opposition makes another analysis of the economy for another purpose he points out that company rates of return have been low and that there is a disincentive for people to put their money into that sort of investment. We on this side of the House believe that a profitable private sector is necessary for productivity growth, for employment and for rising living standards. This provides the tax base for all the desirable public expenditures which we would like to see. But for that to take place we cannot have the public sector imposing too high a burden on the private sector, on the ordinary taxpayers, in a way that would stifle incentive.

Slower world demand for Australia's exports and strong demand for imports of machinery and other investment items have resulted, as the Treasurer pointed out , in a large current account deficit. Sluggish growth overseas, low business profits and high interest rates have led to slow or nil growth in many of Australia's overseas markets. There was, for example, a 20 per cent fall in international commodity prices in the year to the last September quarter and flat or falling prices for our agricultural produce. Australia's economy is thus constrained by its interdependence with the rest of the world. It is influenced by the present slackness in world demand. It is certainly influenced by the high cost of funds which is expressed in interest rates. It is influenced by increasing protectionism overseas.

Associated with these influences has been a rapid growth in the current account deficit, squeezed profitability for export industries and some reappraisal of resource projects. However, investment is still strong. Australia's achievements and aspirations must be measured and tempered by the world picture. Australia has swum against the tide with living standards rising, although not as much as we would like, and the economy has been prospering while the world has stagnated . This has been a result of Government policies which created the conditions in which industry had the confidence to develop our resources. The keys were the constant assault on inflation and sustained restraint on government spending. This restraint has been virtually unrivalled in the world and we have seen the Budget deficit cut from almost 5 per cent of gross domestic product under Labor to less than one per cent in the last financial year.

The Commonwealth has also eased the pressure on domestic capital markets by curbing its own borrowing requirements and promoting industrial expansion, competitiveness and productivity. It has managed the exchange rate without disruption. I might say that that responsible management of the exchange rate is not assisted by irresponsible speculation by the Leader of the Opposition or other senior public figures in Australia who publicly advocate a devaluation. It is an irresponsible attitude to take and it does not assist a proper and responsible management of the exchange rate. We have sought to secure improved access and new markets overseas for Australian products. We have encouraged industry with research and development initiatives. We have encouraged industry with the accelerated depreciation allowance and adequate notices of changes in the level of assistance.

These achievements have been based on some economic growth-as I have said, not as much as we would like and certainly not without problems. There are a number of problems in the Australian economy that we still have to overcome. Challenges to that growth must therefore be met if Australians are to continue to rise to their full potential. The Government must be ready to adapt, especially to fundamental changes in the world economy, if the foundations are to be laid for future growth when the upturn in the world economy comes and if Australia is to be carried through the intervening downturn. Today Australia's economy is under challenge from the growing efficiency, productivity and price competitiveness of the restructured industries of some of our competitors.

In that respect we must acknowledge that in the Australian context our productivity, our competitiveness, is not being assisted by the industrial situation that we presently face in this country. What can we say about the competitiveness of industry in New South Wales in view of the present power dispute? What can we say about the employment situation in New South Wales? Monetary policy managed by a Commonwealth government is only one part, albeit an important part, of the total management of the economy. Other parts of the economy, other influences in the economy, are also important. It would be worth while to see some contribution to growth in Australia from other sectors of the economy. New South Wales is presently the strike capital of Australia with almost twice as many working days being lost last year due to industrial disputes as was the case in Victoria. If certain developments are to take place in Victoria as a result of the program of the Labor Opposition in Victoria, we will see a repeat of that performance in the Victorian context. The Victorian Labor Opposition has stated that it will repeal the Vital State Projects Act used for the hastening of the completion of the Newport power station. In view of present power restrictions in New South Wales, affecting also the Australian Capital Territory, where would Victoria be-indeed, where would New South Wales be-if the Newport power station had not been completed? In recent times New South Wales has been relying on the Victorian power grid for the drawing of its energy.

The Labor Party has also committed itself to repealing the secret ballots legislation in Victoria which enables the new industrial relations commission to order a secret ballot on its own initiative. The early success of this measure was evident in the speedy resolution of the strike at the Broadmeadows plant of the Ford Motor Co. of Australia Ltd. The Labor Party has also committed itself to repealing the Essential Services Act which was invoked by the Premier, Mr Thompson, in July of last year to ensure that milk was delivered to the Australian consumer.

—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Perth Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that total annual aircraft movements into and out of Perth Airport are expected to more than double over the next fourteen years.
Your petitioners note that this will produce a dramatic increase in noise pollution in the surrounding suburbs, particularly those directly beneath flight paths.
Your petitioners further note that unlike Great Britain, Australia has no legislation to allow payments of compensation for injurious affection.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
(1) That the Minister for Transport implement a curfew banning traffic movements at Perth Airport between 11.00 p.m. and 6.00 a.m.
(2) That legislation be introduced to allow payment for injurious affection, including compensation for cost of insulation of private and public buildings.
(3) That the planned parallel runway be constructed immediately so as to direct air traffic over the non-residential area at Newburn.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Cloverdale Post Office, Western Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the Cloverdale North Post Office in Sydenham Street, Cloverdale, W.A., is of great importance to the local community.
Your petitioners note that in the surrounding area there is a very high proportion of pensioners. Many of these people do not have cars and some have difficulty using public transport.

Your petitioners further note that since the costs associated with running such a post office agency are very low Australia Post will make only small savings at the expense and great inconvenience of its customers.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that all plans to close Cloverdale North Post Office be abandoned.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Seal Pups
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens of Australia do humby pray that the Government will:

Do all within your power to influence the Canadian Prime Minister and Government to end the senseless annual slaughter of harp and hooded seals. We can see no reason for allowing this inhumane and unnecessary brutality to continue. The world's irreplaceable wildlife must be permitted to exist without exploitation from man.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal Land Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the projected repeal by the Queensland State Government of the Aborigines Act 1971-1979 and the Torres Strait Islander Act 1971-1979 will almost certainly lead to the degazettal of all Aboriginal reserves in Queensland, as has already been the case with Aurukun and Mornington Island.

That if, as is likely, the Aboriginal communities from these reserves are placed under similar shire council legislation on fifty year leases, they will be exposed to serious encroachment on their land by mining and tourist interests .

That it is also quite clear, on past evidence, that these interests will have the full backing of the Queensland government and the rights of Aboriginal people to land rights and self-management will not be granted by that Government .

That the Commonwealth Government has the power to legislate and acquire land for Aboriginal people under its constitutional powers since amendments to the Constitution in 1967, but it is your Petitioners' sincere belief that it failed to act in 1976 and thus, failed in its duty before the people of Aurukun and Mornington Island.
That the Aboriginal people of Queensland have stated that they want land rights and self management.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government make use of its constitutional and legislative powers to grant full land rights and self-management to the Aboriginal people of Queensland.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Mr Yuri Shukhevych
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Mr Yuri Shukhevych, a Ukranian prisoner of conscience in the Soviet Union, has renounced Soviet citizenship and expressed a desire to emigrate to Australia to join members of his family.

Mr Shukhevych was first arrested as a minor, for being the son of Roman Shukhevych, commander-in-chief of the Ukranian Insurgent Army, and has served nearly thirty years of sentences totalling thirty five years for refusing to denounce his father.

During a brief period of release between 1968 and 1972, in which he was forbidden to return to Ukraine, Mr Shukhevych married and had two children. He and his family have been granted entry visas to Australia following special consideration by the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

As latest reports indicate that Mr Shukhevych is in poor health and is partially blind, and that the whereabouts of his wife and children have become unknown, your petitioners pray that the government direct its officers to take whatever urgent action is in their power both to establish the whereabouts of Mr Shukhevych's wife and children and assist in enabling them to emigrate to Australia forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Child Care Expenses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:
Taxpayers who incur child-care expenses in order to earn income should be able to have those expenses exempt from income taxation in the same way as other business expenses.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Sand Mining
PETITION.PARA: To: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That Moreton Island has been listed on the Register of the National Estate because of its exceptional scientific, ecological, heritage and recreational values; and
(2) That any sand mining of Moreton Island will result in the destruction of the exceptional scientific, ecological, heritage and recreational values of the Island; and

(3) That Moreton Island has been the subject of detailed investigation resulting in the adoption of a Management Plan by the Brisbane City Council the main aims of which are to conserve in its natural state the quality of its scenery and natural environment and to enhance public enjoyment of it for recreation purposes; and
(4) That Moreton Island represents the last significant area of wilderness close to Brisbane; and
(5) That there is an acute deficiency of National Parks within a 150 kilometre radius of Brisbane; and
(6) That Moreton Island contains Aboriginal Relics of immense scientific and cultural importance; and
(7) That the Island represents a major potential tourist resource specifically because of its unspoiled natural scenic attractions; and

(8) That public opinion actively demonstrated over a number of years clearly indicates that most citizens of Brisbane are strongly opposed to any sand mining on the Island, and desire that the whole of Moreton Island with the exception only of existing Townships, Tourist Resort, Airstrips and Lighthouse Reserve should be declared a National Park.
Your Petitioners, therefore, Humbly Pray that the Parliament of Australia will:

(a) accept the wishes of the Petitioners and the citizens of Brisbane generally and take whatever action is necessary and available to it to prevent sand mining of any description taking place on Moreton Island; and

(b) request the Government of the State of Queensland to take immediate action to declare the whole of Moreton Island to be a National Park with the exceptions only of existing Townships, Tourist Resort, Airstrips and Lighthouse Reserve.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Export of Live Animals
PETITION.PARA: To: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(a) the export of live animals for slaughter overseas and
(b) the shipment of live horses to Japan sentences such animals to cruel and inhumane treatment in the export process and at the hands of foreign importers.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the house will request the Government to ban the export of live animals for food and allow only carcass trade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Marine Mammal By-products
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:
1. Since the Australian Whale Protection Act 1980 provides for the banning of importation into Australia of all whale by-products, and
2. the Prime Minister has stated that he and his Government support the international banning of whaling,
3. then consistent with (1) and (2), this Government should immediately legislate to ban the importation of all marine mammal by-products, including the harp seal of Canada, and

4. through the Australian delegate in the United Nations General Assembly, the Prime Minister should state his Government's support for an international ban on the slaughter of any marine mammal for commercial reasons.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that consistent with legislation on whaling, this Government should ban the importation of marine mammal by-products and support an international ban on slaughter of any marine mammal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Prime Minister has failed to ensure that his Government honour his 1980 election promise to assist Australian families by redistributing increased oil levy revenue to enable increased family allowances.

That this breach of promise has exacerbated even further the serious financial hardship experienced by one-parent and single income families and permitted the further erosion of family allowances which at the beginning of calendar year 1981 had suffered a 56 per cent loss in value since 1976 when they were last altered.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will call on the Prime Minister to honour his election promise by immediately making budgetary provision to adjust family allowances to reflect the increase to the cost of living since 1976 and to, in future, index allowances to reflect annual C.P.I. increases.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Use of Live Animals in Research
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That continued use of animal ingredients in cosmetic products, and the inhumane use of animals in scientific research for cosmetic products is abhorrent and barbaric.
2. That no central records exist on such inhumane use of live animals for experimentation purposes, yet research institutions in several Australian States engage in such a practice.
3. That there exists no uniform legislation between the States concerning responsible standards of research conduct, indeed, in some States there is a complete lack of legislation altogether.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will enact legislation to require
(a) the Australian Bureau of Statistics to produce annual statistics on the numbers of live animals involved in research, and provide information as to research purpose; and

(b) the National Health and Medical Research Council to develop humane and responsible standards of conduct for researchers using live animals in all Government, Industry and Educational Research Laboratories.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we object to the decision to cease the continuation of funding of the Community Youth Support Scheme at Warren, N.S.W.
We ask that this decision, based on information that does not represent the true picture, be reversed.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
(a) that the Australian Government signed the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women in Copenhagen in 1980;
(b) that the Convention came into force on 3 September 1981;

(c) that Australian women suffer serious disadvantage in employment, education, accommodation, membership of licensed clubs, provision of goods and services including services relating to banking, insurance and the provision of grants, loans, credit or finance;

(d) that this disadvantage could be overcome by (i) making unlawful certain discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status, (ii) eliminating discrimination on the ground of sex and marital status and (iii) promoting affirmative action for women in employment.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament pass the Sex and Marital Status Discrimination Bill 1981.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Women's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that:

We, women of the A.C.T., observe International Women's Day as a celebration of women's struggle against oppression, for choice and as a focus upon the following fundamental requisites of liberation for ourselves and our overseas sisters:
The right to work/Rights for the unemployed;
Free, safe abortion on demand;
Maternity and paternity leave;
Free 24-hour childcare;
Equal pay and equal opportunities;
Freedom from sexual harassment, freedom from rape;
The right to organise;
Guaranteed adequate funding for women's services;
Free and equal education, and
Our freedom to exist as individuals without stereotypes, without double standards and without fear.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to urge the Government to provide for-
(1) a free-standing Government run health clinic in the A.C.T. where all aspects of women's health, including free, safe abortion on demand are covered;
(2) the recognition of rape within marriage;
(3) an A.C.T. single women's shelter, and
(4) adequate funding for existing women's services in the A.C.T.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament Assembled take action as it deems appropriate to ensure that the present Federal Government children's services programme is maintained and improved, and the Child Care Act is retained as a legislative base for this important programme.
In considering the recommendations of the Spender report, no recommendations put forward should be implemented without full consultation with community groups.

The present subsidy system to Child Care Centres should be retained. The proposal that monies be made available to subsidize child care in commercial centres is viewed with grave concern. The proposal to alter the present guidelines for subsidy in different programmes and introduce a common means test is also viewed with grave concern, as the present arrangements are effective.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action on the abovementioned issues.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Seal Pups
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the present hunt for harp seals in Canada is carried out in a cruel and inhumane manner.
That the population of harp seals has not been clearly shown to be increasing.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government formally call on the Canadian Government to end the harp seal hunt and use its constitutional powers to halt the importation into Australia of products derived from the harp seal, Pagophilus groenlandicus.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the proposed sales tax of 2.5% on books, magazines and newspapers represents a tax on knowledge which should not be contemplated in a civilised country. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that this proposed sales tax be withdrawn from the budget proposals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of undersigned electors of the Division of Richmond respectfully showeth:

Concern that the intended 2 1/2% Sale Tax on Books, Magazines and Periodicals will have a detrimental effect upon the Australian Economy and its people, through disproportionate Publisher/Reseller Tax Collection Costings in relation to the smaller Tax Return achieved.

This cost disproportion will cause a general increase in Publishers prices to all areas, including Education, which eventually cost more to Government Departments than the amount gained by the imposition of Sales Tax.
Booksellers supplying to Government Departments will also be subject to heavier costings in paperwork involving Tax Exemptions, in an area that is already struggling on minimal margins.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will not proceed with the intended 2 1/2% Sales Tax on Books, Magazines, Periodicals etc.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Travelling Post Office Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we protest most strongly against the Australian Postal Commission's decision to phase out the Travelling Post Office (T.P.O.) in N.S.W.

The T.P.O. service has given the country people of N.S.W. a reliable and efficient service for many years. To replace this service with a road system would be a backward step which we believe would result in long delays in mail going to and from country centres.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will look favourably on our petition to retain the T.P.O. service in N.S.W.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Export of Domestic Dog and Cat Skins
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that there is widespread concern in the community at the theft, killing and skinning of domestic dogs and cats, for the purpose of exporting skins to be made into coats. While the disappearance of cats has been known to be common for several years, the move to the killing of dogs, especially pure-bred Dalmations and German Shepherds, appears to be relatively new but increasingly frequent.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Parliament give consideration to enacting legislation to prohibit the export of dog and cat skins, with the purpose of stopping this trade. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the proposed imposition of Sales Tax on items concerned with home building, clothing, footwear, books and newspapers, wrapping for food.

Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament to exempt these items from the proposed Sales Tax as requested by the Senate to avoid such taxes on necessities of life becoming a further burden on home builders, families and children or inhibiting the free flow of information through books and newspapers or reducing employment opportunities for people in the industries concerned and beyond.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth concern over Plant Variety Rights (PVR) legislation.
We agree that:
(1) PVR will aggravate the free exchange of genetic material for plant breeding .
(2) PVR will not enhance Australia's access to improved plant varieties developed overseas but will encourage the dumping of unsuitable varieties on the Australian market.
(3) PVR will restrict the public plant breeding program to basic research for exploitation by private enterprise and discourage breeding for disease and pest resistant varieties.
(4) PVR will lead to the domination of the seed industry by foreign interests not responsible to the Australian people.
(5) The proprietary rights granted by PVR will encourage the introduction of seed distribution and marketing monopolies and lead to seed price increases.
Your petitioners therefore pray that Parliament:
(1) refrains from enacting any legislation on PVR,
(2) calls for a public enquiry into the impact of existing overseas PVR schemes on the Australian seed industry and the international seed trade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
