TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate on the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill is resumed, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill and the Overseas Students Charge Collection Amendment Bill 1982.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I continue my remarks from where I left off on Thursday , when I was so rudely interrupted by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and sundry other honourable members, on the matter of housing. It would have been justified to have interrupted those very pertinent remarks I was making on the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill 1982 had the announcement been worth while but we were subjected to three hours of debate on a pretty worthless measure. I am glad that we are now in a position to get back to discussing the Opposition's very necessary amendment to the motion that the Bill be read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: When I was interrupted I was talking about the substantial contribution we were making to Malaysia's internal politics in the situation which existed prior to 1979, when no fees were charged to private overseas students studying at Australian tertiary institutions. I remarked that, because of the constraints of internal Malaysian politics, an agreement had been reached between the various communities in Malaysia which meant that persons of Malay origin in Malaysia were favoured for entry into universities in Malaysia to the exclusion of persons of Chinese origin. The effect of that agreement, of course, was to create some substantial tensions in the Chinese community.

When I was involved in student politics I was aware of the very considerable significance placed by the Chinese of Malaysia on the fact of their ready access to Australian universities. For a very large number of them-those who were competent students but perhaps slightly less so than the very brilliant students who could run the gauntlet of the restrictions imposed upon them in Malaysia-it was their one chance to obtain a decent tertiary education. The students who came here by no means reflected the most wealthy sections of the Chinese community. I had a large number of friends among the overseas students at the time. Whilst some of them certainly were of a very wealthy background in Malaysia, others were not. I heard a number of stories from students whose parents and relatives had made very considerable sacrifices to enable them to get to university. It is really to those students who, since 1979, have been disadvantaged by this legislation that the Opposition has addressed its amendment, which we hope the Government will take on board.

I am not one of those people who believe that we ought totally to divorce our aid program from our foreign policy. I know that is sometimes argued. It is often argued from this side of the House. But any nation ought to take the opportunity, at least through some aspects of its aid program, to encourage particular political developments or particular political relationships that the country deems important to its national security. There can be no doubt at all that the Association of South East Asian Nations powers-Malaysia is one and the Philippines is another-from which we draw a number of private students, are of very considerable significance to this country. It is a shame in many ways that over the last decade we have come to neglect our relationship with the ASEAN powers. We do have substantive disagreement with them over a number of economic matters. We have substantial disagreements with Indonesia over certain features of Indonesian domestic policy, in the main, and we have disagreement with it over attitudes towards the situation in Vietnam, although the disagreement there is somewhat more marginal than it is in the other areas.

Despite the fact of those disagreements, those countries remain extraordinarily important to us; the good will of the people of those countries is very important to us and the internal stability of those countries remains very important to us. The fact that the students went back to those countries, to Malaysia in particular, and subsequently exercised a considerable degree of authority, in the Chinese community at least and sometimes in the general Malaysian community as a whole, was of very considerable benefit both to those countries and to Australia. It is very unfortunate that the fairly niggardly amount of money that this surcharge raises should have been imposed to the detriment of a foreign policy objective that is worth a great deal more to us.

Probably the way in which the Government intends to amend this legislation-that is why the Bill is before us on this occasion-is an indication of the extent to which Australia has shifted its foreign policy interest in the regions which our Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) is want to describe as areas of our strategic concern. I think the fact that the Government is extending to students from Papua New Guinea and the South Pacific the exemption from paying these fees is an indication of the extent to which for the moment this Government has assigned higher priority in Australian relations to that area than it has assigned to areas of previous interest in Asia.

I noted last year a statement made by Mr Loh, the Director of the National Overseas Students Services, which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald of 12 September. In it Mr Loh expressed his understanding of the reasons that the Government should have engaged in this shift. He stated:

Your Government has obviously decided to treat a specific region with special care. The presence of the Soviet Union offering fishing agreements and other aid packages has obviously spurred on this decision.

I am not sure whether this decision was in fact spurred on by the Government's concern with Soviet activities in the South Pacific, although on numerous occasions Government Ministers and Government back benchers have expressed concern about Soviet activities in that area. But undoubtedly Mr Loh is correct in that obviously there were certain political objectives behind our interest in the region and those political objectives called forth this decision to be generous specifically to students from those areas as opposed to students from Asia. We can see a shift also in Government policy towards this area; for example, in the decision to purchase the aircraft carrier. The aircraft carrier is not particularly valuable for the defence of Australia, but if Australia were ever to take it upon itself to pressure or in other ways to intimidate nations, or movements, in the South Pacific region, an aircraft carrier certainly would be useful for that purpose. If that is underpinning the Government's decision to exempt students from that area from the charge while still imposing it on students from other areas, the Government is mistaken. There never will be a substantial security threat to Australia from that area that has not already emerged in South East Asia and there will never be an occasion when those fairly unpopulated areas will be as significant to us as our relations with the ASEAN powers. I think that the Government really ought to recognise that.

In the Government's policy there may also be an element of competition with New Zealand for numbers of students from this area. As honourable members would probably be aware, the New Zealanders do not charge this additional tuition charge. That, naturally enough I suppose, is one of a number of factors which encourage a large number of students from the South Pacific region to opt to do their studies at New Zealand universities. I realise that this funding comes from the pocket of the Australian taxpayer. I am not attempting to make a party political argument in respect of the action that is being taken. I am thoroughly aware that if it boiled down to that it would not be unnatural in these straitened times in the general Australian community for the Australian taxpayers to opt for imposing a charge on students who come into this country rather than having to meet out of their own pockets the whole of the bill for their education here, and it would be a perfectly reasonable position for Australian taxpayers to take. All I can say is that if the Government were to take this matter a step further and see it as part of the Government's general aid package, as I believe it ought to, there may well be other areas of Australian foreign aid that could be reduced somewhat to take up the amount of money that would be taken out of another area of government activity by virtue of the fact that this surcharge was removed. I think it is arguable that the service that we perform in taking care of these students in this country and providing them with educational opportunities is of materially greater benefit to their societies than some of the other things that we do.

When this surcharge was introduced it was argued by the Minister at the time that a very large number of the students who came to Australia on a private basis remained here and had the benefit not only of an Australian education but also of Australian living standards and participation in the Australian economy and were not contributing the results of their education to the development of their own countries. If that was the situation pertaining then, and I have no doubt that it was, it is not the situation which pertains now. The Government is increasingly insisting that students who come here to study on a private basis return home prior to any attempt by them to return to Australia. That is not, I would submit, an entirely unreasonable decision by the Government. But it does change the circumstances in which the surcharges were originally introduced. It eliminates entirely the argument which was put for imposing the charges at the time they were introduced. In the light of that, I think the Government really ought to take very serious notice of the proposition which has been put forward by the honourable member for Fremantle. In the light of the fact that these students will now return to their home countries to make a contribution to their own societies, we really ought to look at the significance of the assistance that we provide to a large number of Asian students in permitting them entry to Australian universities, take it seriously as an aspect of our aid program and permit the needier of the students in that position to come here. I think the Malaysians will have very good reason for thanking us if we do that. It can only be to the very considerable long term advantage of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MACPHEE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be brief in my response to the remarks of the honourable member for Swan ( Mr Beazley). The honourable member did range far and wide in his contribution, including his reference to the purchase of an aircraft carrier and other aspects of foreign policy. It is true that this debate has some important foreign policy implications but I shall confine myself to those parts of his remarks that concern the overseas students charges legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The facts in respect of students in Australia are that, in 1979, 32.6 per cent of the students were from member countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations, principally from Malaysia, and in 1980 that had actually risen to 42.2 per cent. Again, the students were principally from Malaysia, and very often from fairly wealthy families. By contrast, in 1979, 633 students or 13.7 per cent of the total were from the South Pacific and in 1980 this number dropped to 537 or 10 per cent of the total. Therefore, the House will see that we have had a sharp drop in what was a fairly small percentage of the intake from the South Pacific. So the explanation which was mused upon by the honourable member for Swan is not really so hard to find. We really do have a geopolitical obligation towards both South East Asia and the South Pacific, which I know the honourable member shares wholeheartedly. Quite frankly, our reason for exempting South Pacific students is, if you like, to discriminate positively in their favour in much the way we did in respect of South East Asia and Malaysia in particular.

I had very full discussions on this matter with the then Minister for Education , who is now the Deputy Prime Minister, Datuk Musa Hitam, who fully understands our policy. I am sure that my predecessor had similar discussions before the program was introduced. What we are doing by this legislation is effectively maintaining the real value of the charges which have already been set. They were set for a combination of reasons, not the least of which are simply our own budgetary reasons, which I will come to in a moment. But no offence is taken in Malaysia or elsewhere in ASEAN to those charges. On the contrary, there is an appreciation of the effectiveness of the Colombo Plan and subsequent education plans. I think there has been a recognition both here and in ASEAN that most of the things which the honourable member for Swan said have been achieved have been achieved to the benefit of the countries in our region. One of the pillars of our relationship with ASEAN has been built on the Overseas Student Program and the subsequent refugee program has consolidated that relationship.

I am sure the honourable member for Swan was not saying that we should not assist the South Pacific. He mused about the various reasons why we were assisting students from that area. Quite frankly, not one of the ASEAN countries is concerned with the level of charges. They are still infinitely lower than the charges that students have to pay in other countries for similar standards of education. Of course, as a result of their own efforts primarily but also with some assistance from ourselves, they now have a very high level of education in their own institutions, which cannot be said to be basically the case in the South Pacific. So there is still a question of our having to assist the South Pacific as part of an overall responsibility in the area and to do it in a way which encourages more of that region's students to come here.

The honourable member for Swan did not seriously criticise our policy of obliging people to return home for two years. The last thing we would want and the one thing which would damage our relations would be a brain drain. But if after two years people feel that they cannot make any greater contribution to their country of origin they are, of course, free to apply to migrate. We have no sense of guilt about that policy. The Ministers of the governments concerned also feel that if somebody does not want to stay after a two-year trial on his return from Australia he is quite welcome to migrate. Many of those people add a very important character to Australia, but the worst thing we could do would be to train them and keep them without asking them to go back and contribute to the country from which they came.

Before the debate was adjourned last Thursday the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) made a couple of requests which I shall comply with. First of all, he asked that an explanation be given to the Parliament on the effect of the introduction of the charges in relation to the Overseas Student Program. As was stated in the House by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs at the time of the introduction of the original legislation, the Overseas Student Program helps to promote better understanding of Australia, its people and attitudes. That has been confirmed by the contribution which has been made by the honourable member for Swan. It is an important contribution to international cultural exchange and good will on a global basis. It is particularly beneficial to developing countries, particularly those in the region in which we live. The Government considered carefully the nature and the objectives of our Overseas Student Program at the time of the introduction of the overseas students charges legislation in 1979. Whether the charges would deter or prevent overseas students from coming to Australia to study was a matter that was specifically taken into account. Very careful inquiries were made overseas. From the estimated figures of overseas students at universities and colleges of advanced education over the last three years-that is, those who would have been subject to the charges-one can conclude that the introduction of the charges has not adversely affected the Overseas Student Program.

These estimated figures are that in 1979 about 6,500 were at universities and colleges of advanced education; in 1980, there were 7,200 -that was when the legislation came into effect-and we expect the final figure for 1981 will be a little over 8,000. So, there has been a fairly steady climb, and the level of charge has certainly not deterred people from coming. It is a bit like immigration and refugee policies. We cannot take everyone who wants to come, but we find that the level of charges introduced, and being maintained here, is not a deterrent. The total overseas student population is, of course, much higher that those figures reflect, but those who attended senior secondary colleges, colleges of technical and further education and other training institutions were not subject to the charges.

The honourable member for Fremantle also asked about the rationale for exempting students from certain developing countries, particularly in the South Pacific region, and not from others. I have partly answered that in respect to the honourable member for Swan, but I stated also in my second reading speech that the exemption of charges in favour of students from Papua New Guinea and the South Pacific region is consistent with our special relationship with and our obligations towards this region by virtue of Australia's geographic location , historic ties and relative economic strength. Australia, of course, also values its relationship with other developing countries, but Australia does not possess unlimited resources.

In any case-and this is most important-the charges that we are making represent only about 40 per cent of the cost of overseas students' education in Australia. In other words, Australia has already subsidised 60 per cent of their education costs. Unlike Australian students whose families contribute to their education through tax, overseas students make no such contribution. So it is our view-it is a view understood and respected for those reasons by the governments of the Association of South East Asian Nations-that it is not unreasonable, having regard to the state of the Australian economy and the demands on the Australian taxpayer, that we should make a charge covering about 40 per cent of the costs of the students' education in Australia.

There was also the question of selection procedures. Before 1979, the criteria for entry were based mainly on the non-availability of courses in the home countries of overseas students. This sometimes led to students proposing to undertake courses of little relevance to their home countries. Since 1980, new private student criteria have enabled more students to be accepted from a wider group of countries. These criteria take into account the training capacity of Australia-that is, without displacing Australian students-and such other factors as academic ability of overseas students, the relevance and value of the proposed courses to students as well as to their home countries, and, of course, what courses are available in their home countries.

In respect of the Opposition amendment, one would have to say that the level of need or poverty varies from one country to another. It would be most difficult to determine objectively whether needy students from one country deserve more special assistance than those from other countries. That is what the amendment implies. The matter, however, is more relevant in terms of foreign aid of various kinds rather than in terms of student charges. I have referred to the foreign aid reasons in our consideration. But in any case, under the existing legislation, under section 7 of the Overseas Students Charge Collection Act 1979 , special arrangements can be made for the discharge of liability in favour of an overseas student. It seems to me that this meets the Opposition's objections. These arrangements include an arrangement between the government of an overseas country and Australia under which that overseas country undertakes to pay the charge or the charge is met by Australia. Scholarships by a department or authority of the Commonwealth to assist an overseas student to undertake or continue his study are again quite a common device adopted in Australia.
For those reasons the Government does not accept the Opposition amendment and I commend the Bill as it stands.

TALK.START.PARA: —With your indulgence, Mr Deputy Speaker, the Opposition does not intend to press the matter to a division, but we still believe that it would have been better had the Government accepted the amendment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to delay the Committee, Mr Drummond , but I remind honourable members that, when the second reading debate took place, it was considered that there was a problem with the time, because we were waiting for a Government announcement about housing and, therefore, on that occasion I did not use all the time available to me. I want, briefly, to take up a number of matters with the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee). I am delighted that he is here-unlike a number of his colleagues who do not see through the passage of their legislation. I am indebted to the Minister for having responded to a number of points which I made and which the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley) made, but there are couple of small matters to which I should like the Minister to respond, either now or subsequently.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to us that very little information seems to be held by the Government in relation to the operation of this program. The Minister was kind enough to make available to the Opposition an official from his Department to discuss some of the aspects of the proposals and the development of the overseas student program over the last few years since the introduction of these charges. But it is clear that very little is known about the sorts of students who come here and about the overall effect of the impact of these new charges on the kinds of students who are coming here. The Minister has said that the numbers, except in relation to the South Pacific, have not declined. I understand that they have increased. That may well be so. But we do not seem to know very much about the socio-economic background of the students concerned. When the Minister spoke a few moments ago, I think that he said that the majority of the students came from relatively rich families.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many.

—Many. Whether it is many, a substantial minority, or a majority, the point is that I should like to know on what the Minister's information is based and whether there has been any change in relation to the socio-economic background of the students as a result of the introduction of these charges. I do not know whether the Minister holds that information or whether that is a sort of seat-of-the-pants guess by him. If he knows it, I think that it would be useful for us, in considering these matters, if he would let us know. Indeed, I go so far as to say that it might not be a bad idea for the Government to produce some sort of paper to present to the chamber on the operation of this program and the sorts of changes which have taken place because I think that circumstances have changed substantially.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has explained that the Government said, when it introduced these charges, that it was trying to cope with the fact that most of the students-I think that 75 per cent was the figure used at the time-who came here to study remained here and did not, as was originally intended, return to their home country. As I have pointed out, as the honourable member for Swan has pointed out and as the Minister has confirmed, a very much greater proportion of the students now do return to their home countries and therefore in a sense a large part of the original justification for the introduction of the charges has been removed. That leaves the Government with only one other peg to hang its policy on, and that is the question of wanting to raise some revenue; that is, making the overseas students who, as the Minister rightly pointed out do not contribute to the taxes of this country, contribute to the cost of their education. I acknowledge that they make only a minority contribution but that was not the original justification for the scheme, although obviously the Government did mention it at the time. That has now really become the sole justification for these levies and, indeed, must be the single reason for increasing them at this time.

The other point which is not clear at all is that whilst we know that in this year something like $12m will be collected as a result of the imposition of this charge, we do not know-at least I do not know; I would be grateful if the Minister could tell me-what the net figure is. We know that those students who are supported under, for instance, an Australian Development Assistance Bureau program or some other government sponsored program, do not pay the charge themselves. In the case of ADAB, it would pay the charge. There would be a transfer of funds to ADAB so that it could pay the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs the charge in respect of the student whom it supports. So, whilst the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs may well collect $12m this year , it is not clear how much of that money is a book entry coming from ADAB across to the Minister's Department and distorts the level of revenue which the Government is receiving. I know that the use of this mechanism makes our aid program look that much better but at the same time it distorts the other purpose of the Government's intention-that is, to show that it is receiving a healthy amount of revenue in respect of the cost of educating these overseas students.

Those matters are important. The point is-the Minister has made much of this- that if this is part of the aid program, if we are trying to make a contribution to the education of people particularly from developing countries in our region, then we need to know the sort of information which at the moment does not seem to be available. It could not be provided to us in our discussions last week with officials from the Department. It seems to me very important that we know the socio-economic background of the students who are having to pay these fees. Whilst it may be that, as the Minister has indicated, the numbers from South East Asia have not declined-in fact, they have gone up-maybe a different kind of student is coming here now and others who may have been able to come before the charges were imposed are now not able to do so. There is no suggestion that those people who cannot come now have educational opportunities available to them in their home countries for, amongst other reasons, the sorts of reasons which the honourable member for Swan mentioned-those relating to internal matters in countries such as Malaysia. If we are trying to provide educational opportunities for those people who otherwise would not have them, then it is important that we know a little more about the people who have been affected by the imposition of these charges.

I know it may not be possible for the Minister to respond to these matters now but I ask him to consider having his Department prepare a paper on the operation of the Overseas Student Program so that we are in a better position. It is not as if the Opposition is at absolute loggerheads with the Government on this question. It seems to me to be a question of defining the objectives of the program and really working out whether or not those objectives are being met.

The other matter to which the Minister did not respond-I know it is one with which he has been involved over the last few months-is the problem relating to health care arrangements for overseas students. The Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) did not respond to that matter on Thursday evening. I know it is still a matter of very great concern to overseas students. I do not want to repeat what I said last Thursday but I ask the Minister to make some sort of statement, or respond to us in some way about those problems and what the Government is doing to sort out the confusion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MACPHEE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of the health care arrangements, I have had some correspondence with the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) and I shall pass on the request of the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) that as soon as possible the position be made public. My recollection is that the Minister has made a public statement but if he has not I will ask that he does so. I think the request of the honourable member for Fremantle is a reasonable one. This is one of those programs that cuts across many departments and which in many ways does not belong with the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. It involves largely a foreign policy objective, and in many ways it is a matter of education policy as well because one of the benefits-especially where some of the wealthier students go to private schools-is obviously felt by Australian educational institutions.

SPEECH.PARA: The overriding objectives are stability of the area and a closer understanding between the countries of the area, including Australia. Within those objectives, we certainly do have evaluations. The honourable member is right in observing the shifts which have taken place in the purpose of this policy. They have been reflected in this debate. It ought to be possible to get him quite firm information on those net figures that he refers to, including the book entries, the actual level of revenue and Australian Development Assistance Bureau and other sponsorships. We also should be able to get a reasonably accurate socio- economic profile, though of course we do not interfere with the selection methods of private institutions when families are paying the way of the students . Our most intimate knowledge comes where there is government sponsorship by another government or by ourselves of a student who cannot pay his or her way and who has moved to undertake the courses. I would be delighted to speak to the various departments involved in this program and obtain a document with the objective of either tabling it or at least writing to the honourable member about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

—Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker. After Question Time today at about 2.30 the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Morris), whom I have advised I would be making this statement, made a personal explanation in which he said that last Wednesday in the Sinai peacekeeping force debate I had misrepresented him in my speech. I am grateful to the honourable member for showing me the first typed transcript of his personal explanation so that I would know precisely what he said. In my speech last Wednesday I referred to the infamous revolutionary political views of Miss Vanessa Redgrave and I deplored the fact that, knowing these infamous views, many members of the Australian Labor Party had welcomed and applauded Miss Redgrave's anti-Israeli political position. PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 March, on the following papers presented by Mr Sinclair:
Report of the Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission and Consultants' Reports.
and on motion by Mr Killen:
That the House take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The other evening when debating the Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission we covered a great deal of ground as to the future of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. I have just a couple of points left that I would like to bring to the attention of the House. One of those points concerns the fact that the Dix report made it very clear that the ABC should in fact be in charge of its own transmitters. It would seem to me that this is one particular area that has been of some very great concern in recent years to the Commission. In fact, if we do little more than place those transmitting facilities under the control of the ABC we will be doing the Commission a great service.

SPEECH.PARA: Another point that came to light through the Dix Committee was the amount of Australian content that has been screened by the ABC. Over the years we have seen imposed on the commercial broadcasters around Australia quota systems, time systems and suggestions of expenditure systems to encourage the making of Australian programs. Indeed, I believe that the ABC should, along with the commercial organisations, have due regard to the manufacturing of Australian television programs and that if any imposition is put on the commercial television industry that same encouragement for the production of Australian programs should be given to the Commission as well.

Another point along those same lines is the fact that the ABC does not need to pay regard to certain censorship requirements that are made in respect of the commercial television industry. Therefore, the other thing I think we should be bringing into line in this regard is the point that any censorship classifications that apply to the commercial organisations should in fact apply to the ABC as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is debating the report of the Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission which was presented in May of last year-that is, the report has been around for nearly a year. I want to make the point that this is a very unsatisfactory way for the Parliament to be dealing with a report such as the one before us. The Dix Committee report should have been debated very much earlier. The whole point of having a parliamentary debate on a report such as this is that the Government can be given some indication of the range of views which exist within the Parliament before it makes its formal response to the report. But we are now in the situation where the Government, having delayed for too long making its response to the report, must, I suspect, be very close to finalising its views about the recommendations of the Committee. So I suspect that this debate on the Dix Committee report will really not have any influence at all on the Government 's decision-making process in relation to its response. I think, therefore, that the value of a debate such as this will be diminished substantially. However, we have to be thankful for small mercies.

SPEECH.PARA: Just as we welcomed the setting up of the Dix Committee, just as we welcomed its report, whilst not agreeing with all of what was said, we do, of course, welcome this opportunity, brief as it is, late as it is, probably unproductive as it is in a sense, to respond to the report. What the Dix Committee really did was provide a fairly substantial criticism of the operation of the ABC. But regrettably the report was in short, a bit disappointing in terms of the sorts of remedies which it proposed for correcting the problems which, as I said, it correctly outlined in many cases. I should say that the Opposition has formally responded to the Dix Committee's report in a paper released earlier this month by Senator Button, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and the Opposition shadow Minister for Communications. I will refer very briefly to some aspects of the Australian Labor Party's response as enunciated by Senator Button. We were anxious that there be substantial debate about these questions. Of course, we were also keen to try to do what we could to encourage the Government to come forward with its formal response as soon as possible.

As I said, we are conscious of the criticisms which the Dix Committee has made but we do not believe that the major focus should be on those criticisms. We believe that the opportunity should be taken to revitalise and strengthen the ABC because we recognise, as the Dix Committee does, that the ABC is a great national institution which really deserves fortification and continuing broad community support. There is a need to indicate the importance of the ABC because we basically believe that the ABC is of vital importance in articulating some notion of Australia's national identity. There are very few opportunities for that sort of process, that articulation, to occur in this country, divided as it is into six States which are often at odds with each other and which are led by Premiers who are often at odds with each other and, indeed, with the nation itself. Therefore, it is important for whatever vehicles there are at our disposal to continue to remind the Australian people of the importance of Australian nationhood and to articulate what that really means in the broadest possible way. That is why a great deal of our emphasis has been placed on the Parliament's coming up with a bipartisan statement about the role of the ABC, a statement with which we can all agree; that is, not a statement which the party which might be in government for the time being believes is convenient for it and advances its particular cause, but one which will be enduring and with which we can all agree, regardless of who is in government and of who happens to be running the ABC at any particular time.

Of course, the ABC has an immensely complex role. It has, at the one time, to be a quality broadcaster catering for specialised interests within the community and, at the same time, to compete for audiences in what one might call mass entertainment, but mass entertainment of the highest possible standard. Because of the complexity of that role and because of the importance of the ABC in articulating this sort of national purpose, it is important that the Parliament does agree to the proposal which has been put forward by the Australian Labor Party that there should be a statement from the Parliament which indicates, in a bipartisan way, the role of the ABC as seen by the representatives of the people in the Parliament. In the absence of that sort of bipartisan statement, in the absence of that sort of agreement, the ABC will always be vulnerable to political heavying of one kind or another, whether it is in relation to the stacking of the Commission with tame friends of whichever happens to be the party in office, whether it is in relation to some of the staff appointments within the ABC, or whether it is just the haranguing by politicians of the ABC, accusing it of all kinds of bias which, when it boils down to it, is accusing it of not always agreeing with whatever particular prejudices the critic happens to possess.

We need only to go back to 1975 when the current Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) decided to appoint himself as the then Opposition's critic-a very vocal and damaging critic-of the ABC. At that time he accused the ABC of all kinds of bias and misconduct which were totally baseless but were also very damaging for its organisation. Indeed, what he did to the ABC at that time, and what the Government has subsequently done, has really weakened substantially the organisation. The ABC consists of very creative people who need sufficient freedom to pursue their talents and to provide the best broadcasting available. That sort of baseless criticism, and indeed the response from some of the weaker administrators of the ABC, has not helped it to be a strong and vital organisation in recent times. That is why it is important that we sort out in a bipartisan way the role of the ABC.

On a related matter, we must ensure that whoever is running the ABC enjoys, as far as can be established, the support of the Parliament as a whole. That is why we have proposed that, in relation to a seven-man Commission, the appointees to that Commission should be appointed on the recommendation of a parliamentary committee. The parliamentary committee would comprise members of the Government and the Opposition. The Government would have the majority of members and, in a sense, of course, if it were determined to, it could use its members on that committee to get its appointees. But we believe that there would be a presumption on the Minister who would be receiving the recommendation and, in effect, making the appointment that he would not use the brute force of numbers on that committee to get his way. We would call for applications for members of the Commission and have those applications vetted in a public way by the committee. In that way, we believe we would be more likely to get people of talent, people with relevant experience and skills and people who are likely to enjoy the confidence of both sides of Parliament, which can only strengthen the ABC and the way in which it goes about its task.

The Commission thus appointed would be responsible for making senior staff appointments, including that of the general manager or director-general, whatever the title is. This apparently seems to be one of the issues on which the Government is stymied at the moment. It cannot make up its mind, particularly in relation to the retirement of Sir Talbot Duckmanton, whether it should make the appointment or whether the Commission should make the appointment. Our view is that the appointment is not one which ought to be made on political grounds; rather it is one which should be made on quite neutral grounds-a vitally important appointment which should enjoy wide community support.

I want to mention very quickly a matter which I took up with the Dix Committee in my submission to it. It relates to the management of the ABC in the various States. I return to the point I made initially of the national importance of the ABC in articulating a national identity, a national consciousness. What has happened in the administration of the ABC at the State level is that in far too many cases the State management has taken a far too parochial view of its role and has overlooked and downplayed the national objectives and the necessary national outlook of the ABC. In Western Australia, we had the example where the ABC did something with which the former Premier, Sir Charles Court, disagreed. He had the gall to carpet the State manager of the ABC and abuse him for some story or program which the ABC had run and with which the Premier had disagreed. That was a totally inappropriate action for a Premier to take but it was an action which he felt quite free to take because of the operation of the State management at the time. Happily, the State manager who was then in office has now departed; but it does raise a very serious question.

The Dix Committee's recommendations in relation to State management do not necessarily overcome the problem. What it proposed in relation to each of the functions of the ABC was that the people in charge of those functions at the State level should be responsible to national heads of those functions and not to a State manager-not that, in many respects, they are at the moment. But that does not necessarily overcome the problem unless arrangements are made for a regular and compulsory turnover of the people heading those functions at the State level. I think it is very important that the ABC be organised in such a way that that matter can be taken up; that whoever happens to occupy the important positions which influence content and programming at the State level ought to be rotated in some way so that he does not become too parochial. That is not to say that there is not a very important role for the State management of the ABC to convey to the organisation nationally the interests and the concerns of the local community. Of course that is important; that goes without saying. But it must not override the national purpose of the ABC.

There is one other matter that I want to refer to briefly. The Dix Committee indicated that it was of the view that there should be an increase in activity by the ABC in relation to the employment of Aboriginal people. I concur absolutely with that view but I think the Dix Committee was far too timid in the recommendations that it made in that regard. The point is that the ABC does represent a vehicle through which Aboriginal people can enjoy a much higher profile than they do at the present. The most visible Aboriginals in our community are those political activists who get involved very promptly in campaigns for land rights or whatever other aspects of the Aboriginal campaign might be pursued at any time. That is the type of Aboriginal of which people are particularly aware. The other type of which people are conscious is that minority-but nevertheless substantial part of the Aboriginal community-which is smitten by urban poverty. It seems to me that a huge number of Aboriginal people in the community are doing extraordinarily important things extraordinarily well . They are the sorts of people who must be given a much higher profile in the community.

The ABC has here a very important role; it is that of actively seeking and recruiting Aboriginals to go before the television cameras so that people can see their artistry and other abilities. An increasing number of our Aboriginal artists, many of whom are proceeding under very great difficulties, could be very fruitfully employed by the ABC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton Mr J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the Government for bringing on this debate on the report of the Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission before announcing its own response to it. With this elegant and persuasive report from Mr Dix and his committee, we reach a milestone in the broadcasting and cultural history of Australia. The Parliament has before it the reactions of all interested parties, including the ABC. I agree with the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) that it is up to us to proceed to achieve as much bipartisan agreement as possible. The quality of our response to this historic opportunity will have a profound effect on the enrichment of Australia's intellectual, cultural and recreational life in the decades ahead.

SPEECH.PARA: Before proceeding, I pay tribute to the present General Manager of the ABC, Sir Talbot Duckmanton, who has announced his intention to retire later this year. He has had the unenviable task of managing for 17 years an almost unmanageable organisation. Indeed, the nature and extent of the organisational and legal constraints on the ABC management have only now become clear under the searching analysis of the Dix inquiry. Despite those difficulties, Sir Talbot, together with other talented people, has led an organisation that is shown by the Dix Committee's surveys to be highly regarded by a very broad section of the Australian community. I hope that Sir Talbot will carry into his retirement the appreciation and best wishes of all honourable members of this House.

In the limited time available, I will touch on three matters: Firstly, the overall shape of the proposed organisation; secondly, the question of commercial sponsorship; and, thirdly, the proposals for the administration of music. In regard to the overall structure of the organisation, there is always a danger, when one has a carefully argued and internally consistent report, such as the Dix report, that the really critical recommendations-those determining the capacity of the organisation to meet its public responsibilities-will be obscured in the welter of conflicting arguments put forward by various interest groups. Therefore, the Government's first responsibility is to carry out the principal organisational changes recommended by the Committee. It is not important to argue over the name-which is perhaps best left as it is-but it is important to establish a board of directors as recommended by the Dix committee, and to give to it the powers and financial wherewithal to get on with the job. It is also important to separate the managerial and representative functions. Therefore I support the establishment of the Broadcasting Consultative Council as a separate body. I am in strong disagreement with the views expressed in the statement by the present commissioners rejecting this separation of functions under a common chairmanship.

The present Commission is effective neither as a representative body nor a policy body. Its defensive response to the Dix proposals makes it clear that it does not appreciate its organisational shortcomings. I do not reflect in any way on the personal capacities of the commissioners, rather on the structure, which makes them neither fish nor fowl, neither managerial nor representative, but with a greater capacity to interfere than to initiate, and therefore disappointing to the management, the staff and the customers. Thus, I believe that the Government should adopt the carefully constructed proposals of the Dix Committee.

However, let me take issue with one aspect of the organisational recommendations. While agreeing with the Committee's proposal to have the directors appointed by the Government, I disagree with the proposal to allow the directors to appoint the Director-General. In theory, this system seems to ensure a greater independence for the ABC. The honourable member for Fremantle has argued that point. In practice, I believe that the best way to ensure the appointment of Directors-General of the highest calibre and acknowledged independence is to make it absolutely clear that the responsibility lies with the Government to make a good appointment. Just as the appointment of a Governor -General is a test of the quality of a government's advice to the monarch, so too should the choice of a Director-General of the ABC be a test of the Government's capacity and willingness to adopt a bipartisan approach on a matter of great national importance.

The Director-General is the most important person in the proposed organisation, more important as an individual than the Chairman or any of the directors. It will be his or her intellectual stature, managerial capacity and leadership qualities that will shape the philosophy and style of the ABC. It is unfair and unwise to allow such a critical appointment to be left with a board that is not elected and may well have been appointed by a previous government. Who then would be held responsible for an unsatisfactory appointment? No, the buck must stop with Government.

On the question of commercial sponsorship, let me say that the Dix Committee has recommended allowing the ABC to accept what it called corporate underwriting under strict guidelines. The present Commission welcomes this proposal and even suggests that the guidelines should not be as strict as recommended by the Committee. I am totally opposed to corporate underwriting. It is not central to the Dix Committee recommendations. Indeed, the expected proceeds are so small that one wonders why it is worth risking some of the possible consequences for such a limited return. I oppose corporate underwriting because, firstly and most importantly, it provides a means for governments to evade their responsibility to finance a national broadcasting organisation on an adequate basis. Increasing pressure can be put on the directors to find more and more money from other sources. The directors' job is to achieve excellence in broadcasting, not to plague corporations for funds in competition with all the other bodies who are obliged to do so. There is a difference, for example, between the Australian Opera, which appeals to a narrower audience, and the ABC, which serves virtually everyone. If we want an independent national broadcaster, we must face up to paying for it. Once again, the responsibility must be crystal clear. It must rest with the Government.

Secondly, there is already a heavy drain on the finite pool of corporate funds available for the kinds of purposes envisaged by the Committee. The Australian Opera, for example, has managed to tap corporate sources of finance with some effect, but its task is already difficult enough without competition from the ABC. Thirdly, whatever the initial guidelines for corporate underwriting, there will be pressures to extend it. I believe that it would have a corrupting influence within the ABC. There is a danger of progressive encroachment occurring on the independence of program producers. One of the reasons for having a national broadcasting organisation is to provide an environment for creative effort that is not subject to the commercial pressures one accepts in the private sector of broadcasting. There is also a danger that producers with greater capacity to attract sponsors but with inferior creative talents might be favoured by management in the allocation of resources and air space.

Fourthly, and finally, I object to the blurring of the distinction between the market sector of paid advertising and the taxpayer-supported availability of what is essentially advertising space, even if it is initially of a somewhat limited nature. Eventually, one runs the risk of taxpayers' funds being used to provide at least a proportion of the private benefit derived by the sponsor. For those four reasons, I urge the Government not to accept the corporate underwriting proposal. I stress that it is in no way critical to the effectiveness of the Dix recommendations. Not implemented, it is a side issue. Implemented, it could be the precursor of a dangerous slide in the professional standards of the ABC.

Let me now turn to the Music Australia proposal. Many people, including the ABC 's Music Advisory Committee, have expressed alarm at the ultimate direction suggested by the Dix Committee for the concert and music activities of the ABC; that is, the eventual transfer of the symphony orchestras to the individual States. They quite rightly worry about the possible dismantling of a national asset, albeit one that is not receiving the kind of attention it should within the present ABC structure. I can understand their worries about the fate of the respective orchestras under these proposals, and also their concern that the organisation of concert tours Australia-wide would become very much more difficult if the orchestras were under individual State control. However, I would urge those holding these views not to oppose the essential first step, and indeed the only definite step recommended by Dix, that is, the formation of an organisational entity to be called Music Australia, under a managing director reporting separately to the Board of the ABC and not under the control of the Director-General.

It seems to me perfectly logical to separate the broadcasting and music organisations, so that each can be given its proper emphasis. An outstanding person can be appointed to head each function. Music Australia can then develop its strength unfettered by a broadcasting organisation struggling to rebuild its standing and morale, yet sheltered by its association with the organisation that gave it birth. Then let events follow their course. Total separation from the ABC could be a future option if that seemed wise; transfer of the orchestras perhaps a distant yet unlikely option.

So I ask those friends of the orchestras and of the tradition of music in the ABC to not, like the present commissioners, reject a thoroughly sensible and desirable reorganisation because of fears of some vague, down-the-line possibilities. I say to the Government: Press ahead with the formation of Music Australia within the ABC framework, let it develop and prosper, but take no further steps without a full public inquiry into music as opposed to broadcasting. There are other matters on which I would like to comment, but in the time available I have had to be selective.

In conclusion, may I urge the Government to invest this historic opportunity with the distinction it deserves. Not since the foundation of public broadcasting in Australia has there been such a moment of decision for this unique national institution. The recent changes to the Broadcasting and Television Act, important as they were, were nonetheless limited to providing a framework for corporate decision-making in broadcasting. In reshaping the ABC the Government is dealing with an organisation for which it has the sole responsibility. It must decide for the whole nation, not just sections of it. It must decide in such a way that in 30 or even 50 years people will look back and say: 'That was a rebirth of national broadcasting and of music in Australia, a transformation of which both sides of this House and this Parliament can be proud.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes this debate on the report of the Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. We believe that the ABC should be politically and financially independent, funded from the public purse and under the scrutiny of a permanent parliamentary watchdog committee. We also believe that the name 'Australian Broadcasting Commission' is synonymous with 50 years of distinguished service to the nation and we would be most unenthusiastic about the proposition to change the name of this instrumentality.

SPEECH.PARA: The Dix Committee report, with its 273 recommendations, is an extremely comprehensive one. It is five volumes in all. It is not only a sound diagnosis of the problems affecting the Australian Broadcasting Commission but also a good basis for the revitalisation of this once great instrumentality. The organisation has, in my view, fallen from its previously exalted standing and status. It has lost some of its self-esteem. There has been the ungainly spectacle of frequent industrial disputes with blackouts of both radio and television. It has previously been innovative, imaginative, enterprising and even inspiring. However, in recent times, sensing the vindictiveness of some sections of this Government, smarting under the Fraser Government Budget cuts and writhing under the corporate carping criticism of some Government members- particularly National Country Party members-the ABC has become sullen and resentful, intimidated and inhibited and in many ways unfulfilled, having regard to its great potential.

The extent of public interest in the ABC has been indicated by the enormous response to the call for submissions. That over 2,220 written comments were received from members of the public, from ABC staff as well as from unions, from the ABC itself and from political and community organisations, is an indication of that widespread interest. That 830 individuals and organisations gave evidence recorded in 5,500 pages of transcript represents a warm community response. In the general conclusions of the report there is this significant statement:
The ABC has become slow moving, overgrown, complacent, and uncertain of the direction in which it is heading despite the efforts of many talented and dedicated people who work for it.
One of the 20 questions asked was:
Should the ABC get more public money?
The report states:

. . . financial problems . . . have gripped . . . public imagination and widespread concern was expressed . . . about the inadequacy of resources available to the ABC. There is no question that money and staff shortages have at times had a detrimental effect on virtually all areas of the ABC in recent years.

I believe the unstable budgetary situation has contributed a great deal to the decline in the standard of performance of this organisation. There can be nothing more important in such a great federation as Australia than to sustain a truly national media and cultural organisation such as the ABC. Adequate government funding is basic to this objective. By this process all Australians can have the benefit of news, entertainment and exposure to cultural experience regardless of where they live and notwithstanding regional profit and loss factors involved in the delivery of such a service.

Of course commercial broadcasting, both radio and television, can certainly not be discounted and must be acknowledged as an effective co-partner in fulfilling this national obligation. The ABC must be afforded the opportunity to maintain its dignity as an equal partner with the commercial media. There must be no concession which would have the effect of relegating the ABC to catering for cultural minorities while hiving off mass broadcasting as the exclusive prerogative of the private sector. The ABC will have to unburden itself of its low audience acceptance mentality, which has eroded staff morale and undermined public condifence. This instrumentality must see itself as wearing many clothes. It must wear the garb of a quality broadcaster with an orientation to mass audience appeal.
Senator Button, the shadow Minister for Communications, said in his publication 'The ABC After Dix':
The true role of the ABC must be truly comprehensive-it is about serving specialised interests, at a high standard, and competing for audiences in 'mass' entertainment of the highest quality.

Equally important is the fact that Senator Button has committed a future Labor government to the objective of securing parliamentary endorsement for a definitive statement, clearly identifying such a role for the ABC. While the Dix Committee has proposed that the ABC statutory body should be replaced by a national broadcasting organisation, my Party would prefer to retain the title ' Australian Broadcasting Commission', as I previously mentioned.

Let me refer to the proposal about the Board. We accept that a board of seven people should be drawn from areas of appropriate expertise. We are not at variance with this proposal. Areas of speciality should include broadcasting and communications and cultural, technical, financial and managerial skills and expertise of that type. I want to say a few words with respect to the proposal to establish a national broadcasting consultative council. The Dix report proposes that such a council should be established and that it should be made up of 20 members. The Opposition takes the view that that would be an over- competitive arrangement and that it would even prove to be troublesome and negative. We believe that it would be an unwieldy organisation. As an alternative, we propose that commissioners should be assisted to maintain public contact with the community at large rather than have to depend on an intermediate consultative or advisory committee. Our alternative proposal includes the suggestion that we should provide each commissioner with professional assistance independent of management so that that professional assistance could be deployed in a special area of interest which the commissioner would seek to pursue.

The Opposition accepts the concept that there should be an advisory secretariat . The Opposition believes it should report, however, not to the Chairman but to the Commission as a whole. It should not be allowed to assume dominative proportions nor should it assume a subordinative role to the Director-General, forever toeing the line and distinguished more by sycophant acquiescence than positive contributions. The Opposition would want that secretariat to be made up of non-career members of the Commission staff with allegiance to the Commission rather than to the Chairman of the Commission or the Director-General. The secretariat should be limited to about 12 members, with appointments being made on a dual basis by the Commission itself and each commissioner making one nomination to the secretariat.

I should like to refer to the appointment of commissioners. Partisan appointments to the Australian Broadcasting Commission under successive governments have been criticised over the years. In an attempt to redress the practice of partisan appointments my party proposes that a parliamentary committee, a watchdog committee, be given the task of calling applications and making recommendations for appointments to the Minister. By this process the Minister of the day would ensure that his nomination would be submitted and supported, no doubt, by government members who would comprise the committee majority. This process would cause the Minister to refrain from making a nomination on purely political grounds. I believe the process would afford an opportunity to the Opposition to question the nominee and thus, in all likelihood, to concur with an appropriate nomination. It would be a process of sorting out unsuitable nominations.

I refer now to the question of management and staff. The entire question of management and staff is inseparably interlocked. Often today's management is little more than the junior appointees of yesteryear who have served time in the interim. The unrelenting transmission of status quo thinking is often characteristic of large corporations-both public and private. The enterprising are often the vulnerable. This produces a climate unconducive to dissent, initiative, individualism and creativity. They are the qualities that are so important to replenish ABC vitality. The atmosphere of mutuality, a kind of corporate spirit, pervades the organisation with its old boy network and obligation to uphold the system at all costs. So far as the appointment of the General Manager is concerned, the recommendation of the Committee that the board rather than the Government should appoint the Director-General has the support of the Opposition. In my view it would be unwise for the Government to flout this good advice.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —The seven-year term for the ABC Board proposed by the Dix Committee should be supported on the basis that a seven-year unrenewable appointment would break the old-boy network syndrome and provide for a periodic infusion of new blood. This may produce some unavoidable casualties, including people who are innovators and are creative. However, there is no shortage of skilled personnel and the authority can engage in body-snatching, if you like, for competitors both in and out of Australia and from both the public and private sector. By this process the top 30 positions could be the pick of the industry, cross fertilised into kindred interests and organisations. The ABC has a great deal to benefit from this process.

SPEECH.PARA: On the matter of funding, the Opposition accepts unequivocally the recommendation that the greater part of the ABC budget should come from parliamentary appropriation and that licence fees should not be reintroduced. We reject proposals for commercialisation of the ABC, including corporate underwriting. We would not want to see the independence of the ABC threatened in any way by the need to consider the attitude of sponsors. Journalists and program makers should not have to look over their shoulders, inhibited by the prospects of offending a sponsor. To have one broadcaster free of such handicaps is little enough to ask, and therein lies the main virtue of Australia's dual system-the system of private participators on the one hand and a public participator on the other.

Already enough scope exists for advertising. Everything the ABC does is paid for and the only fair and equitable way financially to sustain the organisation is by the proceeds of uniform taxation. In any case, high costs in advertising exclude small businesses and even though it is said that ABC viewers constitute a Mercedes market, if that is true there might also be a group-I think there is a large group-which prefers the ABC because it does not have advertisements. Although only $5m a year out of the Budget of $250m is to be raised, governments would always be under pressure to lift the amount.

There are many other matters that I will not have time to talk about. I would have liked to talk about the ABC being the main innovator and initiator in respect of translator and transmitter services. It takes the initiative, both for itself and for the private sector. I certainly would have liked to talk about the need to retain the ABC news service. There is a proposal to draw on the facilities of other news services. The ABC could ultimately lose its independent news service. In this respect, the Commissioner said:

In these times of financial restraint and staff ceilings, the ABC could be forced to meet a reduction in resources by cutting back on its own news gathering activities which ultimately could result in only one source of news in Australia.

I regard these proposals as most significant. I believe that the most important thing is to ensure that the independence of the ABC is preserved. As far as news services are concerned, as far as dependence on sponsors is concerned, to resort to any of the recommendations to any degree would, in my view and in the view of the Opposition, prove in the end to be a retrograde step.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKenzie Mr A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to participate tonight in the debate on the review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, a review which I believe was most comprehensive and undertaken most painstakingly by Mr Alex Dix, Alex Castles, Pat Lovell and Brian Sweeney. The Committee was established in 1979 by Mr Staley when he was Minister for Communications. That was at a time when, as chairman of the back bench committee on communications, I was involved in this area. At that time there was considerable discussion about the need for such a review.

SPEECH.PARA: The ABC, to my knowledge, had not been subjected to such an independent, impartial and professional review in its 50 years of existence. Indeed, some concern was expressed by the Government, and I believe also by the Opposition, about the efficiency of the Commission and the efficacy of some of its procedures and administrative processes. It was for these reasons and others that the Committee of Review was established. I have found a perusal of the summary report and also sections of the major report most interesting. It is interesting to note that the ABC and the Sydney Harbour Bridge are both 50 years old this year. I think that the ABC has come in for considerable criticism and examination, much more so than the Sydney Harbour Bridge.

TALK.START.PARA: —The bridge is in better shape.

—The bridge perhaps is in better shape, although I notice that the New South Wales Labor Premier will soon have to increase the tolls to cover the cost of maintaining the bridge. The Committee was not at all reticent in being very frank about its findings of what might be called the approaching senility, or perhaps more unkindly the self-perpetuating inertia, which is seen in some sectors of the ABC. If listeners doubt that, I read from certain sections of the summary report, in which the Committee stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The ABC is now nearly fifty years old, and in the last decade its record has faltered.

It has stood on its dignity and independence when pressing priorities cried out for attention. It has tried to maintain an idea of Australian society after that idea has undergone change. Its energies have been sapped by often bitter industrial conflict. It has not only slipped from the forefront of change but threatens to be eclipsed by it. The ABC has become slow moving, overgrown, complacent, and uncertain of the directon in which it is heading despite the efforts of many talented and dedicated people who work for it.

The Dix Committee, having said that, went on to examine some of the specific areas in which it saw problems. It first of all questioned some of the assumptions. I think we heard mention of one of those tonight when the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Les Johnson), who spoke before me in this debate, said that the ABC catered for a Mercedes market. He was referring to the widely held view that the ABC is elitist and that it provides only programs which are readily accepted by minority groups within the community. The Dix report has pointed out that this is not the case. In fact, only 7 per cent of the community does not at some stage tune in to the ABC. Indeed, 93 per cent turn to it selectively for programs, particularly those on current affairs and news. The normal indication of popularity used by the television industry, the ratings system, does not take into account the frequency with which people turn to a particular radio or television medium. On that basis the ABC does provide a dominance of quality programs, particularly news and information programs.

The Committee went on to examine some areas in which it believed the performance of the ABC had declined. I am particularly interested and gratified to see that the first-mentioned area is the ABC's performance in relation to non -metropolitan audiences. That is the first of the committee's findings. It points out that there are inadequacies in the service to country and outback people. I will come back to that in a few minutes. The second point the Committee made was that the ABC, in broadcasting for the whole Australian community, fails to reflect certain realities of Australian society, particularly contemporary Australian society, when it does not adequately fulfil the needs of non-Anglo-Saxon Australians and Aboriginal Australians. The Committee believes that the ABC's performance may have declined in that it has been over-emphasising overseas programs, particularly British popular programs, and that this may have been at the expense of Australian-produced programs.

The final point the Committee made is again one that interests me. The Committee believes that the ABC has failed to use effectively its decentralised resources in the States and the regions and thus has not as adequately as it may have reflected the interests, characteristics and concerns of the whole country, with particular reference to those who live outside the major metropolitan complexes.

Perhaps I should return to the point of the adequacy of the ABC broadcasting in non-metropolitan areas. I was interested in a submission from the Northern Territory Government which drew attention to the narrow range of national radio and television services available in the Territory and the need, with the Territory's economic and political development towards separate statehood, for a similar situation to be enjoyed by the Territory as is enjoyed by the other States. The Territory's submission put the highest priority in planning for the ABC's development on this matter. The Dix Committee again drew attention to this . It recommended strongly that a second regional network be developed. There would be many people in country Australia who would agree wholeheartedly with that.

The Committee also recommended that the high quality frequency modulation stereo services be extended to country areas. It did not suggest by any means that the extension of FM stereo services to rural areas should in any way diminish the priority attached to the establishment of a second regional network and the concept of localism or regionalism within the ABC. But there should not be any reason why country listeners and viewers should be denied the opportunity of enjoying some of the better quality high fidelity broadcasts that are available to their metropolitan counterparts who enjoy ready access to high quality live concerts, jazz programs, folk programs, drama and whatever. I support the Committee wholeheartedly on that issue.

On the issue of decentralisation, the Committee suggested that the States and regions should have a firmer place in the ABC organisation and in its broadcast output. I point out that the regional offices of the ABC vary widely in their facilities and staffing. For example, it is interesting to note that the ABC station in my area-2CR Orange-has five staff to service a population of 260,000, which is approximatley 58,000 people per staff member. By comparison, other centres with an ABC regional station and office are much better off. For example , Albury has one staff member per 36,000 people; Tamworth has one staff member per 32,000 people; Toowoomba has one staff member per 36,000 people; Broken Hill has one staff member per 10,000 people; and Cairns has one staff member per 13, 000 people. Darwin has one staff member per 2,000 listening audience. Obviously special circumstances apply in Darwin. Nevertheless, at present it would seem that the office in Orange is one of the more disadvantaged as far as staffing is concerned.

I would like to make some comments on the most controversial aspect of the Committee's report, which relates to corporate underwriting or the general principle of whether the ABC should accept advertising in some form. The Opposition and other groups are firmly opposed to this concept, although I think there has been quite a bit of confusion as to what the concept would involve. It would not mean that advertising would interrupt programs, as it currently does on commercial television and radio. A process of sponsorship would simply mean credits at the beginning or the end of a program. That may be a pointer for the commercial television industry because most viewers, I believe, are frustrated and disenchanted with the frequent interruptions that occur during television programs, often with a repeat of the advertisement that people have seen only a few minutes earlier. The commercial television industry, which has opposed the idea of corporate sponsorship or underwriting for the ABC, may well look to its own area and may well find that its ratings go up if it does not have continual interruptions to its programs, with slots of commercials and advertising segments.

The Committee has pointed out that any income from corporate sponsorship or underwriting should not be offset against the ABC's parliamentary appropriation. I would agree with that in principle. Nevertheless, that would be affected by the amount of revenue that the ABC could gain by entering into corporate sponsorship. I believe that many furphies have been raised over this issue as proposed, accepting the fact that the Committee has recommended very strongly that there be strict guidelines and that clear-cut principles be followed. The idea of corporate sponsorship is not as horrific as has been portrayed by the Opposition and by other groups, such as Friends of the ABC.

The Dix Committee paid some attention, albeit briefly, to the concept of the televising of parliamentary proceedings. We know, of course, that the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings is required under legislation and that it must be carried out by the ABC. No such legislation is applicable to the televising of parliamentary proceedings. I refer the House to the report of the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings, which was brought down in 1974. Incidentally, that report has not yet been debated in either this chamber or the upper House. That Committee looked very carefully at the pros and cons of televising a portion of the proceedings of Federal Parliament. It is interesting to note that 80 per cent of the submissions received on that subject were generally in favour of the televising of proceedings.
