The frequency of the arguments that were brought forward with the submissions were as follows: Firstly, that the public should have the right to know more about the day-to-day business of parliament and be able to have a better understanding of parliamentary procedures. Secondly, that the televising of the proceedings should reduce the communications gap between parliament and the people, enable people to participate more directly in the political process and also eliminate possible selectivity in the media. We have seen for so long that what happens in this place is portrayed to the public, except through direct radio broadcasts, through the eyes of commentators and journalists. That is one of the reasons why the televising of parliamentary proceedings was introduced in Canada. The Speaker of the Canadian Senate, Madame Lapointe, said:

One of the most effective arguments heard in Canada from televising Parliament' s business was that the time had come to take Parliament to the people. Far too long its debates and crises had been filtered through the mouths and eyes of others. Not all those others were impartial, detached or objective observers.

I can assure the House that the televising of parliamentary proceedings in Canada has been extremely successful. It has been introduced into the United States. Some 20 countries now televise in some form a portion of their parliamentary proceedings. I feel the Dix Committee should have addressed itself a little more energetically to that question. In conclusion, I believe the Committee has conducted a very useful review. I congratulate the members of the Committee for their most comprehensive and professional review. I recommend to the Government those recommendations from the Committee that apply particularly to non-metropolitan viewers and listeners.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission-the Dix Committee -is a very good and comprehensive report. The report in front of us tonight, which is the main report, constitutes nearly 1,000 pages. It has 273 recommendations. It has probably been one of the most comprehensive reports to the Parliament on the Australian Broadcasting Commission. However, I might say at the beginning that one wonders about some of the recommendations as various newspapers reports during the inquiry had Mr Dix going to the Government and asking whether, in fact, certain recommendations the Committee wished to bring down would be acceptable to the Government and if they were unacceptable they were not pursued .

SPEECH.PARA: The only way in which the Australian Broadcasting Commission will have an effective overall restructure, if that is required, is by a complete independent inquiry. I do not believe that the Committee did itself justice in that regard. I do not believe that an independent inquiry into a subject that is as comprehensive as this should be seen to be evaluating the Government's attitudes on particular issues. The Committee would have had awful egg on its face had there been a change of government and attitudes. That criticism of the Committee I would like to put at the beginning of my speech, as I think that it has marred several recommendations, not least of all the corporate sponsorship recommendations, and while it was also recommended by the ABC, in its submission -which completely astounds me-one would have thought that such a recommendation from the Committee would obviously have been approved by a conservative government.

But what would that recommendation have been if we had had a federal Labor government? Would we have seen the reverse situation occur? Questions such as this must arise, if we are to believe Press reports-which I believe are accurate -that on occasions the Dix Committee sounded out the Government on some of the possible recommendations and thoughts that it had throughout the inquiry.

Now, first things first: Perhaps I may make a few points in regard to some of the recommendations. The recommendation of changing the name from the Australian Broacasting Commission to the National Broadcasting Organisation I find a little peculiar. I do not really see any reason. No good reason is put forward by the Committee for that recommendation, and therefore I reject it. I think that 50 years of broadcasting under the name of ABC is enough reason in itself to keep that name. Therefore, I sincerely hope that we have an ABC-that is, the Australian Broadcasting Commission-for a long time to come.

The operation and structure of management are possibly one of the biggest areas in this report and one of the most comprehensive recommendations-and controversial. The Committee has recommended a three-tiered management, of a board of directors-which is now the Commission-a consultative council of about 20 members, and State and regional committees. I believe that the set of proposals put forward by the Committee is a little too cumbersome. I do not think that we should be increasing management; if anything, we should be decreasing it. The problems in the program areas will not be solved by an increase of committees and bureaucracy. However, no matter what set of proposals we finish up with-and I am not wedded to any particular proposal-the Commission and commissioners should be backed up by a secretariat. This is one point that has become increasingly clear in debate on these recommendations outside Parliament. An independent secretariat of a high professional ability in the broadcasting industry would be a great strength behind the Commission. Perhaps I may say at this point that the directors or commissioners should know the industry, whether or not they be business people, and they should be people who have experience in the industry. That is a very important part of the future of the ABC.

I agree with the ABC in its response to the Dix recommendations that it needs an upgrading of the present committees with advice coming through to the Commission and to the secretariat. As one who spent 16 years in the industry, to my mind the recommendation that the consultative council and the committees should preview Australian Broadcasting Commission programs in pilot form and productions from other sources before purchase is ludicrous. The ABC used the word 'impractical'. However, I should have thought that it would have been a rather nice way of putting it. I just do not think that it is a viable proposition in any way, shape or form. In my experience in the industry, the more people involved in previewing and reviewing particular programs, the worse the final result usually finishes up.

In the entertainment and broadcasting industry, which is what the ABC is in, one usually finds many cooks who like to have a finger in the pie. Unfortunately not all of them really know what they are talking about. The whole object in the entertainment and broadcasting industry, as the commercial people have found out , is to get good people, and really one good person is worth a thousand others who really do not know about the industry. If we build ourselves sets of committees and councils involving several hundred people, many of those people will not be expert in the industry, and many of those people will have a very narrow sectional interest. Generally speaking, this will not add a great deal to the ABC's genuine output and quality of output in any way.

Appointments to the Commission have always been a bone of contention with many people considering that political appointments were being made by successive governments to the detriment of the Commission. Obviously, the method of appointment must be looked at, and this is where I disagree with the Committee. An alternative method must be found. I think that the only solution is a joint parliamentary committee, possibly one emanating from the House of Representatives. My thoughts in this matter are that there should be six members of the Committee-three from the Government and three from the Opposition, with the chairman, who would be a Government member, having a casting as well as a deliberative vote. However, this Committee should not hold public inquiries. It should operate more or less like the existing House of Representatives committees such as the Standing Committee on Expenditure and the Joint Standing Committee of Public Accounts, by which subjects are investigated and recommendations are then reported to the Parliament. It is a lot to ask a person to nominate for a job as a commissioner or to take a post on the board of directors and then put him or her through the grill of a public hearing, at which some people, including members of this Parliament, are likely to grandstand in order to score a few political points.

The corporate sponsorship area is the one that is probably the most controversial and, as I said earlier, I am surprised that the ABC has in fact recommended it in its submission to the inquiry. The recommendation is rejected by me on the grounds that it must impair the impartiality of the Commission. This is where I agree with one member, at least, from the Government side-the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton). While we may have plain sailing for a few years, it must be evident to everyone that somewhere along the track the ABC must be compromised. If the ABC is terribly successful in attracting corporate sponsorship-and it may be; there may be $20m or $30m coming into the bickie tin-somewhere along the track a government, of no matter what political persuasion, will be seriously tempted, in a tight budgetary situation, to say: ' Well, there is only so much cake available and we need that $20m or $30m to go into some other area, such as pensions, and, because the ABC estimates that it will receive that money from corporate sponsorship this year, we shall lop that same amount off the normal appropriation funds for the ABC.' That must happen. It is just a matter of practical application, and I think that we are kidding ourselves, the Committee members were kidding themselves, and the ABC, too, if we all think that that will not happen.

The other thought that comes to mind in the corporate sponsorship recommendation is the possibility that the ABC may find itself compromised in the program context. Again, we have seen that the ABC will bring corporate sponsorship only into areas of non-political shows, such as orchestral tours and musical tours, operatic tours or something of that ilk. However, there is raised the possibility again that, if particular companies are pouring a lot of money into an orchestral tour, they may well say to the ABC: 'Look, we will pour that money and more into next year's tour so that it will be bigger and better than ever. However, we would like a favour in another area.' There seems to be a simplistic view that corporate sponsorship and the sponsors thereof can influence only the area in which they are sponsoring. Of course, that is not true. Because someone is sponsoring one area, that does not mean that the screws cannot be put on in another area, and I believe that the ABC will rue the day when it recommended corporate sponsorship to be a part of the ABC in the future. I reject that recommendation of the Committee and I sincerely hope that the Government does not act in kind, because if any government is going to compromise the ABC, it will be this particular Government.

There are, of course, many other aspects of this report that one could mention, such as programs. There is an excellent comprehensive chapter on programs, but that will obviously have to wait for another speech. The recommendation for a second radio network is fully supported. On industrial relations, I believe that cutting the ties with the Public Service Board is a very good idea, and I fully support that recommendation. In fact, I would be monitoring that over a number of years as an attempt to loosen up the public servant and bureaucratic ties. I think that the ABC must function in a broadcasting and entertainment industry rather than in a Public Service atmosphere. I seek leave, Mr Deputy Speaker, to incorporate in Hansard a section from page 645 of the main report, paragraph 22. 196, which succinctly puts my thoughts and the Committee's thoughts on the industrial relations area.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

While linkages between ABC and Public Service pay groups have been established for a great many ABC staff categories, we understand that some linkages are, at best, tenuous. Our industrial relations consultants have provided a detailed breakdown of ABC jobs showing their Public Service alignment. However, they point out that 'this breakdown does not clearly indicate functions', concluding that jobs such as those of Sound Effects staff and Property, Set and Accessory Makers are more closely related to program than to clerical duties, or contain strong artistic components not recognised in a straight-forward linkage with physical trades. Taking into account these inadequacies of categorisation they have concluded that approximately 30 per cent of ABC staff could be classified as clerical/administrative/professional, 10 per cent as physical grades, and 60 per cent as program-related staff. If this assessment is correct then the ABC is more closely aligned to the broadcasting industry than to the Public Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. In many areas, the report fails to make the hard decisions. One wonders what the Government will now do in bringing forward legislation in order to react to this report. One thing is abundantly clear, however. Government funding must increase for the ABC to compete in its own right in the ever-increasing and complex area of broadcasting. Talking of funding, I mention that it is very interesting to note that the last Labor appropriation for the ABC in 1975, in the last year of the Labor Government, was $132.1m. After three years of Fraser Government appropriation, that had risen to $141.5m. That is an increase of a fraction over 7 per cent in three years. I would guess that inflation over those three years would have been around 33 per cent. Against that figure of 33 per cent we have an appropriation increase to the ABC of 7 per cent. That is the scandal of the funding situation brought about by this Government, and this Government must take some of the blame for the position in which the ABC finds itself today.

SPEECH.PARA: However, no ad hoc large increase in funds should occur. I do not believe in throwing money at the ABC, or any organisation. I do not believe that that alone will fix everything. However, a planned increase of funds is required to enable planning over a period of time. If the ABC knows that x amount of money is going to come in from government funds it can sit down and really have no excuses for planning a future and planning a truly national broadcasting organisation that will benefit everyone in Australia, one which will entertain people in the large mass audience area, one which will have general community appeal, one which will entertain people and inform people in news and current affairs programs, in gardening programs, sporting programs and in the sectional interests that we all have.

Another very important subject is that of a second ABC national television channel. That is one area that should be looked at. However, it has to be looked at in the whole context of the broadcasting industry. I think ultimately a second national network, no matter how it is structured, will come into effect. I know money will always be a problem but I think that a second national television network, along the lines of the two national radio networks-with one possibly being more of a general entertainment and one specialising-is inevitable in Australia. People in the regional areas will welcome that, too. It is only a matter of time. Whatever government is in power must look at the possibility of how it is to come about and whether subscription, or pay television of any description, should be part of any future ABC advancement. That is something that will affect not only the ABC but also the entire broadcasting industry and a decision such as that cannot be made in isolation from the commercial section of our industry.

Overall this country has a very good broadcasting make-up with a good, strong commercial industry and an excellent government-funded network running alongside it. We have the best of both worlds. However, at present I believe the ABC and its management are being made scapegoats in certain areas by this Government. That is a deplorable situation. The Dix report is a comprehensive report but it has failed in some areas. However, I do hope that the Government is sincere and honest in its deliberations because changes that are made now will have a telling effect not only on the ABC but also right across the entertainment and broadcasting industry.

Before I close, as I have a minute to spare I revert to the program section of the Dix report. It was a very comprehensive section and many people would have missed some of the submissions put forward by various groups. In particular, I allude to the Australia Council's submission. Whilst some people in the Australia Council may think that they know the industry, some parts of the Australia Council's submission could have been written by a plumber. They really have no comprehension of the media set-up in the area in which the ABC must work . The area to which I specifically allude recommended strongly that the ABC have live and direct broadcasts of events, such as plays, on stage. The Australia Council thought that that was a terrific idea, when in fact any professional in the industry would be able to tell us that one part of the industry cannot be transplanted into another part of the industry and be made to work properly. One cannot transport; that is, one cannot directly televise a play on a stage and make it good television. If one is to put a play on television screens or on film, one must shoot it as such. It must be done in studios and shot as a television play. Some of the submissions put forward by the Australia Council could really be looked at and as a result the Australia Council should have a good look at itself in the future. The Dix report is a good, comprehensive report. I am sorry we did not have twice as long to debate it as we have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission is the result of the most wide-ranging inquiry ever made into the ABC. However many of its recommendations are adopted, it will remain an essential reference work in any discussion of the ABC and of the media in general. Mr Dix and his committee deserve the public congratulations they have received for their work. The sheer physical scale of the inquiry is impressive, with its 831 witnesses and 61 hearings, ending with 276 recommendations. Perhaps more important is the fact that the report has not been afraid to make enemies, or at least critics, which is one test of the honesty of any inquiry. It has criticsed and earned the criticism of management and unions, of the commissioners and of the Public Service Board, and of conservatives and innovators. To the extent that it has deliberately sought support, it has been from what can be called the creative elements in the ABC. Whilst this brings its own difficulties, it is an emphasis that must be welcomed .

SPEECH.PARA: The ABC is one of Australia's great institutions and the vast majority of Australians use it in one way or another. Its news and information services enjoy tremendous standing in the community, as do so many of its other programs, from music and sport to, may I say it, parliamentary broadcasts. It has served the country more than well for about 50 years. Yet, today, the Dix inquiry finds that 'the ABC has become slow moving, overgrown, complacent, and uncertain of the direction in which it is heading'. So it is certainly time for the root-and- branch inquiry of the kind the Dix report gives us. Many of the principal recommendations of the report have already been referred to and discussed. I refer to the proposed structural reorganisation, the tenure proposed for the Chief Executive Officer and the method of appointment, the greater degree of financial accountability, the greater use of contract staff and the adoption of commercial sponsorship of the kind already used by most public broadcasting radio stations.

The part of the report that I want to discuss is the section on bias-political and social bias-in some of the ABC public affairs programs. The issue arises coparatively rarely in news programs, which consequently enjoy a high public standing, as of course do some current affairs programs. I concentrate on this section of the report for two reasons. The first is that bias arouses such widespread anger in the public, and the second is that the report recommends a solution which I do not think is a satisfactory solution at all. I refer to the proposed amalgamation of the news and public affairs departments. I say at once that public complaints about bias are obviously not confined to the ABC. Obviously the same complaint is made about many of the commercial stations' public affairs programs. Nevertheless, the public indignation is greater when or where the public perceives political bias in the ABC. In the commercial stations , investment, profits and losses are matters for the private sector but the 300 to 400 journalists of the ABC are paid by the public which feels cheated when it sees or hears, or believes it sees or hears, distortions caused by political bias or malice. It is not a simple matter and attitudes of listeners and viewers range from those who see no bias at all, to those people, to pick one example, such as Mr Max Harris, the Australian columnist, who belabour the ABC's ' dominant, insistent and tedious bias towards left-wing radicalism'.

The Dix report approaches this question rather gingerly. This is shown by an interesting variation in the two texts of the report-the first one, presented to us when it was first printed, and the final one, delivered later. The variation or alteration in the text occurs in paragraph 10.19 on page 189 of the final text. The first text did not have page numbering. The first text, referring to alleged deliberate distortions of a leftist kind in public affairs programs, said:
There is evidence that the situation does occur.

Most people would agree with that and critics such as Mr Max Harris, and many rank and file members of the Liberal Party, would add that it occurs repeatedly or routinely. In the next edition, on page 189 the text is altered to read:
There is evidence that the situation does occur occasionally.

The adding of one word, the word 'occasionally' of course changes the emphasis entirely, from something that occurs perhaps often to something that occurs rarely. I do not know what meetings, agreements or disagreements led to this small but very significant change in the text between the two versions, but I mention it to indicate the sensitivity-the almost explosive sensitivity-of the issue.

However, there is no doubt that the report acknowledges the problem in the ABC' s public affairs programs. The report gives evidence of bias and plainly rejects the familiar argument that, say, leftist bias in one program is balanced by conservative bias in another. To quote the report:

It seems to us that our society will be better informed and better able to make intelligent progress if ideas are seen to compete with each other, if they are presented within a reasonably short interval of each other, and at similar times of the daily broadcast schedule. We are accordingly unimpressed by arguments that programs giving prominence to committed left-leaning views such as those talks and documentaries sometimes produce are balanced by others produced in other areas, which are sometimes alleged to have a bias the other way.

The report recommends that programs of the Lateline, Broadband, Double Take series become less tedious and more controversial by incorporating disagreements with their dominant radical stance. One would, of course, make the same point if programs were tediously biased the other way.

The report does not analyse how this state of affairs came about. It does not quote from the recent book by the former Deputy General Manager of the ABC, Clement Semmler, on this point. The book is called The ABC-Aunt Sally and Sacred Cow. On page 106, Clement Semmler writes:

In the last ten years there has been tremendous pressure to enter ABC broadcasting-especially in the glamour area of public affairs broadcasting; hundreds of applications are received for a single vacancy. This has meant the aggregation of lively and independent-minded young people, in a social climate where there has been a rapidly changing standard of behaviour and morality, both personal and public. And at the heart of all this is the fact that, for all the variety of views and opinions among these young producers, editors and reporters , there is a kind of consensus, a pool of shared social and political assumptions, which on many subjects-abortion, divorce, censorship, drugs, immigration, promiscuity, the environment, war, capital punishment, penal policy , capitalism, education, social legislation-are at the best, partisan opinions, and at worst, the opinions of a small educated middle-class left-wing minority.

These lively spirits are entitled to their ideas and to their Labor Party prejudices, but in broadcasting the public is entitled to professional reporting and not partisan propaganda, otherwise these lively spirits simply reinforce what Brian Hogben said in his recent Paton-Wilkie-Deamer Memorial Lecture at the Journalists Club in Sydney. Mr Hogben is a former editor of the Daily Mirror and is now Group General Manager, Editorial, of News Ltd. Referring specifically to the Press, but in fact to the media in general, he said:

It boils down to this: For all too many years a handful of us has been endangering the freedom of the Press by abusing it, and lowering the prestige of the profession by cuckolding it. We're approaching a point at which people will wonder seriously if we're worth preserving.

The Dix report confronts this problem. It espouses the principle adopted by the Annan Committee in Great Britain of 'due impartiality' in all public affairs programs. 'Due impartiality' is much the same as balance but the principle of balance can sometimes be applied in a mechanical way. We are all familiar with that device. Sometimes a sensationally false allegation is reported without any real inquiry into it or judgment on it and then at the end, for balance, there is a denial. Due impartiality on the other hand requires the reporter to exercise judgment and sensitivity and not just to report mindlessly or perhaps maliciously. To encourage this sort of professionalism, the report makes two major recommendations. The first is an increased emphasis on professional training, firm policy guidelines and effective supervision. The second is the gradual amalgamation of the news division and the public affairs department, a recommendation supported, incidentally, by the Australian Journalists Association.

The first recommendation is obviously desirable. The second is controversial and I find myself opposed to it. The first recommendation is the real step ahead . Professional training to minimise knee-jerk bias, to encourage due impartiality and the exercise of judgment, to raise standards-this is what the public affairs programs need. It will not come cheaply and will make a dent in the Budget, but it would be money well spent to overcome the most serious weakness in this side of the ABC's performance. When due impartiality is achieved, it may be time to consider amalgamating news and public affairs. 'It may be', I say. To do so at the moment could be defended in terms of economies, cost control and the avoidance of duplication of staff and equipment. But otherwise it would be mixing traditions in unproductive tension.

News stands in the tough professional tradition of objective reporting and commands almost universal respect and trust for that reason. Public affairs, despite some real achievements from time to time, is too often a matter of prejudiced advocacy. Amalgamation at this stage would dilute news and not change public affairs advocacy. Amalgamation seems to me an attempt at a mechanical solution to a professional or intellectual problem. I would go further and say that even when public affairs broadcasting is improved, there is a case for keeping the two departments separate, even if a closer association could be useful, as it was for a time in the British Broadcasting Corporation when both departments, while separate, came under the one head, although even that position has now been abolished.

In short, I believe the ABC is going to have its hands full attempting to establish due impartiality, professional standards and professional training in public affairs without also carrying the strains and tensions of amalgamating that department with News. The Dix report has significantly advanced discussion of the problem of bias in ABC programs but I believe the Commission should carefully examine the proposal for amalgamation and, I hope, reject it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that when this Government grabbed power in 1975 one of its more determined aims was to weaken the independence and influence of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. Whilst there is also no doubt as to the comprehensive nature of the voluminous report of the Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission and the value of its overview of activities and problems, there is also no doubt regarding the conservatism of the Committee members. The Federal Government ensured that the recommendations contained in the report would be acceptable to it by ensuring that the Committee members were sympathetic to the Government aim of making the ABC a clone of the existing commercial television and radio stations. How else, for example, can one view the recommendations regarding the corporate underwriting of television programs? Incidentally, the fact that the ABC commissioners, in their comments on the report, have suggested that corporate underwriting be extended to radio programs, is a clear indication to me of the commissioners' affinity with the Federal Government's views on the ABC.

SPEECH.PARA: The commissioners are supposed to have the best interests of the ABC and the listening and viewing public at heart. Yet they have aided and abetted the deliberate winding down of any programs which appear to criticise the Government or to indicate that there is something terribly wrong with the grossly materialistic and self-seeking nature of the social and political system in Australia. It is commendable that in the area of funding the Dix Committee recommended against the reintroduction of licence fees but it is particularly regrettable that the Committee recommended the corporate underwriting of ABC programs. Corporate underwriting would mean a complete loss of professional independence for program makers and would inevitably result in direct political interference with the content of ABC programs.

Some observers have stated that the attitudes of Committee members, commissioners and the Government in relation to corporate underwriting are naive . I go much further as I contend that it is a deliberate manoeuvre to undermine the integrity and independence of the ABC. Indeed, the commissioners went further in their own response to the Dix report as their suggestion was that corporate underwriting should be extended to radio. They made the additional comment that they did not believe that all information programs should be excluded. I cannot believe that the commissioners' attitudes on these matters can be seen as naive. I believe that it is their intention, acting as the Federal Government's representatives, to ensure that the public will eventually withdraw all support for the ABC as a public broadcaster. Their final support for the Committee's recommendations that revenue attracted through corporate underwriting should not be offset against the ABC's parliamenary appropriation makes pathetic reading when one considers their support of recent savage staff cuts.

The new Chairman of the ABC, Professor Leonie Kramer, apparently favours the definition of herself as a radical conservative. Presumably radical conservatism in relation to public broadcasting means cutting back on radical programs and ensuring that radical staff members leave the ABC. The ABC has experienced such a debilitating loss of technical and professional staff that it is a wonder that many of its programs are able to go to air at all. Many technical and professional services are performed by contract labour because the permanent staff is insufficient to cope with program schedules. The consequence of this short-sighted staffing policy is that services cost three to four times as much as services performed by permanent staff.

The Chairman of the ABC has stated that staff cuts are obtained by natural wastage, by not replacing people who retire. Such a statement does not accord with the fact that many of the professional staff have resigned because of sheer disgust with the political interference they have experienced in the presentation of news and current affairs programs. For example, programs such as Nationwide and Four Corners are now but a shadow of their former glory. Again it should be noted that Professor Kramer has been reported as saying that she is opposed to divisiveness and combative talk and that she wants an end to this style of confrontation. It would appear that what she wants is broadcasting of the worst possible kind, which consists of sickly sweet, saccharine type programs which assure everybody that all is right with Australia provided we all accept conservative philosophies and do not waste any time in discussing alternative and opposite views.
I will give an example from the Friends of the ABC Committee of the sorts of things that occur with corporate underwriting. The Committee's Press release states:

If a corporation sponsoring a costly TV program takes offence at another ABC program, seen as inimical to its interests and image, a corporation executive may quietly intimate to the right person in the ABC that company patronage will not continue unless the offending program be withdrawn or modified. A financially weakened ABC would find such pressure difficult to withstand. Programs like Doubletake, Background Briefing, Nationwide and Four Corners would be at risk here. Corporations have little taste for controversy and are very sensitive about image. This is what they are out to sell.
The nervous self censorship that already operates within the ABC would become more oppressive if the Commission were beholden to both Government and Business for financial favours.

That was stated by the Friends of the ABC Committee. Recently Senator Button published his response to the Dix Committee's report. Several weeks ago on Nationwide Professor Kramer said, in response to Senator Button's comments, that the criticisms of ABC management were unspecific and undocumented. I will give four examples of inept management which will prove that Professor Kramer was not up-to-date in her information. First of all, some four weeks ago, TV Entertainment was set to produce a one-hour music and variety special to be called The Mike Batt Show. Mike Batt is an English entertainer who is principally a composer and who conducts his pieces and occasionally sings. His wife and daughter also periodically appear on stage with him. Mr Batt was hired by the ABC to fly to Australia to star in the special. Sets were designed and built. Costumes were designed and fabricated. An orchestra and dancers were employed. Choreography was done. All the usual preparations were undertaken. But come the day to record, with the entire cast plus star poised to perform in the Gore Hill studios and the tape about to roll for recording, the show was cancelled. The reason was that TV Entertainment had failed to seek permission from Actors Equity for a foreign star to perform on Australian soil. The whole thing fell through seconds before it would have become a reality.

I will give another example. The New South Wales programs department is responsible for the Andi Ross Show, which goes out each afternoon in New South Wales on Radio 1 and Radio 3. Recently Andi did her show when Parliament was being broadcast over Radio 1. This meant that she would only be heard by country listeners on Radio 3. But, unknown to Andi Ross or New South Wales programs, most, in fact all, of the regional stations decided to take the opportunity to go local. Andi Ross's voice and records were getting no further than the Forbes Street switch room. Nobody told her. For some days she continued to broadcast to herself.

I will give a third example. As is well documented in past Press reports, in 1981 industrial relations in the radio public affairs section at head office had become so bad that an industrial psychologist was appointed by senior management to try to improve the situation. The result was an increasing flow of employees, mainly journalists, to commercial television programs and commercial radio, particularly 2GB.

Possibly the best example of incompetence was the recent publicity given to the fact that a generous bequest left to the ABC by a long time listener to ABC drama has never been taken up by the organisation. The amount is $200,000 and it was left quite legally to the ABC by this now defunct benefactor. There was absolutely no reason why this bequest could not have been processed in the normal legal way. The benefactor's solicitors, in a number of letters to the legal department, pleaded for the ABC to take some action but none was taken. Even a letter to the General Manager and the subsequent Press publicity still has not elicited a response from the ABC of any likely action. All this has occurred at a time when the ABC is desperate for cash and at a time when the drama department in particular is being starved of funds.

I have given four specific examples for Professor Kramer's consideration. We had a perfect example in the Parliament today of what would happen if the ABC were subject to corporate underwriting. The announcement that the Government is to spend $100,000 of a total of $300,000 on advertising its recent housing policy package in Victoria obviously requires exposure as a blatant piece of electioneering for the Liberal Party's election campaign in Victoria. Corporate underwriting would ensure that newscasters and political commentators on radio and television would be effectively prevented from making comments on such an inflammatory subject. Such commentary could do irreparable harm to a government which ensures that business corporations get the lion's share of concessions and subsidies at the expense of the average taxpayer.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it won't change the result of the election.

—That is quite correct, as the honourable member said. For corporations underwriting the ABC programs, such broadcasting would be totally against their interests. ABC Commissioners, fearing a cessation of corporate funding, would ensure that such critical political commentaries were not made. It has been suggested that corporate sponsorship would raise about $5m to $10m. It seems nonsensical to risk the independence of a great institution such as the ABC for what would be a paltry sum in comparison with the total budget of $220m. The Friends of the ABC Committee, in one of its publications, has given a number of macabre examples. One example is cited in Brik Barnouw's book The Sponsors 1978 in which a natural gas company sponsored a drama series, including a play based on the Nuremberg trials, and insisted that any reference to gas as the killing agent in the death chambers be deleted. Of course, there is also the example of the well-known multinational organisation Proctor and Gamble which insisted that any program it sponsored would contain no material that would give offence either directly or by inference to any commercial organisation of any sort.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members on this side of the House support the proposition that non- renewable contracts should be extended to all senior officers, except the Director-General, in the ABC. Such officers should, however, be eligible for reappointment after a thorough and wide-ranging review of their services. The proposal of the Dix Committee that the term of the Director-General should be a non-renewable seven-year term should be supported as it would ensure that the appointee has the opportunity to carry through to a conclusion innovative processes while allowing the opportunity after the seven-year period for a fresh approach from a new appointee. As indicated previously, the present Commissioners reflect too closely the aims and attitudes of the present Government and this is inevitable when the appointments are made by the Government. It is essential that there be at the very least a bipartisan approach to such appointments which should be subject to recommendations from a joint parliamentary committee. I have a personal preference for the reinstatement of a staff elected Commissioner who, as has been pointed out by other critics of the Dix report, can bring the much needed experience of a professional broadcaster to the services provided by the Commission. Apart from this valuable function, the staff- elected commissioner also serves the vital function of representing the interests of the staff on the Commission.

In more enlightened societies, it is an elementary requirement of industrial democracy that workers' representatives be present on the boards or commissions which govern institutions and corporations. The only argument is usually about how many representatives workers should have and the type of reporting procedures that is to be adopted by them. The present Government does not believe in industrial democracy. Therefore, it very quickly ensured that the staff-elected commissioner was not replaced and the position was extinguished.

In conclusion, while there are many other observations that I could make about the ABC, I emphasise that I consider it to be one of Australia's great institutions. The Government has aided in its decline over the past six years but it should not be allowed to decline further. The defects in the Commission which I have mentioned, particularly the effects of government policy, must not be allowed to destroy the integrity and talent of broadcasters, producers and production staff. The decline in the ABC is of major concern to the Australian people. Steps must be taken by the Government to improve the structure of the organisation, as has been suggested by honourable members on this side of the House, and provide suitable funding so that the standards and quality of ABC programs can be restored to a level that will no longer cause concern to the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On such occasions as I am able, I watch or listen to Australian Broadcasting Commission programs as a matter of choice. This may be the result of 20 years of my life when I had no choice. However, I wish to be recorded as a supporter of the Commission. The Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission has covered many aspects of the circumstances which affect the operations of the ABC. It considers programming, independence, staff morale, financing, advertising and the Commission's leader. Such debate is really academic to those who occupy the eastern and south-eastern regions of the electorate of O'Connor, an area which is about one-third the size of Victoria. All they require is the opportunity to view an ABC transmission, warts and all. They receive no television transmission and, quite often, an inadequate broadcasting service.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation becomes even more astounding when one realises that some of these people reside within 200 miles of Perth. As a long-term resident of the more remote areas, I have often pondered upon the incongruity of the national broadcasting network's choice of the most densely populated areas for the introduction of new and additional services. This government-funded service has too often been seen as having principally the role of providing competition for the commercial stations of Australia. In the cities it competes in an area in which private enterprise is both willing and able to provide all types and levels of entertainment that the public demand. Therefore, it is not surprising that, in this area of massive competition for public leisure activity, the ABC has limited support.

Consequently, I turn to sections 18 to 21 of the recommendations of the Committee, which are addressed to the responsibilities of the ABC to rural areas . I am gratifited that, through initiatives of this Government, we are fast approaching a time when the availability of television and radio will become universal, and the right of all citizens of Australia. Included in those initiatives was the policy of allowing local communities to erect national translator stations to service their local areas. This policy has already borne fruit in my electorate. The residents of Hawick and Cordinup in the shire of Esperance have already funded their translator. The possibility this option raises is that, when satellite transmission becomes available, many rural communities will find it less costly to erect a single dish aerial and translate the program so received by means of a low-cost transmitter. The total cost for a superior signal would be less than the individual purchase price of a large number of private dish aerials. However, those remote area dwellers, whose personal entertainment is severely restricted, are still confronted with the need to find substantial sums from personal finances in order to provide themselves with a service that is enjoyed by most Australians without cost. It represents yet another tax on decentralisation and I trust that at least long term planning will provide for the refunding of expenditures of this nature.

The other great difficulty in this area is the time and difficulty involved in obtaining such a licence. Although I recognise some of the difficulties in relation to the numerous applications that have been received, I feel that priority should be given to remote area dwellers. Their very remoteness should remove a lot of the difficulties, such as frequency allocation, which are involved. Most importantly, they are people who have no television service and probably very little else in terms of public entertainment. The further planning for the very best means of delivering the ABC program to these remote areas immediately the satellite is in place should be given priority now.

An additional large percentage of my constituents will be serviced by the construction of a conventional high-powered national television transmitter in the shire of Mount Marshall. This program has had somewhat of a stop-start progress since it was first promised by the then Minister, Mr Staley. I thank the present Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) and the Government for including provision for the planning stage in the last Budget. I hope that the Government will continue to support this group of Australians by providing funding for the construction of the transmitter in the forthcoming Budget. The cost of the station per capita shows that it is still the least expensive means of delivering the service and will demonstrate the Government's continuing commitment to providing television in these areas.
I express my support for the views expressed by the Committee in section 19 of its summary and recommendations, which state:

As the ABC itself recognised in its submission, the highest priority must be the provision to country areas of the range of program choice heard on the two national radio channels, which is now available only in the capital cities and Newcastle.

I repeat that we should at least have a service to all Australians and preferably at the same cost to the individual as has applied in capital cities. Section 18 of the recommendations deals with the difficulties of people who receive only one program, whether it be radio or television. Most residents of my electorate have national transmission and the choice of the excellent programs supplied by the vigorous Golden West network. These residents probably have a service equal to that of any rural area in Australia. Of the remainder, those who receive a signal at all do suffer from the inability of the national station to provide a suitable choice for the wide variety of tastes that still exist in areas of low population.

Many of these people also suffer from the delusion that only the ABC provides repeat programs. However, it must be realised that, when one has no other station to turn to in order to avoid these repeats, not only do they become more noticeable but also is there a much greater possibility of having viewed or heard a program on a previous occasion.

Because large parts of Australia cannot attract the capital expenditure necessary for commercial viability, they are eternally locked into government television. Under these circumstances, it is imperative that programming be of the highest standard and public acceptance. When only one program is available, that program must be as popular as possible. The minority in this case is very real. However, the minority is not one with a specific interest. It is a small number of people with very general tastes.

If the ABC sees its role as that of being obliged to cater for specialist interest groups in the city, it must produce a separate program for distribution to areas in which its signal is the only one received. I appreciate that the minority interests of those minorities will not then be met. However, this becomes a burden that the remote areas have learned to bear. An excellent example of that occurred recently when the ABC decided to discontinue its direct telecast of night trotting and replace it with a program of European films with subtitles. This is not much help when the choice is between those films and turning the television knob to a blank screen.

The development of satellite transmission will allow the ABC to provide a total rural program including a greater percentage of local news and activities. Section 20 of the report refers to this issue. I hope this matter is considered by the Government and the ABC as one which should be given top priority. Naturally, the recommendations for the provision of second stations, in respect of both radio and television, will be received with gratitude by the people in my electorate. I am sure that they also see as meriting the top priority the universal transmission of high quality popular programming. In defining what is popular, let me introduce a personal viewpoint. The word 'popular' does not mean soap operas. I am sure our government station can produce high quality yet popular programs if it chooses to. Might I add that on many occasions it is my belief that it does just that.

Included in this rural programming I must raise the issue of international sport. The fact that such activity has now attracted the interest of commercial undertakings is only evidence of the huge appeal that such activities have to the general public. Such programs should not be denied to people who have the least opportunity to see them live. I will not accept that technical difficulties make transmission of these programs impossible for the ABC. Certainly on the advent of the satellite, ABC-only areas should be guaranteed access to these events. Considering the cost of promoting these events I would not object if the entire contents of a commercial transmission, including advertisements, were transmitted by the ABC with the revenue attracted by that greater audience remaining with the commercial station which held the rights.

The Committee also makes reference to the provision of frequency modulation radio to rural areas. It suggests that this transmission has probably less appeal than the two conventional stations of both radio and television, and I would agree. Nevertheless, the transmission of FM radio appears to cover a large area of my electorate and a large percentage of my constituents await the event enthusiastically. Some, including the residents of Albany, had expected transmission by now. One can imagine their disappointment when it was recently announced that due to technical problems relating to interference to other transmissions the entire program would be delayed for some years to accommodate a complete review of frequency allocations throughout Australia. Again, a worthwhile service is being withheld from country people while the real problems exist in the city. By that I refer to the crowding of the airwaves in those areas. I sincerely hope the Government will reconsider this decision and attack the problem in order of need and less of difficulty. It is quite obvious that in an area such as my electorate, which is not densely covered by any form of radio or television, the difficulty in finding slots for the FM program is not nearly as difficult and, of course, it would not impinge in any way on the east coast. If that is the case, I see no reason why that electorate or area should be included with all the great problems over here and why the problems which exist for my people should have to await the resolution of those problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —How big is the electorate?

—It is nearly as big as Victoria. The whole thing is that in those areas these particular niceties make a huge difference. When the men who operate agricultural plant and machinery get out at night, as they do today, to be able to have a choice of radio stations must be a great comfort. Might I add that some of my constituents no doubt would prefer that at least a percentage of the FM transmissions that the ABC currently produces was of a slightly lighter note. Nevertheless, I would like to think that if the Government took such an attitude it would guarantee a number of Western Australians the speedy resolution of a problem, while recognising that the problem in an Australia-wide context is quite significant. In this regard I would like to thank the Minister for Communications for considering that point of view when I put it to him the other day and for promising me that he would do his best to consider it.

SPEECH.PARA: All in all I think that this report has addressed itself to the huge problems of the ABC. I do not really want to buy into many of the technical and internal problems; I just wish to say for my electorate that the ABC will do, provided we all get the opportunity to hear it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The summary and main recommendations in volume 1 of the Dix report of the Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission begins with a quotation from T.S. Eliot:

SPEECH.PARA: A good past is positively dangerous if it makes us content with the present and so unprepared for the future.

The difficulty with the Australian Broadcasting Commission, which did such amazing pioneering work in the first years of Australian broadcasting and which put Australia permanently in its debt, has in a sense not kept up with the times . I suppose paradoxically one could say that it has kept up with the times in a sense that it has been seduced by the appeal of ratings. Because it has been seduced by the appeal of ratings it has felt that it has to provide a service not that is complementary to the commercial networks but which to a very large extent duplicates them. The ABC provides basically a first rate radio system and a third rate or fourth rate television system.

Sometimes heavy Commonwealth funding for some of the battleship companies, as we call them, like the Australian Opera, the Australian Ballet and, worst of all , the Australian Broadcasting Commission itself, has led to an extreme caution linked with a calcification of the imagination. The sheer volume of funding makes programmers feel that they have a responsibility to appeal to the largest possible audience. As a result they play safe, appealing, like the commercial channels, to the lowest common denominator rather than to the highest common multiple. In a sense they feel that the rationale for the considerable amount of Commonwealth funding that is provided in the Budget each year is to be found in getting high ratings. In other words, instead of using Commonwealth funding as an opportunity to provide innovative programs, programs that are different in quality and quantity from those that are available on the commercial networks, the ABC has tended, I think, in the last 10 or 15 years in particular, to play very safe indeed.

I want to talk a little about programming because I think in many ways the Dix Committee let the ABC down very lightly. If one looks at the ABC annual report for 1979-80 it will be seen that the operational payments for television amounted to $86,045,229. So we have this extraordinary phenomenon of the mountain labouring to produce a mouse. When we look at the actual programming that is provided week by week, it is very difficult to see that the ABC has put anything like as much of a significant contribution into programming as we have reason to expect. Paragraph 11.19 of volume 2 of the Dix report points out that there is a considerable difference between the proportion of programming time allocated by the ABC and what the commercial stations provide. The following table shows that that is so:

TALK.START.PARA: —That's TV games.

SPEECH.PARA: But when we look at what is broadcast in the evening, we find this rich program . At 6 o'clock Laff-a-Bits is broadcast. I do not even think I want to know what that is. TALK.START.PARA: —It was very good.

—I thought it was 30 minutes.

At 9.55 p.m. there will be news and weather and at 10.5 it will broadcast a series called Rock Arena starring someone called Gillan . At 10.45 they are all tired out and they go home. True it is that the SBS does not seem to have its primary appeal for people in the ethnic community for whom it was designed. It seems to be common ground that the people who watch channel--
—No, that's not altogether true.
—I bow to the superior wisdom of the shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs who, although he does not live in Melbourne, is a mine of information.
—A keen viewer.
—He is a keen viewer on the few lucky occasions when he is in Melbourne.
—Why are the ratings so poor?

—It is rating very poorly because it has not been promoted to any real extent, by this Government. I wish to express some concern about the future of music in Australia. —Talk about the music program.

—All right, I will talk about the music program. I will talk also about the existing concert department. There was a period-I think it is no longer true-when the ABC was the largest concert-giving organisation in the world and even now it probably ranks as No. 2. It has built up an enormous amount of expertise. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The hearing of this reference by the Committee of Privileges was a long one because the Committee found itself continually questioning the method by which such a hearing should be conducted. The fact, as revealed by the minority report from the honourable member for Lalor and the honourable member for Holt (Mr Duffy), they believed that the power to punish for contempt of Parliament should be removed from the jurisdiction of the Parliament and placed in the hands of the judiciary. Getting away from the difficulties involved in the actual consideration of this case, the report outlines a number of areas of concern which it believes ought to be the subject of a joint committee of inquiry. The basis of the Commonwealth Parliament's privilege is set out in section 49 of the Constitution, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The powers, privileges, and immunities of the Senate and the House of Representatives, and of the members and the committees of each House, shall be such as are declared by the Parliament, and until declared shall be those of the Commons House of Parliament of the United Kingdom and of its members and committees, at the establishment of the Commonwealth.

As the Parliament has not declared its powers except in relation to a few more minor matters, we have a situation in which the powers, privileges and immunities of this House and of the Senate are those which the United Kingdom's House of Commons had in 1901. In the circumstances, therefore, it seems wise for the Parliament, through the joint committee of inquiry, to look at the whole question of parliamentary privilege to see whether we ought to review the Parliament's powers in order that they might more closely reflect today's needs and, indeed, the rights and obligation of both members of parliament and the general public.

A number of questions arise for consideration. I mention just a few of the most important ones which I believe ought to be subject to review. Firstly, there is the method of raising complaints regarding privilege in the Parliament. A number of suggestions have been made for the revision of our Standing Orders in relation to this matter. I refer in particular to the Revised Arrangements adopted by the House of Commons in 1978. Secondly, there is the matter of the penalties which can be imposed by this Parliament. It has been suggested, quite correctly in my view, that the House should exercise its penal jurisdiction as sparingly as possible.

The third matter I raise is that of the rights of witnesses to be legally represented or advised when appearing before the Privileges Committee and the House if they are called to the Bar of the chamber. In the case dealing with Mr Laurie Oakes, requests for legal representation were made to the Committee by a witness and a potential witness. The Committee felt itself bound, under the Constitution, by the long standing parliamentary precedents of the United Kingdom prior to 1901. As is made clear in our report, since the 1770s the United Kingdom House of Commons Committee of Privileges has not heard counsel or solicitors on behalf of persons called before it. This is a matter which I believe ought to be considered. Even if the rights to legal representation are not agreed to, it may be appropriate to consider giving witnesses access to their legal advisers during Committee proceedings, as well as allowing such advisers to make submissions on behalf of their clients at a time determined by the Committee.
In relation to this matter, I quote paragraph 37 of our report to the Parliament, which states:

Having carefully considered the procedures adopted elsewhere and the undesirability of turning an inquiry by the Committee of Privileges into a court type situation, the Committee feels that there are good grounds for review and reform. It sees this issue as requiring early resolution by the proposed joint select inquiry.

The fourth matter of importance is the suggestion raised in one of the minority reports that inquiries such as are now undertaken by the Privileges Committee ought to be transferred to the courts. I believe the basis of this suggestion is that Parliament should not be, or indeed should not be seen to be, both prosecutor and judge in these matters. I have some grave reservations about transferring to the courts all or part of the Parliament's power in relation to privilege. Apart from any arguments concerning the separation of powers between the Parliament and the judiciary, I would have to be convinced that many of the findings of the 1966-67 United Kingdom Select Committee were not relevant and appropriate to our position in Australia. I quote three paragraphs from that report. Paragraph 142 of the United Kingdom report states:

This balance between the freedom of the individual and the essential protection of the House involves considerations of a political character which may vary according to the circumstances of the day. It is right that the House, which is responsible to the electorate, should make such decisions rather than that they should be made by an appointed tribunal, whether or not of a judicial character.
That Committee went on to state, in paragraph 143:

Once the decision has been made that a contempt has been committed, the question of the necessary penalty, if any, may again be governed by considerations of a political character. In practice, as pointed out by the Clerk of the House . . . the House has in recent years-
this is the United Kingdom House of Commons-

adopted a very much harsher approach to contempts committed by its own members than to those committed by strangers. If it has been judge in its own cause, it 'has been a very lenient judge in its own cause'. An outside tribunal-and in particular any branch of the Judiciary-would have very great difficulty in exercising a similar selective leniency and would undoubtedly be embarrassed by the need to take into account considerations of a political character.

If the jurisdiction were transferred to an outside tribunal, whether that tribunal dealt with both guilt and penalty or with only one of them, it would still be necessary for the House to decide in each case whether to refer the complaint to the tribunal. In order to make this decision the House would have to be satisfied that it would be proper to do so and accordingly in practice might have to give to the complaint the same consideration which would be given to it if the jurisdiction were retained by the House. There could, in Your Committee's opinion, arise embarrassment in the event of a conflict of view between the House and the ultimate tribunal.
The Committee went on to state:
Your Committee accordingly strongly recommend that the House should retain its penal jurisdiction.
I find the United Kingdom Committee's decision to be persuasive and, as I have said, I will want to be convinced that we should adopt a different procedure.

Finally, I refer to privilege in relation to the reporting of parliamentary proceedings not only by the media but also by Hansard. This, in my view, also ought to be considered by the joint committee and, if necessary, the laws in relation to the publication of parliamentary proceedings should be reviewed. I support the recommendation of the Privileges Committee for an inquiry to be carried out by a joint committee of the Senate and the House of Representatives and I hope that such a committee will consider the points that I have raised.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have made the point previously, I was absent from the Parliament when the matter of the referral to the Privileges Committee of the question of the article that appeared in the Sydney Daily Mirror in September 1981 was first raised. I have had more than a passing interest in the privilege of parliament, the privilege of parliamentarians, the relationship between parliament and the media and the laws of natural justice concerning the activities of parliament. It seems to me to be a very complex field. It is more than just a complex field; it is almost a minefield. I think all honourable members are aware that once action is taken by the Parliament and people are found in contempt of the Parliament the only penalty which can be imposed is that of gaol, as was done once by this Parliament in the early 1950s.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had in more recent times, as the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) would be aware, the powers of the Senate being used to call before it a person to answer questions. It was as if it were some sort of criminal investigation of the person. He could have been questioned by all senators who wanted to ask him questions. A good deal of notoriety surrounded the performance . I have always taken the view that Parliament is almost better off by remaining out of the field altogether. I am not greatly shaken by what people may say in the media about parliamentarians collectively. If they do so individually, there is a form of redress and many parliamentarians have followed that course quite successfully. But if a person says something about parliamentarians collectively , we have the opportunity not only to deny it in this place but also to take it further and perhaps put that person's reputation and performance to the test.

Once we proceed, as was the case in September of last year, to bring under discussion before the Privileges Committee the question of contempt, the Parliament really does get itself into an awful mess. No one can say that the exercise conducted by the Parliament late last year enhanced the position or stature of the Parliament. It did quite the opposite. A lot of angry parliamentarians decided that they would not put up with this sort of thing and that they would try to do something about it. It seems to me that the whole thing backfired because we happened to give the matter prominence and anybody who did not buy the Daily Mirror-that was most people in Australia, thank God- was made aware of the article that had previously been published in that newspaper by virtue of our reaction in this Parliament. I know from looking at Hansard that there were divided views and feelings among members of this Parliament about this matter but, as I said, my view would have been to let sleeping dogs lie. There is very little we can do about it.

I think we as members of parliament should try to overcome the enormous problem that we have in our relationships with the public. We cannot quite understand why members of the public think so poorly of us although we all work so hard. When someone happens to take a shot at us by saying something which is not true we tend to want to fight back in order to rectify what we think is a very imbalanced view of our role in society. But we cannot do it that way. We cannot do it via the Privileges Committee, nor can we enhance the role of the Parliament by thinking we can do what the Senate did and bring people before us to answer questions in order to make some political points.

There is greater freedom in other parliaments. I must say that I was amazed to find when I was in Spain last year that Press members have access to every part of the Spanish Parliament. In this building there are very small areas where only members of parliament can go. In the Spanish Parliament there is no section of the building to which the Press does not have complete access. It raises the question in a democracy of the particular role and responsibilites of the Press and parliament and how best to play our role in this regard. I think it is extremely difficult, virtually impossible, to start writing rules about how we can get even with people who say things, as outrageous as they may be, about us collectively in this place. Unfortunately, the vast majority of people who live in Australia like reading them. They happen to coincide with the view that they have of us. They do not read it all that often. Nevertheless, we rate in popularity with the public about one percentage point above child molesters and about five percentage points below starting price bookies and jockeys. Honourable members can see that our standing in the community is not all that great. When we take action such as that which we took last September people tend to side with the person whom they think the Parliament is trying to stamp on or restrict. There is no way in which we can win.

When the Committee met and tried to sort out what path it would follow in bringing this matter to some sort of logical conclusion it invited the author to attend its hearings but the author was not all that attracted to the idea. He just said that he was not interested in attending the Committee's hearings. But if the Committee had gone on with the matter and reached the situation reached in the early 1950s the author could have found himself in gaol because there are no other powers available to the Parliament, and again the Parliament would have been held in ridicule as a result of such action.

If we were mad enough to set up a group of people to go through every document that is printed in Australia every day of the week, every week of the month, every month of the year, to see how many people vilify parliamentarians we would have a non-ending session of the Privileges Committee seeing whom it should get hold of because of the things they were saying about us. The House will recall that one of the persons called before the Parliament on a matter of privilege in 1953 was a person by the name of Browne, who passed away recently. He was involved in putting out a newsletter called Things I Hear. It used to upset many people besides parliamentarians. There is also the Toorak Times, which is not a bad little journal. No one knows quite who writes for it, who owns it or who is responsible for it, but out it comes and it is circulated in the thousands.

It is just not possible in a democracy to do the sorts of things that Parliament attempted to do last September. We should have had more intelligence than to try to do it in that way. I am afraid that we shall have to be a little tougher, to steel ourselves against these sorts of attacks, or try to answer them here in the way in which we do. If people go overboard and attack someone personally, the avenues are open to that person. The $3,000-a-day men are always there waiting in their offices to get someone's brief. One is almost half way home, if one has a good case, as soon as the newspaper receives the letter. So one has plenty of protection. The laws of natural justice apply outside. I should have thought that the libel laws as they exist in Australia are as stringent as they would be in most other parts of the Western world. I think that is the safeguard against personal abuse or personal misrepresentation, or an attempt by any section of the media to bring a person's political career to an end. But I do not think it is possible- and I am afraid that our most recent exercise in this matter has proved that it is almost futile-to use the instrument of Parliament to try to make it appear as though we can prevent people in any form of the media from saying what they want to say about parliamentarians collectively.

We are going to set up another committee, which is probably the 8,000th committee that we have had in the last 500 years in the Westminister system, to see what it can do, and I am pretty sure that it will have the same result as all previous committees.
