TALK.START.PARA: —Last week there was an important debate in this House in respect of the claims made by Vietnam veterans for a judicial inquiry. In the course of that debate statements were made by both myself and the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson), who was speaking for and on behalf of the Government. A Press release was issued over the weekend by members of the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia which deals quite specifically with some of the points raised in that debate. It sets out their viewpoint. In order to see that the views of Vietnam veterans on matters which are of concern to them are before the Parliament so that honourable members can have the benefit of considering all the issues as the veterans themselves see them, I seek leave to have that statement incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Press Release from the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia
The Vietnam Veterans Association is extremely disappointed that the Prime Minister was not prepared to answer personally the charges made against him in the Parliament last Thursday.
The response for the Government to those charges by the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr David Thomson, was totally inadequate and factually wrong.
Some examples of his wrong statements are:

1. The Minister said only the VVAA supports the judicial inquiry, among ex- service organisations. We wish to point out to the Minister that, on 11 August, 1981, at an RSL-convened conference in Canberra, 27 out of 28 ex-service organisations present (including the Korea and South East Asian Forces Association) voted to support an independent judicial inquiry. That inquiry has also been supported by the Senate, the Sydney Morning Herald, the Labor Party and the Democracts, among others.

2. The Minister said that the RSL has not called for a judicial inquiry. In May , 1980, the RSL New South Wales State Congress voted, by 499 to 1, to support a judicial inquiry. The New South Wales Branch represents about half the RSL membership. This decision was put before the RSL National Executive by Sir Colin Hines, New South Wales President, on 7 September, 1980. It was not voted on because of statements made to that meeting by Sir William Keys, RSL National President. Sir Colin Hines said in ''Reveille'' (March/April, 1981, Vol. 56, No. 2) that he had been overruled. A statement was made to that meeting by Major- General (retired) D. Vincent, who was Commander, Armed Forces, Vietnam, 1967-68, that he knew the chemicals were dangerous, but he was acting under Government instructions in ordering their use by Australian forces, and that he did not realise the full extent of the dangers until 1980.

3. The Minister said that the Government had initiated a program of epidemiological studies. He is apparently unaware that his own Ministerial colleague, the Minister for Veterans Affairs, Senator Messner, announced on 15 February, 1982, that the Government had scrapped the major study.

4. The Minister said that Government Departments are co-operating fully with the current inquiry being conducted by the Senate Standing Committee on Science and Environment. Having discussed that inquiry at great length with the Committee and their Secretariat, I can quite categorically state that Committee Members have expressed considerable concern at the lack of co-operation they have had from all of the Government Departments involved (Veterans' Affairs, Health and Defence).

5. The Minister said that the VVAA does not represent Vietnam veterans. Without the VVAA, the RSL would not have done anything about our claims, there would be no Senate Committee inquiry, no Government-sponsored studies, no counselling centres and no public concern.

6. The Minister said only 63 veterans had visited counselling centres in Sydney and Adelaide since they were established. Our information is that those centres have had over 340 clients, and are having trouble handling the workload. Already they are seeking more staff. On 16 July, 1981, at a meeting in Canberra with the Minister for Veterans Affairs and his senior advisers, we proposed the type of counselling service which we believe was and is necessary. The Minister refused to accept our submission and established a much more limited service. Even though the current service is so limited, the already demonstrated level of demand indicates the problems that Vietnam veterans are experiencing, along with the effects of those problems on our families. In a recent article the Sydney Morning Herald reported that the Adelaide Counselling Service alone was receiving 10 clients a day.

7. The Minister quoted two scientific reports as evidence for the Government's case that the chemicals were not linked with the long term illnesses now suffered by Vietnam veterans. The Government-appointed Repatriation Review Tribunal, in its ''Reasons for Decision'' in the recent Simpson case, found that there was sufficient evidence of these links to award a pension to Mrs Simpson. It should be noted that, in that case, the RRT only considered evidence about the US dispersal of defoliants, and only phenoxyacetic herbicides at that, and did not consider other evidence of the use of chemicals by Australian forces. We have long pointed out, on the public record, our concern about both US and Australian forces' use of both arsenic-based Agent Blue and the organophosphate insecticide, Malathion. Has Mr Thomson personally read the 1967 Midwest Research Institute report which he quoted in the Parliament? Apparently not, for he would have found, for example, the following statement:

''Arsenicals, particularly the trivalent forms of arsenic, have long been regarded as either carcinogens or possibly as co-carcinogens. In either case there is reason to be wary of the widespread distribution of these materials until evidence of their long-term safety under the conditions of use has been obtained.'' (Assessment of Ecological Effects of Extensive or Repeated Use of Herbicides, Midwest Research Institute, 1967, pp. 163, 164'.

8. The Minister said that the chemicals used in Vietnam were, and still are, commercially available and used within Australia. There is a wealth of public evidence that most of the chemicals used in Vietnam were not of the same composition as those used in Australia, the US, and elsewhere, at the time or since. As the Minister should know, both because of his own military experience and his responsibilities as a Minister of the Crown, peacetime precautions often cannot be followed in wartime. The Government's own report, ''Pesticides Used In Vietnam Hostilities and Their Use in Australian Agriculture: A Comparative Study ,'' says: ''Once again, however, it must be stressed that difficulties are encountered during conditions of war which prevent the rigid adoption of precautions that can be applied in peacetime. . . . . . . . . . . Although the regulations were designed to protect personnel from potential adverse health effects, it is impossible to determine the extent to which they were met.'' (p. 32).

9. The Minister defended strongly the public servants in the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The real problem, for Vietnam veterans, is the attitudes of most of the senior management in the DVA. We are not critical of DVA junior staff who are restricted by these attitudes, and who in any case do not make major decisions. The appearances of the Vietnam Special Studies Group personnel from the DVA before the Senate Committee's inquiry have been less than impressive. My Association is concerned also at the recent speech made by the DVA Permanent Head, Mr D. Volker, where he foreshadowed major legislative and administrative changes to the repatriation system.

In summary then, we are very concerned that the Government has still not examined the detailed evidence which we believe supports our claims. We are forced to repeat, yet again, our call for a judicial inquiry, outside the political arena, which can impartially assess that evidence.
We are also disappointed that, despite mounting evidence in support of our claims, the Government's attitude to our problems is the same as it was over two years ago.
21 March, 1982

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to raise the question of the funding of support schemes for homeless youth, particularly in Western Australia. I will outline the two major contributions of the Commonwealth in this field and, I hope, provoke some statement of the intention of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) in the future. On 1 July 1979 a three-year project in youth accommodation was supposed to commence. It was going to be funded dollar for dollar by the Commonwealth and the Western Australian Government. A total of $83,500 was to be provided by each government per year to reach a project total of about half a million dollars. One per cent of this total was to be spent on evaluation. The Youth Support Services Program was to allocate funds while the Western Australian Department of Community Welfare was to provide administration . No funds were received in the first year. On 5 March 1981, $51,990 was provided, half from each government. In this financial year, 1981-82, $44,800 has been provided plus a top-up for last year of $22,700. This is a total of about $120,000.

SPEECH.PARA: The scheme is soon to end. The planned evaluation has not eventuated and, indeed, given these delays and reductions in funding no reasonable assessment could be made. However, the lack of meaningful evaluation means that very little has been learned about the best ways to house young people in need. The Youth Accommodation Coalition, a group of representatives of voluntary organisations concerned with this problem, estimates that 50 per cent of the money allocated to the scheme has gone towards administration and development, leaving only the other 50 per cent for direct spending on housing for the homeless. How accurate this assessment is we cannot say because no direct evaluation is taking place. Given this situation, there is good reason to be concerned that money so vitally needed may well have been wasted.

The second matter of concern is the capital grant of a quarter of a million dollars through the Department of Social Security to Jesus People Incorporated. It appears that Jesus People was the only group which knew how to apply for the money. Certainly the Youth Accommodation Coalition did not know. The Minister for Social Security has advocated on various occasions the small suburban house type of emergency accommodation. This makes it all the more surprising that a quarter of a million dollars should be given to one group to house 25 to 30 young people. In my electorate there is a small group called the Victoria Park Youth Accommodation Coalition, which is a member of the broader group of a similar name to which I have already referred. Last year the Victoria Park group was given a once-off grant of $300 from the Western Australian Department of Community Welfare to provide youth accommodation. It is successfully housing five people in separate rooms in a suburban house while charging these people less rent than the Jesus People, for example, charge for dormitory accommodation . An important part of the Victoria Park scheme is an arrangement of compulsory saving that after a few months gives each young person enough to put towards a bond and the other once-off costs associated with moving into privately rented accommodation.

This comparison leads one to ask just how this $250,000 of taxpayers' money is being spent-how much is to be capital expenditure, how much will go in wages and administration and what evaluation is to be made both of the expenditure and of the service provided. Further, it needs to be asked will any more of these grants be made? Will the Youth Accommodation Coalition be notified in the future when a grant is to be made? In particular, I wonder if this problem is occurring only in Western Australia or is money to be handed out with such apparent lack of consultation and concern for the immediate needs of the homeless young people in other States? I do not wish to attack any organisation helping to house homeless young people. They all fill a very important role. But from information I have been given I believe there is a need for much greater attention to evaluation of the effects of money spent in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falconer Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to draw the House's attention to undertakings given by the Australian Labor Party in Victoria to repeal certain very vital legislation in that State should the Labor Party become the government of Victoria after 3 April. I think I should preface my remarks by noting that the Labor Opposition in Victoria has claimed in some of its campaign statements that it has a special relationship with the unions, that it has a co-operative relationship which would enable it to manage industrial affairs more efficiently and with less industrial disruption than the present Liberal Government.
—Absolutely true.

—We hear it from the honourable member for Burke. He says that is absolutely true. Of course, he must be forgetting about the very real example we have in front of us at the moment in New South Wales. New South Wales, and the Australian Capital Territory as a consequence, are suffering very real disadvantages, very real shortages of electricity because of union action. It is precisely that sort of situation which the Victorian Government has managed to prevent to a very large extent not only with better planning than the New South Wales Labor Government but also with some very effective industrial legislation which it has been possible to use at key points in order to ensure that essential supplies and services flow to the community.

SPEECH.PARA: I would point first to the Vital Projects Act which was available when the Newport power station was being built. At the time of the construction of that power station we received many representations and suggestions from people who thought that this station was not needed. I think we can draw a great deal from the New South Wales experience at the present time. The present situation shows that the Newport power station was very badly needed. Indeed, Victoria would be very badly off and New South Wales would be very badly off if it were not for that power station. The Newport power station was able to be built because of the Vital Projects Act which enabled its construction to proceed.

Construction of the very large Loy Yang power station complex was started within a very short time-indeed, within one working day-of the Wrongs (Public Projects) Act being introduced into the Parliament. The Wrongs Act in this instance was used to guarantee power supplies later in this decade. The Wrongs Act enables the Minister or the statutory authority concerned to take action to recover damages which have been incurred as a result of irresponsible union action. As a result of the introduction of that Act into the Victorian Parliament, the Loy Yang power staton complex was able to be got underway after some very irresponsible blocking action. The Labor Opposition in Victoria is committed to the repeal of that Act.

Also, we saw the use of the Essential Services Act last July when the Transport Workers Union held up supplies, including rather incredibly milk, to the Victorian community. Milk supplies had usually been exempted from previous industrial action by the Transport Workers Union. Milk began flowing to the community within half an hour of orders being made arising out of the Essential Services Act. That legislation allowed that crippling transport and waterfront dispute to be broken last year for the benefit of the Victorian community. Furthermore, we have the example of the secret ballots legislation in Victoria. We have not yet really seen this legislation properly tested. Nevertheless, it does provide a basis of protection for the rights of individuals. It gives some unions which would seek to trample on the rights of individuals cause to think carefully about any action they may take in this direction.

The Victorian Labor Opposition is committed to repealing all four pieces of legislation. These three pieces of legislation have been demonstrated to be of importance to the welfare of the Victorian community in emergency situations. They are reasonable and responsible pieces of legislation which are not used often or in an irresponsible way. They are not called upon without just cause. They are available for government to use if an emergency situation arises. It is disgraceful to think that the Victorian ALP has committed itself to the repeal of the legislation. It is obviously ignoring the welfare of the Victorian community. The Victorian Labor Opposition's position is largely explainable because of the attitude taken by the Victorian Socialist Left of which some members opposite, including the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous), are a part. They have influenced the Victorian ALP to take this irresponsible attitude in response to the urgings of the Halfpennys and the Gallaghers of this world rather than in response to the urgings of responsible and moderate elements of the trade union movement and in response to the Victorian community generally.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to read just a few letters I have received. I put them forward as a petition to the Australian Government and to the Canadian Government. Dear Mr Charles, Having watched on TV and read in the newspapers, the horrific slaughter of harp seal pups, I would like you to petition the Prime Minister to ban the import of all seal products and also all Canadian goods, until the killing of these harp seal pups no longer takes place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Almost 12 months ago I spoke in the adjournment debate about the problem of parallel scheduling of flights by the two domestic airlines. Following that, I contacted both airlines and I had responses from the managers of both to the extent that, once the new generation of aircraft were put into the air, parallel scheduling would cease. At this stage, we have not seen the cessation of parallel scheduling that I would have liked to note. In fact, there has been very little movement at all in this respect. Certainly, some flights of the two airlines leave at almost the same time, with a variation of about five, 10 or 15 minutes. But there has been nothing of note that has given me any reason to think that the airline companies have done anything in this regard. Worse still, the recent decision of the Wran Government in New South Wales to continue daylight saving for an additional month has thrown all schedules into crisis. The amazing thing is that, where parallel scheduling existed before, both companies have seen fit to take off certain flights at the same time because of the crisis. As a result, the situation for a place such as Mackay, which was serviced through to Brisbane with afternoon flights, is that all of a sudden, because of the crisis through daylight saving in New South Wales, those flights have been withdrawn at exactly the same time. In fact, in order to be here for a 2 o'clock commencement on a Tuesday sitting day, I have to leave Mackay at 11.45 a.m. on the Monday. I do not think this is good enough.

SPEECH.PARA: I have not yet had the advantage of seeing the schedules of one airline for the coming winter session but I have certainly seen the ones for the other airline. I hope that the system that we saw introduced to overcome the crisis with daylight saving will not be continued later. Certainly, I draw to the attention of the airlines that the majority of Australians believe that there should not be the parallel scheduling that has gone on in the past. As both companies have adopted the new generation of aircraft they should commence separate scheduling. If it is not possible to that extent, perhaps each company could take turns about each month to make sure that there is a greater servicing of the Australian public through different timings.

I have also spoken in the adjournment debate in the past about smoking on aircraft or smoking in public places. I understand that the statistics prove that 70 per cent of people do not smoke but are allowed to suffer because of the 30 per cent who do. I do not think anybody believes that a person who smokes does not have the right do so. But I think the 70 per cent who do not smoke also have the right to be able to breathe air free of pollution by those people who do smoke. I was very interested in a letter that appeared during the week in a major Australian publication, the Bulletin, which exemplifies the problem that we poor 70 per cent feel in this regard. The letter reads:
I have just emerged, gasping and sore-eyed, from the smoke-filled interior of a domestic airliner.

While it is gratifying to see a steady increase in the number of non-smoking seats one must ask: 'When is Australian airline management going to have enough courage to ban completely this ultra-selfish habit?'
Please understand that I do feel considerable sympathy for smokers as a group-
I am not sure that I do-
I have witnessed desperate attempts by friends to shake off this distressing addiction-
I have also known people in that regard-
but I do object to having to share their discomfort by being forced to breathe their pollution.

To allow any 'smoking' seats at all in aircraft only encourages the continuation of this anti-social habit and does not convey adequately to the smoking minority the disapproval which most non-addicts feel. Smoking should be placed officially in the category of those things which are done only by consenting adults in private.

Over the last 12 months we have seen dramatic increases in air fares as a result , among other things, of the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares. I believe that the compartmentalisation of the non-smokers away from the smokers is additional cost to the fare which is not warranted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make one remark about the comments by the honourable member for Casey (Mr Falconer). I think that the Victorian people will determine quite clearly whether they prefer the confrontation nonsense approach to industrial relations that he outlined or the kind of approach based on negotiations among employers, employees and government. The result will bear out which is the best approach to achieve harmony in industrial relations. Should, by any terrible misdeed, there be a re-election to power of the Victorian Liberal Government, which I do not foresee, Victoria would be in for a period of industrial disharmony of the kind which has never been envisaged in the State.

SPEECH.PARA: Leaving that point aside, what I want to talk about is the announcement at a meeting of the Ministers for immigration and ethnic affairs in Hobart on 12 March of the decision to set up a special action plan to help migrant women who are suffering from the problems of marriage breakdown and associated welfare problems. I am rather sad that this has happened in Australia 30 years or more after the wave of migration began. The problem has been with us for more than two generations. It is somewhat late at this time for the Ministers to get together and talk about an action plan. Nevertheless, it is better later than never. I welcome the action plan and I hope that certain positive developments will come out of it.

One of the things that it will look at is the role of women's refuges in assisting migrant women. For the Commonwealth Government at least to show some interest in women's refuges is quite extraordinary given the kind of action which was taken last year by the razor gang in which responsibility for women's refuges was completely dropped by the Federal Government and put into the hands of the States to deal with in whatever way they chose. At that time many women's groups around the nation complained bitterly that this would result in reductions in funding for women's refuges and this has in fact happened in several States. But, with respect to the problems of migrant women coming to these refuges, the fact is that in the past no facilities have been provided. The refuges have not had the funds to be able to deal with migrant women nor have they had qualified people who understand the kinds of cultural problems that arise in marriage breakdowns of people from different cultures, especially Southern European, Middle Eastern and Asian cultures.

The fact is that the traditional marriage set-up is considered to be a much stronger bond amongst quite a few of these ethnic communities; yet the pressures they have had to face within the Australian situation have led to considerable breakdown in these communities. For example, in the Turkish community in Victoria there are serious problems of breakdown of marriage. The women, because they know very little about how to cope with this situation, are forced into total isolation. In my electorate, some of them have not even been provided with the facilities to enable them to get around by public transport. For various reasons the husband has left his wife and the wife has been left in the home to cope with the children without any welfare services. If the Government is really serious about wanting to do something in this area, it needs to think very hard about increasing the number of ethnic social workers and those working specifically on these sorts of problems.

NOTE: An abbreviated description of my Department's responses is included in the table. An expansion of the terms used under RESPONSE in the table is provided below.

Reviewed: In response to a complaint about a particular doctor, statistical data are gathered on the doctor's claiming pattern and analysed for apparent irregularities. Where it appears that fraud may be involved and further action by way of investigation is required, the matter is referred to Departmental investigation personnel. Where there is sufficient indication that overservicing may be involved, the matter is referred to a Medical Counsellor. Information arising from a review of medial benefit claims which is insufficient to justify either course of action is normally recorded and re-evaluated if additional information is subsequently received.

Investigated: Where the information received from the fund and that arising from a review of claims indicate that possible fraud or overservicing may be involved, the case is referred to Departmental Investigators. Following detailed examination of available information, an investigator will normally recommend one of the following courses of action:
the undertaking of patient interviews where fraud is suspected;
the referral to Medical Counsellors where overservicing is suspected;

referral to a Medical Services Committee of Inquiry (MSCI) where the doctor has previously been counselled, or where he has been before a Committee previously, or where there are indications of gross overservicing.
If patient interviews are undertaken where fraud is suspected, investigators will ascertain whether there are substantial grounds for referral of the case to the Australian Federal Police.

Referred to AFP: Where evidence acquired by Departmental investigators indicates there are substantial grounds for referral, the case is referred to the Australian Federal Police for fraud investigation and possible prosecution. The referral indicates the alleged breaches and is accompanird by all documentation obtained in support of the allegations such as patient statements.

Referred to Medical Counsellor: Where a review or investigation indicates that overservicing may be involved, the information is usually referred to a Departmental Medical Counsellor for examination. If he considers that excessive services may have been rendered he will normally discuss the matter with the doctor concerned. If the Medical Counsellor considers that there was overservicing he will counsel the doctor. If the doctor does not respond to counselling (as indicated by the pattern of claims received for his services in the months immediately following counselling), his case is likely to be referred to an MSCI.

Referred to MSCI: Following unsuccessful counselling, or where extreme overservicing is indicated following an investigation of claims, a case is referred to an MSCI to determine whether particular services are considered to be excessive (that is, not reasonably necessary for the adequate medical care of the patients concerned).

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Vietnam: Use of Malathion and Agent Blue

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his answer to question No. 2733 (Hansard, 29 October 1981, page 2797) can he now state what chemicals were included in the recent study by Marie T. Mulcahy, Medical Journal of Australia, 15 November 1980, pages 573-4, as chemicals which may have caused chromosomal damage in Vietnam veterans.

(2) If Malathion and Agent Blue were not included in that study, is he able to state (a) why this was so, (b) whether he has any evidence in his possession which would indicate possible chromosomal damage, following exposure to these chemicals and (c) what are the references for that evidence.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In Dr Mulcahy's letter it is stated that men who claimed exposure to Agent Orange were those subjected to cytogenetic examination.

(2) (a) The letter would indicate that Malathion and Agent Blue were not specifically considered because the subjects were self selected and the author had no control over selection in relation to alleged exposure.

(b) Neither my Department nor I have any evidence that Agent Blue causes chromosomal damage. My Department has a number of reports of studies of the possible mutagenicity of Malathion. The results of these studies are inconsistent and do not sustain the interpretation that Malathion is mutagenic.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What instructions has he given Medibank regarding the limit of expenditure on chiropractic services on which insurance is to be offered.
(2) Will he allow Medibank to raise this limit if Medibank decides it is commercially attractive to do so.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) None. Benefits towards the cost of paramedical services such as those rendered by chiropractors are paid from anciliary tables conducted by registered health funds. There is no specific provision in the health insurance legislation relating to the operation of ancillary tables. Accordingly, health funds, including Medibank Private, are largely free to determine for themselves the nature and extent of the services for which anciliary benefits are payable, in light of contributor demand and their competitive position in the market place.

(2) The Government does not stand in the way of any health fund that wishes to increase its ancillary benefits provided that contributions are sufficient to finance the benefits payable. In this, I am guided by the advice of the Registration Committee that is constituted under the National Health Act to make recommendations to me on such matters. This Committee includes a representative of the Commonwealth Actuary.
